Tasted at Tolkiens House pub, Zagreb, Croatia.
Very nice aroma and taste wheat beer.

Pours a a deep brown with a hint of ruby and a lively head which dissapears almost immediately but continues to effervesce gently. An immediate waft of apricot and cranberry escapes the glass as soon as I pick it up to get a sniff. As it approaches my nose these lighter fruits are replaced by toffee apple and damson jam. A lightly bitter medium sweet beer with caramelised vinous flavours, fairly sticky and full bodied, though at the same time surprisingly light for such a dark beer. Im not sure which spices are used in the brew, but they certainly help to disguise the high ABV (8%) which makes it dangerous quaffable. Faint taste of ginger gives way to a long and fruity finish, leaving the taste of a good port in your mouth. Im a fan [330ml bottle]

Chevy Case, DC 11.2 ($7): Was excited to see this and decided it was worth a buy. Pours a blackish brown with barely any head and barely any carbonation. Aroma is of a whole lot of things like cake, chocolate, spices, malts, malts, cake. Taste doesnt have quite as much cake, but is pleasant enough. Not too sweet, although plenty sweet enough. Smoke and a whole lot of spices, especially, to no ones surprise, coriander. Very low carbonation makes for a flattish mouthfeel, but not really unpleasant in any way.
Ho trovato davvero meravigliosa questa traditional ale, ecco come degli scozzesi che sanno il fatto loro riescono a sorprenderti con cotanta bellezza...

The beer pours a dark brown color with a white head. The aroma is heavy on the toffee with some dark fruit and some peat malt. The flavor is very similar. I get a lot of peat malt, dark cherries, toffee, light smoke and some alcohol. I also get a little bit of clove and black pepper notes. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. A very nice Scotch Ale. Glad I got to try this one.

Appearance:  dark, syrupy brown pour, short head quickly vanishes; no lacing.  Aroma:  molasses, prunes, hint of chocolate and coffee, then a bit of spice.  Taste:  as the aroma indicates, although not very sweet, and pretty herbal and earthy, with notes of leather, spices, and wood.  Finish:  smooth, with the flavors lingering quite a bit.  Notes:  Had this quite some time ago; rating from notes.  Did not rate it very high, so Im guessing I will need to try it again.

Pours dark brown with red, like mahogany. Light off-white head that dissipates quickly, leaving a halo. Brown sugar, malts, raisins on the nose. Medium bodied old ale flavor with spices, but very well balanced and subtle. I would guess that the coriander masks the alcohol a bit, because it does not seem like an 8% beer to me. As this beer warms up, more sugars come to the front. Sweetness combined with spices, malts, and dark fruit, but not in a "holiday" beer way. Very well executed old ale. Tasted at 50F, 55F, & 60F.

Pours a dark caramel/chestnut brown color with bright mahogany edges when held to a light and a half finger light beige head that quickly settles into a thin lasting ring. Sporadic spots of lacing left behind.

Sweet roasted malt aroma thats bursting with sweet cocoa and caramel notes as well as some zesty coriander and other spice. Slightly smokey with faint coffee bean presence as well as some toffee and hazelnut, toast and dark fruit. This beer smells very good.

Medium bodied with a good balance of roast, sweet malt and spice. Lots of caramel and toffee flavor as well as some cocoa, hazelnut and licorice. The sweetness is balanced by a slight roasted/smokey character and a prominent zesty spice presence. Hints of coriander, pepper and subtle clove. Im also picking up some citrus fruit and alcohol sweetness but the smooth malt and spice flavors dominate. Well balanced with an extremely well masked ABV make this beer extremely quaffable. Recommended.

Pours nearly black, ruby in the light, one finger of beige head that dissipates quickly. Smell is roasty, chocolaty, herbal earth notes, coriander, slight aroma of coffee as well. Taste is roasty, herbal, coriander, spice, chocolaty, coffee, very complex and "fresh" tasting. Thin and slightly watery mouthfeel, light carbonation but quite refreshing and not heavy at all.

This traditional ale pours dark amber with a small, light tan head. The aroma is a bit of leather and spices. The flavor is starts out earthy and peaty, but not too much. There is no sweetness, more like a light-bodied porter overall.

Bottle at Universal Caffe, Rome. Pours black as Coke with a small tanned head. Complex aroma of dark roasted malts, liquorice and spices. Taste is the same with some delicious light roasted malts, dark caramel, vanilla and other spices. Lingering malty aftertaste. Great.

Reviewed from notes. Picked up at Chevy Chase Wine & Spirits in the District.

Poured into a snifter. The color is a nice, dark copper/caramel color with a very thin off white head that does not really leave behind any lacing at all. The nose is caramel, toffee, bread, and hints of dark fruits. Some slight alcohol there as well. The taste is fairly one dimensional with a faint caramel and toffee sweetness. No really fruit presence. Perhaps a bit of nuttiness. Medium mouthfeel with fairly low carbonation and a bit of booze. Fairly plain without much going on; this was a bit of a disappointment.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 10-23-2010

Dark Amber, small head, no lacing.  Taste is balance between caramel and smokey musty peat moss (what coriander?)  Only negative is a greasy quality that carries through a mild finish.  Good quaff, not great.

33ml bottle. Finally got around to reviewing this great Scottish ale after sampling it in larger bottles in tastings. I got 6 of these smaller samples and drank them served warmer with a range of foods. Deep brown color with a small cap. Modest carbonation. Aroma is delicate but complex; musty sweetness, roasty grains, light smoke, spice and herbs.Flavor profile approximates a wee heavy with ample sweet malts, smokey peat tones some herbal tones and coriander. Wet finish with roasty bittering and light sweetness. The consumate Scots ale.

UPDATED: JUN 28, 2011 20 june 2011, bottle. dark amber, clear, no bubbles, thin bubbly head. nice aroma. raisin, alcohol, meaty nose. sugary malt but hard to pinpoint exact spices used. med body and faintly fizzy. great! sugary malt, rich raisins. alcohol is well hidden. gorgeous!


(original rating - 7,3,6,3,12 = 3.1)
ruby coloured, clear w/ no bubbles
can smell the 8% right away. 
roasted coffee smell is big initially, then rich bready aromas
thin/med body
reminds me of a belgian dubel. bready and higher abv
not terribly complex. ok

UPDATED: JUN 22, 2014 Pours dark with a beige head. Aroma is nutty with tobacco, chocolate, leather and roasted notes. The taste add some coffee, roasted malts, dark dried fruits, liquorice, caramel and some spice leading to a dry end.

Very dark amber/ruby color.  Bright ruby highlights around the bottom and edges.  A tan head with huge bubbles and not much size or retention.  A tad of lacing left behind.  Picking up hints of dark roasted malt with some burnt grain.  Some dark fruit sweetness in the aroma also.  Some earthy tones reminiscent of some "smoke."  Kind of even smells like a red wine.  Some dark fruit in the taste.  Similar to a prune.  Some roasted malt in the taste.  Minute amounts of bitterness.  Just a hint of coriander, but not much however.  A touch of alcohol.  A touch of smoke in the flavor also.  Medium/full mouthfeel.  Some alcohol warmth.  Leaves plenty on the palate.  Mostly smooth.  This beer is just ok for me.  Nothing I will seek out really.  Wasnt real easily drinkable.  The combination of flavors and aromas were ok for 1 beer, but not something I want to try again or make a night of.

330 ml bottle - pours a clear, dark mahogany with a two-finger cream coloured head that reduces to a thin layer after 5 minutes or so.  Aroma of blackberries, brown sugar, molasses, herbal.  Flavour is herbal, malty, dark fruit, fruitcake, slightly spicy.  Medium finish.  Slight anise present.  I like it, though not as much as most on here.

Absolutely wonderful aroma, thickly wafting up from the surface of this brown beer is a scent reminiscent of candied fruit and a little bit of hoppy citrus. Very unique blend of scents which is very enticing. Pours dark reddish brown, dissipating cream coloured head. Expect big taste from this beer, prunes, a bit of soil, slightly chocolate notes. It is not as sweet as the aroma would suggest, it has a dry aftertaste with some alcohol. Somewhere along the line the palate of this beer stumbles a bit, the beer is simply too thin for the amount of flavour and alcohol present. A minor misstep, still a very nice beer, definitely worthwhile.

Bottle. Pours a dark brown with not much of a head. Aroma is strongly of liquorice and anise, some roastedness and a bit of tar. Taste is filled with liquorice and anise, some caramel and spiciness. Palate is excellently full and smooth. Probably the best that Ive ever had.
This is a fantastic beer. Caramel notes balanced palate, all you can ask for.

pours murky dark brown, almost black with a small disappearing head. dark chocolate malts, burnt caramel-toffee, bourbon, vanilla, smoke, coffee, and a hint of herbal spices. not sure to taste coriander, but it tastes herbal goodness. low carbonation, silky, oily and old ale feeling. masterpiece!

bottle - Pours very dark brown with a minimal head.  Theres a wonderful, rich dark fruit aroma that includes cherries and grapes.   The flavor is of sweet malt, dark fruit, subdued spices, and caramel.  This medium bodied brew has gentle carbonation with finishes lightly sweet with a little alcohol.  Excellent.

Super good if pricy! Carbonated, smelling of fruit and sugar, much like the flavor. Medium to Medium heavy body. Very English - roasted chocolate, fruit explosions, mild mocha lingering feeling, some molasses, some "Belgian" candy-ish spirit.

Delicious spicy and strong beer. Thin head that dissipated quickly. Dark malty colour with an orange tinge. Unique and complex like the very best. Though the strength can be felt, its not overly alcoholic. Excellent brew.
330ml bottle.  Pours a very dark brown with a medium tan head.  Aroma is raisin, treacle and some alcohol warmth.  Raisin and alcohol warmth to start.  Molasses in the finish.  Very thin for its 8%.

This ale poured a dark orange colour with a quick living, brown colour, creamy head. to the nose there are scents of ripe fruit, rasins, rum, alcohol, butter and coffee. First sip was smooth and rich with a thick mouthfeel. Flavours of ripe fruit, candy, spices and nuts??? most prodominent. Finish is full and flavourful with buttered raisin flavour lasting. This one was one of the most complex beers ive ever rated. So many flavours and scents... blew my mind.
UPDATED: NOV 21, 2016 Fantastic stuff. Went down way too easily for its strength. Thinner than I would have thought. Spices. A hint of the kind of sour in lambics. Serving: Bottle

Pour is cola brown, lively carbonation with bubbles forming on the side. Smell is yeast, alcohol, dried fruit, licorice. Taste is...wow, quite a bit different. The caramel malt taste reminds me a Scotch Ale. Med. body, carb not too excitable on taste. Good sweetness. Get a little alcohol on the finish. Am not getting a whole lot of spices in there, especially missing is any trace of coriander, Ill try a few more.

LCBO special import. Pours a dark brown colour with a nice foamy-cream beige head that stays a while, but has limited lace. Beautiful nose, not too strong though, with raisins, plum, chocolate malt and notes of vanilla and spices. Hints of cherry and oak also come out a bit later. Average mouthfeel with absolutely no burn. Is this really over 4% ABV ??? Wow... what a taste too ! Again, really smooth and not too strong, but so delicious. Raisins and plum, with a nice smooth butterscotch finish and a touch of nuts in the aftertaste. I really, really enjoyed this beer, as it is very well-brewed and balanced. Would love to have more of these in my cellar.

Great beer winter beer. Aroma of dark fruits, raisins, prunes, nuts, and caramel. Pours dark brown very little head. Taste of sweet dark fruits, caramel, nuts, brown sugar and little hint of the high abv. Overall a great winter warm up beer with a very well hidden alcohol.
23rd December 2007  DArk brown beer. Sweet with a subtle floral and fruit undertone. Dry sweet finish. Unusual - nice.
Pours a dark brown with a small off white head.  Aroma is raisins, malt and grain.  Taste has great complexity.  Prunes, raisins, malts and a bit boozy and sweetness.  Nice beer.

Dark brown pour with a frothy off white head. Big bready malt aroma. Sweet bread, brown sugar, and dark ripe fruit. Impressive flavor of sweet ripe dark fruits. Figs, apples, bready brown sugar and some light yeast, even some pudding. Incredibly satusfying, excellent beer.

Bottle. LCBO. Fantastic brew. I bought it on a whim and was blown away.  Pours dark reddish brown with a thin beige head.  Ripe dark fruits with peaches and a hint of cherry. A not of sweet dark nut in the aroma and in the mouth rounded with malts and raisin. Low carbonation, rich and complex. A fantastic brew.

UPDATED: JAN 6, 2011 (bottle) pours a clear dark ruby-brown colour with a small off-white head. aroma of chocolate covered raisins, toasted oats, dark fruit, bread and toffee. flavour is the same, quite chocolaty and fruity, almost vinuous, with a bready malt backbone. quite sweet, with a medium to heavy body and smooth carbonation.

330ml bottle sample. Pours a dark almost ruby brown, with next to no head, no lacing. Aroma is of caramel, molasses and nut. Tastes the same as the aroma caramel, molasses and nut, very smooth. I enjoyed this brew but it wouldnt be my regular.
Bottle from in-law for Christmas, drunk at Craigs house (mostly by Craig). Extremely dark brown. A light head. Heavy taste.

330ml bottle.From the Lcbo Pours a dark  brown with a small tan head.
The aroma is rich fruity and full Bodied really nice
The taste is not as full bodied as would be expected but still really really good

330ml bottle.  Pours a dark reddish brown with a thin tan head.  Aromas of yeast, peppercorn, fruit cake, rum, faint juniper.  While the aroma isnt mind blowing, theres something very pleasing about it.  Taste is sweet, with noticable alcohol, some earthiness but almost all dried fruit, fruit cake notes.  Some pleasant spicy heat in the finish.  A perfect beer for the cold weather.

Bottle. Dark brown appearence. Fruity aroma and a slight carbonation. Refreshing sweet ccoriander taste. Also tasted traces of what seemed like whiskey.  Would have preferred to have had this beer in the summer, rather than the winter. Very drinkable which I find surprising considering its high alcohol content.
330ml bottle from the LCBO.  Dark pour, with a white head.  Aroma of dried fruit reminds me of a dubbel.  So does the flavour; sweetness and fruit.  Nice, but not outstanding.
This beer was alright, had an aroma of fruits, not quite able to pick out which kind. I would prob would have this again
Pours small fizzy head. Very carbonated. Almost like a pop. I have another bottle so I am going to try again.
nice roasty aroma. kind of subtly flavoured but the finish was quite nice, the bitterness was just right

330mL bottle from the Lhyikboh. Pours a clear dark brownish red with a tiny, only semi-existent beige head. The aroma is interesting, pleasing dark fruits (plum, red grape, etc.), mild booze, crystallized brown sugar, plum sauce, no spice to be honest. Flavour has all the same elements blended quite well together, with an odd flavour in the finish which I guess could be the advertised corriander, though it seems like a stretch to call it that. Beet sugar? Very mild carbonation, slick and slightly oily feel on the palate. Pretty tasty, booze is not very evident at all. Nice contribtuion to the LCBO seasonal line-up, though I doubt Ill go after this one again.

Bottle. Pours deep dark brown, opaque; cola like tinge with a decent head fading away to a minimum retention. Floral aroma, dark malt sweetness - all light notes, not too overpowering with a touch of nut and bread. Medium body, medium carbonation - subtle complexities in the way of spice, malt sweetness, roast - some hop flavour, yeast and a finish which runs sweet and chewy until a toasty dryness on the edge of the palate.

Looks like a cola - little head or carbonation and a dark brown. Hate to say it, but I caught a faint whiff of urine. Luckily, no urine flavour, but a bitterness that became an unpleasant sour bite. Fortunately, it didnt linger, but I have no idea what the fuss is with this beer. I bought a few, so Ill be trying it again, but this one gets a "feh!"

Pours a deep (not dark) reddish brown with thinnish light brown head that lingers.  I get raisin, honey, molasses, toast, coriander.  It gets better with every sip.  This might be my first 5 for palate - it has a spectacular smooth mouthfeel and rich finish full of molasses and spice.  Warming alcohol underlies it from start to finish but the taste is completely hidden.  Very comtemplative.

33 cL bottle from the LCBO, served in a snifter. Pours clear mahogany with a small tan head. The head fades quickly to a thin remnant, leaving a small amount of lace on the glass. The nose has complex notes of candied fruit, figs, raisins, molasses, sherry and a hint of spice. The flavour is moderately sweet throughout, with molasses, complex fruity and vinous notes and some spice. A delicate hop accent rounds out the whole package. The finish is moderate in length and mostly clean but with a hint of spice. On the palate, it is medium in body with a smooth, watery texture and minimal carbonation. Overall, this is an excellent fruity dark ale reminiscent of a Belgian ale. It is subtle, complex and very agreeable. Worth another try. 2010-12-11

330 mL bottle.  Dark cola-brown with a little beige head.  The aroma is interesting and appealing with molasses, dark fruit (plums), dried fruit (figs), and possibly some cola.  The flavour is highlighted by brown spice (nutmeg?) that lingers through the finish, dark and dried fruit (plums, dates), and a sweetness that I cant quite place.  Alcohol is completely hidden.  Good body and appropriate carbonation.

Dark brown pour light off white head ... dark fruity aroma and caramel malt ..... taste of molasses, dark fruits(raisins, plums, figs), lightly spiced coriander and caramel malt ........ ends with a sweet and caramel malty finish ... abv hidden well lots of flavor well done

UPDATED: JUL 9, 2013 Bottle, 11C. Deep reddish brown with a small light tan head that laces well. Aroma of stewed and dried fruits - prunes, rhubarb, figs, dates- pudding spices - coriander, preserved ginger, angelica, mace - and toffee. Luscious and fruity with creamy toffee and toast. No real overt bitterness, but the finish is lightened as well as spiced. Spices and alcohol become more prominent down the glass as it warms. 330ml is a pretty big bottle of this, but its puzzling just how the sweetness can be there and so heavy but get lifted away at the end of each sip. [4] Very dark red brown. Head fades to a coat, then is at the rim. Complex fruity aroma as above, maybe some carob too. Sweet with bitterness that gradually creeps up, spices playing quite unfamiliar roles. Remarkable but a bit wearing - lots going on in very gracious style, but no sense of fun. About the 4th time had thinking Id _really_ like it this time.

It pours a mahogany with ruby highlights and a finger of quickly lowing, off white head.  The nose is of roasted malts and fruity yeast - almost a Belgian aroma on this.  I can pick up ginger and cinnamon, a light nuttiness and loads of uniformed dark fruits.  In the mouth the flavours echo the nose, with the malts carrying a subtle Madeira note; grapes and raisins seem to dominate the fruits.  The mouth feel is medium and very smooth, very smooth indeed - the alcohol is nowhere to be found.  The finish is short and malty with a light tart end coming from the yeast.  Its very true to its style and very enjoyable to drink, but nothing exceptional.

Anticipation was killing me to try this beer. I have been eye-fondling it in my local liquor store for many weeks. Poors thick into the glass. A tight tan head. Aroma was disappointing ... smelled musty. Rich malty chocolate tones with powerful anise base. Coriander flavor is barely perceptible. Nice overall spiciness from hops. This is a great overall brew, but one of the rare times that I have been in disagreement with ratebeerians

Poured a murky brown/purple color with a thin off-white head.  Great aroma of honey and scotch with some cloves and spices.  Taste is very interesting.  Honey at first with caramel malts and coriander.  Transitions into a smooth and slightly creamy finish with some hops and more caramel. Some plumb taste as well in the finish.   Not too sweet or syrupy, but definitely on the sweet side.  Overall quite good!

12oz bottle from BC Liquor (old rate). Dark amber colour, fruity plumb/prune aroma, with small head that disappears quickly. Had a very nice plumb raisin flavour balanced nicely with coriander. Begins with sweetness and ends in a spicy bitterness. Delightfully warming and complex.
Bottle. Pours dark brown, with thick head, good lacing.  Aroma sweet maltiness, with some caramel.  Flavor is malty sugariness with some heat.  Some dry hoppiness to balance. Texture is sticky.

Deep red pour, short-lived off-white head.  Aroma reminds me of being in a very old library, deliciously dusty/leathery/earthy.  Taste very complex, vinous, intense, smooth.  Provokes thoughtful contemplation.  Really.

(330ml bottle) Pours like a bottle of Coke, with a small ring of white bubbles around the glass, and lots of bubbles coating the bowl. Winey aroma, laced with light coriander. Thick body. Flavors of bubble gum and light sweetness of plum. Not much in the way of hop character. Interesting to try, but not my type of beer.

Bottle. Pour is brown black and has some red hues when held to light, head is creamy quick, which leaves a ring around glass. Aroma sweet with some spice as well, kind of caramel and malt scents. Taste is licorice and malt which comes off creamy and smooth. Palate is sticky and chaulky.
Rather dark. Roasted malts. Some fruits. Coriander gives it a nice twist. Pleasant smell.

Aroma is dark fruits and roasty malts. Smells sweet.. Appearance is dark brown with red tint. Small head that disapates quickly, leaving a ring around the glass. Taste is dark fruits and mild roasty malts. Tangy and spicy. Licorice, peat, and leather. Palate is medium and crisp for such a high alcohol beer. Licorice and peat really linger on the tongue. Slight alcohol heat lingers as well. Overall a nice and unique beer. Reminds me of a roasty strong scottish ale.
Pours dark brown with a one finger head. Disappates rather quickly. Aroma is roasted malts, dark fruits, and spices. Flavor is rich, dark, and delicious! Even better as it warms. Quite a treat.

Pours a dark brown, far darker than Id expected. Aroma is full of roasty malt character, with hints of toast and maybe plum or raisin. Flavor is deep, robust and complex but not at all overwhelming to the palate. Fantastic balance of warm malts with dark fruit flavors. Mouthfeel is unbelievable as well. Possibly the smoothest beer Ive ever tasted. Fantastic.

Bottle. Nose is incredibly rich, almost wine-like in its complexity -- dark fruit, wood, spice. Pours a cloudy brown with a fine grained head. The flavor is unlike anything Ive ever had before -- it has the dark roasted nature of a porter or dark ale, but the coriander adds a spicy, broad note. Under all that, theres also fruity and almost sweet notes, as well as a boozy bite. The finish lingers with a whisky-like peated edge. This is less a beer and more an experience; I couldnt drink more than one of these, but Im glad Ive tried it.
Pretty dark with a beige head. Excellent mouthfeel with a filling full body. sweet liquoricenice touch of coriander. Strong. some coffee and roasted nuts. love it.

Deep ruby-brown pour with no head and no lace. Smooth, dark-roasted malt flavors of dates, subtle spices and ripe cherries. Hops are present throughout, adding a resinous bitterness. Nicely balanced, medium-heavy body, lightly carbonated. A delicious, sessionable beer with a well-hidden ABV.

A: snifter. Pours an deep obsidian-brown color with a slightly off-white head. Low head retention level and very light lacing.

S: tons of coriander in the nose, more than any beer I have smelled. Sweet, rich sticky malts, with some really strong sweet citrus tones.

T: tastes just like it smells. Tons of coriander are all over this, with some sweet, roasted malts with a lot of sweet citrus flavors. Very interesting palate.

M: very mellow compared to the color. Light to medium body. Lower carbonation than expected.

D: very drinkable if you like coriander. The taste threw me off after looking at a dark, thick looking beer. Makes me think that this is what beers in the 15th century tasted like. Well worth a try and glad that mhewes traded with me for it.

330 ml bottle. Rated @ 21.3.2009.
Pours a dark brown colour with a frothy white head. Pleasant aroma of spices, herbs and wood. Flavour of toasted malt, spices, wood and caramel. Coffee notes too. Medium bodied with a lingering malty/spicy finish. Very nice.

Bottle. Pours a coke black with a slight head. Malty nose with some spice, aroma is very weak. Taste is rich, caramel malts with a slight licorice taste. Mouthfeel is lingering, leaving an aftertaste of spiced molasses.

Bottle. Heavy malt aromas of dark bread, nutty and milk chocolate, moderate hop and yeast notes of herbs and dough with background notes of toffee, postum and dark dried fruit. Head is small, fizzy, very light brown with no lacing and is fully diminishing. Color is clear dark brown with a red tint. Flavor starts moderately sweet and the short finish is lightly bittersweet and acidic. Palate is medium, oily with a soft carbonation and a lightly dry finish. This Traditional Ale smells absolutely awesome, with deep rich malt notes and a great balance from the hops and yeast, though I couldnt find any coriander. The only negative I could say is that the flavor falls a little short of the aroma.

Bottle. Pours clear, nearly black, dark ruby red with a dense tan head that dissappears rather quickly. Taste is lightly bitter, medium sweet. Palate is velvety, soft, thick and full-bodied. Aroma is complex, it has spices, malts, licorice, chocolates and raisins.

Mahogany colour with an all together quality creamy white head and lace. Rich malt, winter berry, subtle yeast and liquorice aroma. Rich flavour, roasted malt, chocolate, berry spicy flavour. This beer is completely delicious. Great texture. Reminds me of Christmas, great stuff.

11.2 oz bottle, best before 6/2017.  Pours a murky brown with a smallish white head that quickly dissipates to a thin collar.

The aroma is sweet malts, molasses, floral spices and dark fruits and chocolate and a little smoke.

The flavor is sweet malts, cola, dark figgy fruits and chocolate with a slight bitter spicey finish.  The mouthfeel is medium bodied with low carbonation and very watery.

Overall, an interesting and complex beer.  It really needs to warm up some to shine.

330 ml bottle from Premier Wine & Spirits (Halifax).  Pours a deep ruby-brown with small beige head.  Nice aroma of raisin/plum, caramel, light spicing.  Flavour is dark fruit, caramel, chocolate, light spices and a light roastiness.  Unique and quite good.
Sweet floral aroma with malt. Dark brown colour with poor head and lacing. Sweet malt candy floral flavour. Fizzy palate.
Bottle. Pours a clear brown beer with a weak offwhite head. The aroma is malt, caramel, fruit and flowers. The flavor follows the nose closely. The palate is sweetness. Overall an average beer.

Nice near opaque pour with a small light brown head. Aroma has a fair amount of caramel and dark berries, ripe fruits, hints of chocolate, and a bit of an oak quality as well. A doughy yeast component, too. Taste has a nice amount of dark fruitiness, hints of chocolate and a slight coffee bitterness, a little liquorice, a burnt nut taste in the finish as well as a malty bitterness. Really great beer, very malty complexity in this one.

Bottle, courtesy of Enjoyit. Very deep ruby brown colour with a minuscule collar of beige head. Very beautiful. Intriguing aroma with some strong, crystaline caramel, quite sweet and soft, followed by a rich and warm wine-like structure, coupled with corriander, wet malt, brown sugar and lovely and adequate hop-profile. Some herbs as well. Taste is moderately sweet with a nice, big malt-base, followed by a thick, warm, viscous wine-like sensation with even more sweetness. Bittersweet in the finish with fruits, berries, spices, herbs and some hops. Big body, low carbonation, long duration. Very nice!
Colour is brown with a creamy top. Aroma is roasted malt and fruity note. Flavour is roasted malt and  alcohol
UPDATED: SEP 30, 2010 Quite sweet, tastes of dried fruit and sweet licorice. A perfect beer to end the night with.

330ml bottle. Pours a very deep amber with minimal tan head that leaves a lasting lace. Smells like a spicy pig pen...in a good way with some nice smoky, roasted notes and a faint hint of sugar buried way in the back. The same flavours come out on the palate in a slightly different mix with a nice spicy, almost-bitter finish.

Pours dark Brown clear small sh liv tanned Head. Roasted malts, chocolate, coffe aroma. Full bodied sweet malty flavor with notes of sweet fruits and toffe. Alcohol and malts on palate. Finishes with lean sweet malty aftertaste.

Pours a deep dark brown with little to no head. Smells of toffee, chocolate and roasted malt. Tastes flat with a toffee/coffee/chocolate taste and a light bodied mouthfeel. Kind of boozy but not overbearing. Not a big aftertaste, if anything it has a little toffee aftertaste. Not a bad beer, but not something that I would pay for again.

11.2 oz bottle from EZ Liquors. Poured a muddy dark brown with an average sized dense beige head. Aroma is perfumey with notes of corriander, lavender, chocolate, wet malts, peat, wet wood and yet as complex as this one is its delicate and balanced. Medium bodied with soft carbonation and a slight alcohol warming on the end. The flavor is reminiscent of the aroma and although it is complex with mulitple different flavors detected its still delicate and balanced. Flavors of yeast, dark fruits, wood, grass, earth, lavender and corriander. This is a great sipper but sadly Im in a pounding mood so this one is going down far to quick.
Pours brown with a beige head. Aroma is roasted malt and dark fruit. Flavour is roasted malt, alcohol and dark fruit.

Bottle at Bishop Arms Karlstad. Aroma is vanilla, wood and sweet licorice. Looks beautiful, dark brown hazy liqiud with brown foam. Taste is brilliant balanced but sweet licorice dominates the aftertaste. Spices butterscotch, vanilla, raisin is also in there. Overall, good stuff.

Bottle at home. Pours out dark brown, with a hint of red. Looks very dark brown at the glass. Small of-white head, could have been some more... A bit of a weird smell. Not bad at all, but not a beersmell I expected, seems even some milk-smell inside. Also spices and coffee, toffee, caramel. Not bad, some sourness inside also. Lighter bodied then expected, way more easy drinkable then expected. Taste of toffee, some spices and coffee, and again that weird milk-thing comming up. Also red fruits. Good beer for sure, could use some body maybe.
Bottle from Cavie and drowland.  Dark brown pour with a white head.  Aroma is alcohol, alcohol, grapes, cinnamon, and bread.  Taste is dark fruit, alcohol, and spice.

Bottle courtesy of drowland.  Very murky brown color with light white bubbles. Spicy aroma, alcohol and clay. Smells pretty strong. Taste is fairly smooth for the ABV, but also has some flavors of smoked beef, clay and peat moss.  Interesting.

Fine nose with tones of caramel, cinnamon, milk chocolate and sweet yoghurt after a little time in the glass; It has a medium body (I expected more), with a bitter sweetness to it. It lacks a hole lot of depth and complexity to be a really good beer; The finish is medium in body, not very long and too bitter.

33cl bottle. Pours an opaque dark brown color with a medium beige head. Good lacing and mostly lasting foam. Aroma is warm and sweet with a strong malty and yeasty presence. Caramel, toffee and coffe notes. Taste is similar, with a strong presence of sweet flavors: brown sugar, caramel, dark fruits, licorice. Palate is full with little carbonation. Overall, a good warming beer. Good complexity for the ABV.


caramel dark fruits brown sugar

Pours a dark brownish color with a slight white head which fizzes away quickly. Nose is nutty, caramel, raisins and some roasts. Flavor is sweet, slight dark fruits flavors and get bit of the corainder on the finish.

Brune et trouble, sa mousse est éphémère. En arômes, on perçoit des notes de fruits des champs et de malt. Très douce et sucrée, elle reste raffraichissante et offre des saveurs de baies, de malt, de caramel et tout ça avec une belle douceur chocolatée. Bière complexe et délicieuse.

330ml bottle from Whole Foods Los Altos.  Pours a very dark brown color with reddish tints and just a little foam after an aggressive pour.  Aroma is excellent - sweet caramel and toffee, pumpernickel bread, candied dark fruits, rum cake, and spice.  The flavor is sweet - but at a good level - and well-spiced.  Coriander and other spices, along with caramel and toffee, mild toastiness, candied date, sugarplum, and raisin.  Not much bitterness at all.  Medium-full bodied and exceptionally smooth on the palate.  A very impressive beer overall.  Easy to drink at 8% ABV.

Smells very light and sweet, like baking in the air on a warm sunny day in spring before the air is full of dust and pollen. A bit bready. Almost no head or lacing, murky looking, fairly brown. Initially sweet, it isnt too sweet and it gradually fades out into the richness of the malts. Theyre not heavy or strong or anything, but you really get thier flavour here. Very nice finishing touch, the flavour and end feeling in the mouth make this seem like a diet trappist brew. The flaovur in the mouth is quite similar. A bit too flat overall, but quite nice, I would get this one agian, just one at a time though.
Bottle: Poured a dark brown to black with little to no head, bubbles formed. Aroma is roasted nuts. Taste is roasted malt and leafy spices.

Bottle thanks to douglas88. wise choice.  This bottle has been in the fridge for 6 months mostly because the label is so cool.  Pours darker than I expected with very little head, but it has alot of carbonation, nice little bubbles. Smells great, plums and spice. tastes better, mild and fruity taste might have alot to do with the aroma but the sweetness could be due to fairly high alcohol content. Everything in this ale balances out well, never had anything like this.  Buy a case.

Pours dark brown with a bubbly small tan head that leaves a ring. Aroma of rum soaked fruit, coffee, very toasty malts, light butter, sweet fruit, mild floral hop, nut, molasses. Taste has more of the coriander noticeable and it is certainly not overdone like most spiced beers. This beer is very smooth and tasty, mostly sweet with just a hint of coffee bitterness on the finish. Medium slick body, soft carbonation.

Bottle from VBM. Pours a dark brown body with a reddish tint and big short lived light tan head. Aroma is nice caramel, light spice, booze and sweet malts. Flavor is a nice balance of sweet and bitter with some roasted notes. Flat carbonation, medium bodied. Not too bad, but Im a bit disappointed by this.
Bottle at Birroteca Tana di Luppolo.  Dark brown, 3 bubble head, no lacing.  Aroma of cocoa and coffee beans.  Taste starts sweet, then vanilla and milk chocolate.  Light body.  Nice.

dark brown, mild white head.  spicy nose.  low carbonation.  mild bitterness before some sweet and spicy spiced notes before some low crystal and toasty malt flavors with a bit of peat smoke perhaps.  little residual sweetness and only complexity added by the alcohol.  interesting brew, solid

Dark mahogany brew with a small eggshell head.  Flavor and aroma show dark fruit, biscuit, roasted malt, and brown sugar.  Lots of wine notes here.  Caramel and toffee as well.  A little thin but the alcohol is masked well.  Not bad.

Bottle at Göteborg beer festival, 2010-04-25 Göteborg
dark, fruity, prunes, chocolate, wine - great!

11.2 oz. bottle- Pours almost black with very little head, aroma is spicy cilantro and cherries. The flavor is very mellow and drinkable with a subtle spice and low in carbonation. There is also some raisin flavors,  I have to admit I was hoping for better with this beer, the carbonation is my biggest complaint. The flavor is undeniably smooth and complex though, glad I drank it but will never buy again.

Bottle. Pour was medium brown copper with a nice aroma of coriander and light lemon peel. Flavors were slightly spicy with a little more coriander, light toast, and some malt background. Pretty good brew with a nice balance, but Ill have to research the style more and re-rate at a later time.
Brown pour. Medium head. Earthy-Corriander, slight fruity (cherries, dark plum). Light sour. Very fantastic balance of flavors. Highly recommend to drink again.

12 oz. bottle from Belmont Party Supply.  Not sure of the vintage, but it says "Best before June 2017."  Poured into a snifter, this one is a hazy deep brown color with a tiny beige head that dissipates quickly into a small ring inside the glass.  Aroma of spices, banana, rye, brown sugar, caramel malts, coriander, and butterscotch.  Flavor is similarly complex, with notes opening up more as it warms: spices, rye mostly, caramel malts, coriander, molasses, butterscotch, wood, earthy hops, and dark fruits.  Medium-bodied, with slightly below average carbonation and a slick mouthfeel.  Finishes sweet, but not too much.  Complex, balanced, and really nice.  Cool beer that you can drink now or in a decade and enjoy in different ways.

Bottle via trade with Probstk. Dark brown pour with very thin white head pretty inert. Aroma is cherry, vanilla, wood and toffee. I also get a hint of pear. Taste is nice and sweet, super discreet alcohol, well balanced with a creamy rounded palate. Very nice beer.

Shared this one w/ SkyCop32. Picked up at Maruhn Getränke in Darmstadt. Pours a dark ruby brown color. Aromas of orange/citrus and peaches?. Flavors of spices, coriander, ginger. Tart and tangy finish, a weird but very interesting beer.

Had this a couple times when first started drinking, but never rated before now. Pours dark brown. Medium sized creamy khaki head. Big spiced 
aroma. This is a great tasting beer. Not easy to describe. Spiced; dark, 
malty, ginger-bread-y cookie flavors. Carbonation on the low-medium end.

Jacobite is a dark ruby/brown beer with think light brown head. Low carbonation. Aroma:  cherry dominant, with a nice roasted malt presence. Chocolate, wine, dry candy fruits (plums),  spicy.  Taste: very complex, malty, strong sweetness, a medium bitterness. A really interesting communion between belgians and uk beer experience. Great.

Bottle.
A - Black cola color with a slightly below average sized head that is creamy and light beige. Good retention and a nice lacing left.

S - Lots of spices and some citrus. Also a good dark sugar/molasses smell. Dark, spicy, and alcohol.

T - Pretty sweet base with some dark malts, brown sugar, molasses, dark fruits, and barley. There is also a lot of spice, in particular coriander, as well as some peat and a bit of alcohol.

M - A little above medium body with a little below average carbonation. Smooth, a little sticky, and a touch of a drying finish.

D - Complex flavors, but they dont kill the palate. Sweet and spiced. Smooth and goes down easy too.

Notes: A nice solid beer that definitely has some Scotch flavors. Has sweetness but not cloying or overpowering, same goes for the spiced flavors.

33cl bottle.   Brown with a small beige head.   The aroma is a dark crusty mix of bread, coriander and dried fruit.   The flavor has caramel, lightly smokey bread, and a spicy finish with barely any hops to be found.   The body is actually a little thin if anything, and this drinks really easily for a stronger beer.   The aroma is somewhat seductive actually, but it doesnt translate quite as well in the flavor and mouthfeel.

Poured a dark brown body with a minimal amount of a cream colored head. Smell of heavy malt is prevelant with notes of hops, brown sugar, and dark fruits. The mouthfeel is thick and syrupy but not too cloying. The taste is of raisins and a bit of hops on the backend. I really like this beer but not the best Ive ever had.

12oz bottle 
Appearance: Pours dark brown with a medium sized tan head that dissipates quickly, no lacing left in the glass 
Aroma: Belgian candy, dark fruits 
Taste: Sweet malts, candy and grainy mouthfeel 
Finished with a faint medicinal taste. There eems to be alot going on with this beer. I just couldnt pinpoint what it was all about!

12oz bottle.  Deep red with a thin head.  Smells like sweet fruit, raisins, cherries, with some alcohol and chocolate.  Taste starts sweet, with vanilla some licorice, fading into a bitter herbal finish with a touch of raisins.

Bottle conditioned, 330ml from Abbey Stores, Salisbury. Dark brown, chestnut with white head. Lots of rich maly notes with a dark mollasses charcter, fruity, strawberries, with background spices. Very pleasant and drinkable. Really pretty good.

Dark mahogany with a slightly roasted appearance and a fine deeply tanned head. Rich, viscous malt nose, deeply wound aromas that slowly unfurl into mysterious, but subdued dark fruits and syrups and touches of crystalized candi malt sweetness. Lovely, viscous body with dark fruit syrup flavors punctuated by coriander, which is well positioned within the brews flavor spectrum as other tastes seems to radiate and undulate back to that spice. Touches of mineral and wine pepper on the finish.
330mL bottle, pours dark brown with a tan head. Aroma of roasted malts, nuts and coriander. Flavour of dark malts and coriander, with a smooth finish. Good.

Refrigerated bottle poured into a glass.  Pours a dark brown with medium brown highlights, a little head that disappears quickly, and the aroma is dominated by coriander.  Taste is dark malt and spicy coriander.  Too much coriander for me, not really complex, this beer is just ok for me, mostly overrated.

Enjoyed from a 12oz bottle in a whiskey snifter.  The beer pours a deep brown color, with a small off-white head.  The nose gives hints of chocolate and toffee with a touch of alcohol; somewhat resembling an aged English barley wine.  The palate is full and somewhat (but not overly) sweet and malty.  Again, it shows a moderate amount of chocolate and a more subtle note of toffee, along with a floral note.  Subtle fruity esters and a depth-adding bit of alcohol shake hands with the palate toward the finish.  As with the nose, the mouthfeel and flavors seem to resemble a lighter English barley wine.  Overall, an enjoyable winter warmer.

Bottle.  Mahogany body, much sediment, a thin and partial ring of head without lace.  Aroma has a lot of banana accompanied by dark fruits, spiced honey, faint caramel notes, licorice, milk chocolate, and a bit of coriander.  Mouth is medium and almost flat, lightly dry.  Flavor is lightly sweet with dried, dark fruits, milk chocolate, coriander, roasted malt, vanilla, licorice spice tea.  Pretty unique, complex, and gourmet.  The carbonation is pretty bad, but otherwise I really like it.  Could use some more body because it would carry the flavor longer.  The finish thins out, leaving you with rather unflavorful (woody) hops and coriander in the mouth.

Bottle.  Dark brown pour, little carbonation and had a rich aroma simlar to a good fruity port.  Flavor is very sweet brown sugar, sweet black cherry, tea/spices and then finished syrupy.  Started decent enough, but finish was kind of a mess.  Worth a try, but I probably would spend my money elsewhere next time.
Nice traditional ale.  Bottled sample from MLCC.  Was surprised that this was 8%.  Who is Lubiere anyway?

Pours brown with little head, but it hangs around. Medium lacing on the glass. Aroma of coriander, but sweet. Smells of black licorice and hints of chocolate as well. Taste starts subtle and then explodes on the tounge. Dark chocolate, black licorice and alcohol with subtle coriander notes. Pretty good beer

Wow this is blisteringly good. Ideal compliment for the Scottish cold snap. MMM. Get a load of that aroma. Poured from bottle into a round Beermerchants glass. Perfect appearence. Smell is so similar to Rochefort its spooky. Taste is prominently brown sugar, caramel and figgs with raisens too. Wow. Can not beleive how good this is. 

Excellent mouth feel. Malt is very Belgian style. Could be a little more complex and a little more abv but dont let that deter you. Wondferful beverage. I am stonked. Lets get steaming! Lets get wasted! Bring out the haggis.

Appearance: 330ml bottle. Pours dark brown color with ruby highlight. Tiny, creamy, tan head.
Aroma: Wonderfully complex fruity esters, spicies like anise, coriander. Reminescent of Rochefort 10 in the blueberry/dark cherry character. A bit of rum or sherry(?)-like alcoholic notes.
Flavor: Mellow darker malty, sugary sweetnes, Cocoa beans, anise, molasses, dried-fruity fullnes up-front. Sweet vanilla and caramel at the mid palate. Ends in a bit bland english hop(?) spiciness.
Mouthfeel/Palate: Medium body, not heavy or full at all. Smooth texture, soft carbonation with creamy mouthfeel and excellent drinkability, zero harm of alcohol. Short spicy-fruity finish.
Overall: Interesting Scottish ale with rich malty sweetness, lovely spicy character, amazing smooth body. Almost like a Strong Belgian Dark. My only problem is the overwhelmed, almost non-existing hop profile.
Remarkable stuff!

This one just misses the mark completely for me.  Funky vegetable vinegar strange aromas with alcohol coming through pretty potent.   Flavor  is mostly the same with a heavy dose of sweetness on top.  Just strange with a hint of no thanks.

11.2oz bottle. Pours deep brown, topped with a medium sized tan head. Enticing aroma, with chocolate and blueberry at the forefront, which make for an interesting combo. Spice and a little peat round out the aroma. Blueberry, peat, and milk chocolate hit the palate first. Spice joins in gradually and hangs out for a long finish. Minimal carbonation. Body is a lot thinner than expected. Tasty, but lacks body.

Bottle from my local. Intensely dark brew with ruby highlights and a little creamy tan head. Not getting much coriander in the nose, only whiffs of candy sweetness, molasses maybe? Also has a bit of a roasty quality. Flavor is bitter sweet, spiced molasses and chocolate malt. Some dark fruits emerge toward the finish and I am able to grasp a bit of coriander as it warms. Very unique and flavorful brew...Slainte. Heres tae ye!

Served from a 12 oz bottle from OTM. The appearance is a deep chestnut brown with a micro white head. The aromas are light acetone, and berries. Flavors are quite nice. A mild sweetness to the malts, raspberry, raisin, 
The mouth is fairly drying.  A really nice beer that Im glad I picked up after Ive passed it by all this time.

Almost black, reddish beer with a small, with a small head; stunning aroma of liquorice, dark berries, vanilla - almost like an blueberrypie in a bottle; medium body, mouthfeel is slick and velvety smooth; flavor of liquorice, vanilla and dry fruitness. Elegant.

Pours a deep tobacco brown with little to no head into a pint glass.  Aroma of sweet malts, toffee, licorice, coriander, raisins.  Taste begins with licorice, malt pulls through, finishes dry with a touch of coriander.  Slightly boozy, med-full body with medium carbonation.  Odd but pleasant sticky chewy mouthfeel.  Really odd brew but most definitely a tasty one.

Pours such a dark brown that youd confuse it for being black. light tan head when poured, but once the beer is in the glass. The aroma is of plums and licorice. This is a flat beer that is medicine-like taste that I was not impressed with.

UPDATED: NOV 5, 2010 Wow one of the BEST beers Ive enjoyed, one worth revisiting. Nose mineral and faint dark berry, taste full fruit and sweet pinot & muscat grape. Dark blueberry, liquorice, long deep fruity-malty finisn showing honey and crushed petals of violet. Magnificent.

"Ye Jacobites by name, yer faults I will proclaim," goes the auld Scots song but Im damned if I can find any flaws to proclaim. This is an elegant sipping ale, sweet, sticky, lightly spiced and very moreish for its strength. In the glass, its as black as the Butcher Cumberlands heart and keeps its head better than my clan chief, who lost his at the hands of the Hanoverians after the last Jacobite rebellion ended in bloody defeat at Culloden - beheaded in London. The aroma is subtle and enticing - clove, blackcurrants, chocolate pudding and yeast. Perfect mouthfeel - soft and creamy. Incredibly easy-drinking for an 8% ale. Theres not a hint of alcohol in a beautifully balance flavour mix. Tiramisu, soft chocolate, yum. A true regional classic and probably the best Scottish beer Ive had to date. (33cl bottle from Platinum Liquor)

UPDATED: DEC 12, 2009 (br-btl bk-lbl, "ale flavored with coriander", Innerleithen in Peebleshire, 8%)
lct-br, no-head, full-body, §co2, 

aroma: earthy fresh-coriander whisky

taste:
T1 sweet-malt §coriander 
T2 sweet-§minty-^coriander §irish-cream 
T3 §sweet-coriander 
^drinkable, might make a great marinade or soup base.

Bottle. Pours a mahogany body with some light ruby accents, with a tan head.  Dark fruity esters, abundant fresh chewy plums, raisins, dark vinous notes, port and some light licorice tones.  Chewy chocolate notes with some light peat y tones amongst the caramel plum y malt bill.  Awesome Ale.

Sötét vöröses barna színe van a habja pedig sárgás fehér,vékony és gyorsan eltűnik.Illata erősen korianderes és dió likőrös.Íze igen fűszeres,bors,koriander,fenyőgyanta és tealevél is érződik benne.Karamellásan édeskés és egy kis füge is érződik.Nagyon összetett és rafinált!Az alkohol tartalma csiklandozza a nyelvet,szép kerek teste van.Utóíze finoman és komlósan kesernyés és gyógyfüves,hosszan tart.Nagyon különleges és finom sör.Magas alkohol tartalma és fűszerezettsége miatt akár emésztés segítőnek is kitűnően megfelel.

Pours a very dark red-brown with an oddly light-colored and quickly fading head.  Strong aroma of sweet malt, raspberry, raisin, clove, licorice.  Taste is sweet malt to start progressing to mildly tart fruit and drying out into a long herbal spicy finish.  Medium body and lively carbonation.  Quite different.  Not nearly as strongly flavored as I expected.  It actually tastes a bit watered down.  Could be an off bottle.

[330ml bottle from Westholme Stores, Goring] Nice looking beer - a deep ruby-brown, although with virtually no head.  Its possibly a little too fizzy.  Beyond that - well, its really just sweet and sticky.  Treacle and caramel malts, with some raisins and hints of spice in the finish.  Alcohol shows. Not sure what all the fuss is about this one.
Bottle 33. Amber beer with a strange malt aroma, bit sour at the finish or its the spices??  bitter and roasted. Quite disapointed about it.
33 cl bottle, Fargo, ND, USA via Winnipeg. Deep black, cola-like colour. Sweet plumb aroma with raisin flavor, reminiscent of port. Sweet finish with a faint warming alcohol mellowness. Very nice.

UPDATED: JUL 11, 2010 A - Chocolate, caramel and alcohal
A - Dark amber with little to no head
F - Sweet with a bitter alcohol flavor
P - A bit fizzy for an ale, but full bodied
O - A bit strong...not terrible.

Bottle. Dark reddish brown beer with a small beige head. Strong spicy aroma has licourice and alcohol. Flavor is so rich with a bit sweetness, soft maltyness and quite bittery end. I like the saltyness very much. Body is nice and full. Maybe my favourite beer so far.

12 ounce bottle from Holiday Wine Cellar ($5.99).  Pours a dark brown with beige head.  Aroma of toffee, milk chocolate, brown sugar, spice.  Lovely and delicate flavor of lightly roasted malts, milk chocolate, dark fruits and cherries, brown sugar.  The coriander is there and more pronounced in the finish.  Different, but an excellent brew.

Bottle at home.
Dark brown with a small head. Aroma heavy malty (caramel, dark fruits, wood, spicy), light hoppy. Flavor heavy sweet, light bitter. Almost full body. Fine.

12 oz. bottle - dark brown with faint tan head; figs, spice, sugar and coriander; texture is thin and almost syrupy; coriander is very obvious; almost lovely, but a tad too much on the spice for my liking

Pours a burnt orange with a small ring for a head. Aroma is very odd and very different from any beer Ive ever had. Fuzzy peaches, flowers, molasses, jube-jubes, spices, perfume, and alcohol. Very nice on the nose. Fuzzy peaches, licorice, jube0jubes, apples, cloves, cinnamon, flowers. Decent palate. Very good!

Tried a bottle of this for the first time, tonight. Colour... dark walnut with garnet hues. Nose... spice, molasses, turbinado and treacle sirup. Palate... a quick froth of C02 followed by slightly tangy burnt sugar, dark brown sugar, Christmas cake, sailor jack, dark raisins, golden sirup, and a long finish with hints of coriander! Heres to Bonnie Prince Charlie and the Stewarts, Frasers, Farquharsons, Camerons, Macintoshes and Macdonalds who fought with him on that fateful day at Culloden in 1746!!

Bottle, thanks to hobbersr. Nose is sour patch kids, cough syrup, brown sugar, and spice. Palate is more sour candies, sugar cubes, and the flavor that makes mini-marshmallows taste different from their more conventional brethren, plus brandy, apples, cherry lollipops and sasparilla root. Very unique.

disappointed. didnt get any of the much talked about complexity to savour. A decent but unexceptional brew with treacle, liquorice, cherry and smokiness. Not all that subtle or balanced and not as rich in flavour as expected. Probably one to come back to.

330 mL bottle.  Pours brown with a medium white head.  Great and unique aroma, with the coriander reminding me of red fruits (strawberry and cherry), along with some dark fruits.  Flavor has dark fruits and a bit of coriander along with smoke and a touch of citrus.  Pretty good.

Pours light brown with a thin head.  Very aromatic, tons of red fruit, raspberry, watermelon, red licorice, 5 cent candies (like you got at 7-11 when you were a kid) and cheap perfume.  Tastes of perfume, fresh oak, wood smoke, and again, gummy candy.
Dark brown with a low head. Malty aroma with notes of spice and basement. The flaavour is dominated by liquorice and spices. Port like resemblances.

12oz bottle.  dark deep brown pour with a thin tan head that leaves a ring.  aroma of plums, raisins and brown sugary malts.  taste wasnt what I was expecting for some reason.  slick thin to medium palate makes any strong flavors fly right by.  catch bits of  toffee, yeast and lemon.  finishes up nicely with roasted spices and a yeasty sourness.  left me wanting more - always the ultimate compliment.

Bottle. I tried this a while ago and didnt think much of it but Im glad I decided to give it another go. Pours dark brown with a lasting beige head which leaves plenty of lacing. Aroma is caramel, malt, cinnamon and brown sugar, all of which feature in the flavour as well as a dash of chocolate and other spices. Smooth, creamy mouthfeel with a big body and long finish, this is a really great beer. Recommended.
Not for everyday, but every real beer drinker should definitely try it!  A nice brew with complexities.

Bottle from Lees Discount Liquor.  Brown cloudy color with thick haze.  Nose of apple skin, brown sugar, thick roast, caramel and a light raisin-like quality.  Flavors are much the same with added chocolate.  Very smooth, very thick and relaxing.

330 ml bottle courtesy of ditmier. Thanks Eric. Pours an opaque dark brown color with a small beige head that soon dissipates to a fine ring. The aroma was soft with caramel, mocha, oranges and dust. The flavor has a big coriander presence which takes on different fruit aspects with each sip; I get oranges, chocolate covered cherries and berries. The mouthfeel is silky smooth. The finish is somewhat short and dry. In conclusion a very tasty little ale.
One of the best Ive tasted this year. Very complex flavors but all enjoyable and intense - great smooth mouth feel - finshes with a wonderful panache - truly a great beer
bottle... anything with a best if consumed by 2017 has to be good. and it was dark brown and super yummy... try this one

Realizing that for all I had quaffed of the Traquair House Ale, I had yet to sup on their equally divine Jacobite Ale; ale brewed with hops, malt, yeast, water, and coriander. Simple is best, and I have a feeling that he is going to sweep me off my feet, and my life will never be the same.


Deep browns, blacks, and burnt mahogany settles into my glass underneath a shy khaki head which lingers as a thin layer. No lace yet, but with a couple tender swirls, fragile lace leave their mark on my glass. I raise his liquid nirvana to my nose, and the first and only thing I can think of to say is: Wow! Awesome! Heavenly! I am swept away beyond what words can describe, but I am going to try. Ooey gooey sticky dark fruits: dates, plums, prunes, figs, raisins. Rich Swiss chocolates melt under the warmth of her gaze, drowning sweet black cherries while truffles make sweet love to toffee and caramel nougat. Prune juice, anise, chocolate pudding and pudding bread lead into a dry bitter chocolate finish which is all Hersheys syrup and coffee. Permeating his nose is coriander, cinnamon, and nutmeg. Im not sure what I have done of late to deserve such a perfect presentation of Beervana, but I am not going to count my luck. Judging by his nose, my first sup of Jacobite Ale must come under eyes closed, heightening my sense of smell and taste. As his dark nectar hits my lips, a chill runs from the tip of my toe to the top of my head. Goosebumps tingle and hairs stand on end. Clean and smooth, he is delicately sweet with toffee and caramel chocolate truffles melting in my mouth, sending shivers up and down my spine. I pause before exhaling cinnamon, nutmeg, and coriander. The Hershey syrup adds a touch of roughness to his palate which complements the darker, dryer side of fresh brewed coffee and espresso. His middle is a juicy chewy cornucopia of the moistest dates, prunes, plums, figs, and raisins. Chocolate mousse, pudding bread, and holiday spices marked by coriander continue to fill out his palate. Rich and enveloping, I am drowning in sweet ecstasy. The Jacobite Ale is not cloying in any way, shape, fashion, and form. His palate is rich, but his body and mouthfeel is light, clean, and exquisitely balanced. My lips become coated with dry earthy finish even as prune juice lingers in with a supple kiss. I dont want this moment to end, but all good things must eventually come to an end, I suppose. That hasnt stopped me from stocking my cellar with 6 more bottles, though.


The Traquair House Jacobite Ale is heaven descended, and I pray that Traquair never stops making this beer, or any of their beers for that matter. The big players can go fly a kite, and I hope they get carried away into the atmosphere by a freak storm, never to return. Jacobite has reminded me all over again why Beer is so much more than just a beverage: it is Passion personified.

A bottle 0.33L from Alko. Malty nose. Dark reddish brown colour. Pale beige head. Mild soft taste. Some hints of coffee. Not sweet. Varming alcohol. Spicy taste with some raisin notes. Slightly medicinlike.

Dark brown pour, dense tan head. Nose is vinous. Flavor reminds me a lot of a very nice port. A hint of bitterness in the aftertaste balances the flavor well. I have to agree with nqualis, I dont know why Ive waited so long to try this excellent beer.

A clear dark red/brown colored beer, with a thick foamy beige head. The aroma of dark fruits like prune, with some smoke and dark malts. The taste is dry chocolate with dark fruits like prune and some spices. The aftertaste is warm, bitter, a little sweet and some spices.

Source:12 oz bottle purchased in Chattanooga. 
Glass:Pint. 
Appearance:Dark brown pour with a thin off white head.  
Aroma:Caramel malt, spices and dark fruits. 
Flavor:Caramel malt base with a huge dark fruit presence, sherry and port with a spicy finish. 
Palate:Medium/full body with soft carbonation.
Overall:Excellent brew.  Not sure why I waited so long to try this.

Dark dark red, nearly black, with a one-finger creamy tan head, good retention and little lacing. Molasses, coriander, and subtle licorice aromas, all of which are present in the flavor profile as a background to the rich maltiness. Chocolate and coffee make an appearance late. Silky creamy mouthfeel, little carbonation, slightest hops bitterness, and a lingering spiciness in the aftertaste. Alcohol is subtle but warming.

2004 Bottle.  Snifter, Interestig head, large bubble, in a shortly lingering head.  The nose is an odd melange of coriander, sherry oxidation(soured toffee, think Oloroso), and silky sweet malt.  In all honesty, the whole lot smells like fresh blueberries.  I cant explain that one.  The palate is amazingly lithe and and rolls across the palate as the etheral spice tickles the tongue.  Yes, you will have to get over a small amount of oxidation, but Im really starting to think that its beginning to blow off.   Maybe Im just getting over it myself?   Blueberries seem to meld into more green vegetale spice. the oxidation begins to smell of an old leather jacket.  Not bad.  After the fancy foot spice fades the palate is left with a touch of brown bread and roasted malt that add a certain complexity that draws the quaffer back for another thought.  This beer, at this age very much reminds me of drinking an old vintage port.  Alcohol warmth only speaks as it closes the door and the chest is warmed.  Scotland indeed.   While a little oxidized, this beer scores major points with its development over 5 years.  I dont think this any more age and honestly, it probably hit its stride around 3 years. Loses some points for price. 90

330ml bottle 
8.0% ABV 
I tried this beer on July 3, 2009 at "Smokeless Joes" in Toronto, Ontario, Canada.  The beer poured a dark reddish brown with a very thin white head.  The aroma was sweet malt, caramel and some hops.  The mouthfeel was medium bodied with medium carbonation.  The flavour was sweet malt, molasses, plums, and a buttery flavour, an excellent beer.
Bottle. Dark brown colour with a qminor off-white head. Aroma and flavour of malt, caramel, spice, malt and hops.

Small creamy head good carbonation in a very dark brown almost cola looking pour.Aroma spicy malt,dried fruits,sweet fruit and sugar,floral hint.Flavour aniseed, nutmeg,cinnamon,molasses caramel ,coriander gives it a mellowness,thereis an earthy note,finish nice mix of spice and maltiness,good on the palate.

0,5 l bottle, bought at Bierei, Vienna. Poured dark brown with a small delicious lacing tan head. Fruity and resiny hop in the nose with some toasted caramel and candy sugar, some vinous perfume. Full bodied beer with a mild caramel flavor, some interesting vinous or must character and a pleasant fruity and well balanced spicy hop taste. Feeling of cellar with oak barrels. Easy drinkable, the high percentage alcohol does not hurt the palate.

Dark brown pour with an off-white head that quickly went away. Aroma is herbal, a little mediciny, and malt. Taste is herbs, malt. The coriander gives it a real nice mellow taste and mouthfeel. It is a very tasty beer, what else would you expect-its Scottish. Very low carbonation.

Dark copper with a short-lived creamy off-white head.
Aroma is very complex:  toasted/toffee malt, liquorice, tea, golden syrup, some vague woodyness and spices (cinnamon, ginger?).
Flavours of toasted malt, more spices, alcohol. More woody notes. Pretty sweet, but countered by a subtle roasted coffee bitterness. Very tasty!
Slick velvety mouthfeel with creamy carbonation, some alcohol heat on the palate.

Pours a cloudy dark brown with a thick creamy head that disappears quickly. Aroma is of promised coriander, toffee, apricot, and fruitcake. Flavor is very close to the aroma, booze becomes more apparent as I sip on. Theres a candy essence that cant be ignored. Palate is a little watery, little carbonation. Not a bad one to try. Overall, good.

This beer pours dark brown and shows hints of red when held up to the light, looks a lot like a glass of coke, there was almost no head except for a skiff of bubbles floating near the edges of the glass. The beer smells of coffee and spice with just a touch of alcohol. The beer is very tasty sweet berries and spice with some well balanced hops and malts giving the beer some good bitterness. Very tasty beer, very enjoyable me thinks I like it.

Looks like light grade motor oil...light brown with a deep tan head. Man, I could swear that all of these things found their way to my nose: chocolate, corriander, aromatic malts, sweet spiciness and dates. Excellent flavours of spices, dates and corriander (although weak) and floral hops?? Goes down very smooth and soft - highly drinkable. A harsh spicy burn and well balanced hops finish you off. All around a very complex and easy drinking brew.

Bottle. Tre Små Rum. Gothenburg. Brown colour with a small head. Aroma: Malt, spices, meat, strong wine, swedish snuff. Taste: Malty and spicy, notes of chocolate, earth, swedish glögg, dark fruit. Light bitterness. Light carbonation.

0.33 l bottle from Alko. Dark reddish brown color with  small head. Rich toffeish, caramelly, toasty and resiny aroma with pine, wood and warming alcohol. Malty, toffeish, toasty, peppery, resiny and warming flavor. Soft oily palate. Rich malty ale with nice warming character.

With great thanks to HogTownHarry. Appearance: Murky brown with a small brown head. Aroma: Chocolate, malt, alcohol. lots of spices, pepper and a very chocolate prominence as it warms. Flavour: Malt, smoke, peat and hops, lots of wood and earth notes, quite well balanced, I suspect Harry had been ageing this!
Bottle. Deep amber coloured with a small beige head. Aromas of molasses, spice, dried fruit and malt. Sweet and malty flavour with notes of coriander, dark fruit, caramel and hops.
I usually dont like beers that are this sweet but this does have a nice bitter core and is interesting to drink. The sweetness is very tasty.
pours dark brown with a small tan head.  Aroma before pouring into the glass is of blueberries and cheese.  aroma is of berries, alcohol, and caramel.  smooth, slightly creamy mouthfeel.  not too bad

Pours almost black. The aroma is sweet and strong, Roasted malt and dark fruit dominate the palate. Great flavour. Great ale character. Strong flavour to start then it mellows towards the end. Great beer.

Poured a nice browncolor with a thin off lite-brown head. Aroma was malt, a lot of toffee notes.  Flavor was more of the same. Heavy toffee caramel notes with a good malt taste and that fleeting of something else. A medium bodied beer with a chalky finish.  An interesting beer.

12oz bottle.  Pours brown with a thin tan head.  Caramel malt aroma with coriander, berry, vanilla and a smidge of citrus.  Herbal flavor up front (coriander) followed by a touch of malty sweetness, vanilla and alcohol.  Third brew Ive tried from these guys and all three were far from boring.

In short: A clean and lean dark ale with a wide flavour spectrum.  Excellent.
How: Bottle 330ml.  Many many times.  This rating for a 6+ months old bottle
The look: Clear dark ruby-mahogany body topped by a beige ring of foam
In long: Nose of crème-caramel and dark fruits.  Body is lean, a bit too much for the style, I would prefer a more corpulent body for this beer.  Soft carbonation.  Taste is molasses, black liquorice, some dark fruits, caramel and black pepper spiciness.  I dont know what herbs they use (Traditional Ales dont use hops I think) but there is a strong tobacco leaves flavour in there.  Finish is black pepper and tobacco leaves.  Because of the extra-clean/lean body the alcohol is showing a bit despite the relatively low abv.  The beer has a lot going for it with many cohesive flavour elements and it is highly drinkable.  Very very good yet it is too clean and lean, and imho it is not the world-class beer that so many others make it to be.  Still, Ive been drinking the Jacobite on a regular basis for a while and I will continue doing so because this is a very good (almost excellent) beer that is widely available.  Seems to be Scotland most appreciated beer export.  A traditional ale that Scottish have been drinking for many years during their annual eight weeks of fog and rain.  Or if you prefer the way they call it over there, a summer ale.
Bottle at Lees Brown body with tannish head.  Nice and spicy head with sweet caramel malts.  Very strange and interesting flavor.  Nice carbonation.  Tasty.

Bottle. Pours deep ruby brown with a beige head. Huge spicy aroma, with light smoke and some fruity, almost whiskey like sweetness. The flavor is malty and spicy, with cocoa, smoke, toasted bread, and a light sweetness. Very good.

Pours deep dark brown (almost balck) with a nice tan coloured head. Nose is really expressive! A heap of spice & tea, almost gewurztraminer like (i dont know how...?) hides beneath a layer of dark choc/coffee malt. Palate lets the dark malt come through more. Dry coffee roast and bitter chocolate with a layer of dark fruit & caramel sweetness, crazy depth! Finishes with significant spice. Like muggus says, a weird hybrid style here - part belgian dark, part porter with some crazy aromatic spice to boot. Awesome!

330ml bottle.
Deep near black body with small dense tan head. Leaves good lace and legs on the way down.
Amazing sort of nose. Rich burnt toffee, dark chocolate, smokey woody roasted malts, liquorice, with a unique spiciness that makes it almost seem Belgian; pepper, clove, coriander, citrus peel, cinnamon, nutmeg, dark fruits.
Oilly body, sticky texture, carbonation relatively low, slight spice astrigency but well balanced by malt sweetness.
Rich malt body, seems to take a different direction to the nose. Dark chocolate mixed plums, prunes, dates, good helping of rich nutty maltiness, liquorice, vanilla, leading onto clove and cinnamon spice. Orange peel on the finish, some pepper alluding to alcohol, and a lingering dry bready yeast note.
Another unique and delicious beer from this brewery. If I had to narrrow it down to similiar beers, its almost like a Porter combined with a Weizenbock, and a Belgian Wit, odd combination, but its so tasty!

The spice comes through strong in the aroma - Im assuming its the coriander. The flavor is much maltier than the nose suggests, nice roasted malts, a little chocolaty on the front end, the spice pulls through towards the end but doesnt over power.  Nicely balanced between the malt and spice. Very enjoyable, I want another!

Poured a nice cola color with a thin off white head.  Aroma was malt, a lot of toffee notes, and a hint of spice.  There was something kind of mysterious lurking in the background that I couldnt place, but was very intriguing.  Flavor was more of the same.  Heavy toffee caramel notes with a good malt kick and that fleeting mystery flavor.  The spice was nice and Im sure it was the coriander that was lending the mystery, but it didnt really taste like coriander.  Intriguing beer.
bottle - dark brown beer with a not very long lasting beige head. Spicy aroma, like fruits and cinnamon. Flavour is also spicy, toffee and malt.

33cl Bottle (BB 2017). Very dark brown almost black.A very light tan head.Spicy aromas with hints of chocolate, licorice and caramel. Very complex taste bittersweet chocolate, caramel,licorice, roasted malt,toffee ,coriander,plums and more. Extremely tasty and drinkable. Im curious to age the other bottle I have for some years. Exceptional !

From a bottle this poured a dark and muddy brown with an off-white head and good lacing. Nose of ripe fruits and spices like coriander.  Rich mouthfeel. and lots of flavors of chocolate, figs, nuts, and the finish is very nice with light bitterness. A very good beer.

Bottle. The strong smell of coffee and bitter chocolate, very malty and sweet. The head is small, creamy and brown with a normal duration. The body is nearly black. The beer has a nice taste of chocolate, I should check it one on one with the Double Chocolate Stout from Youngs if I get the chance. No spices in the taste. The body is very creamy, medium to very strong with no carbonation. A very nice beer.

11.2 oz. bottle, consumed on 4-4-09. Unique aroma is juicy, sweet, and fruity. Chocolate milk shake and fruity pebble scents. Pours a medium to dark brown with a copper tint and a moderate amount of light tan head. Overly sweet taste. Brown ale-like taste: Nutty, especially hazelnut. Not nearly enough hops. Not as spicy as I expected, but the coriander comes forth in the finish. Light body. Moderately lively in the palate. Theres something non-beer-like about this beer, probably related to the low hopping rates. Thats too bad, since I like beer.

11.2 fl oz bottle.  The aroma is very heavy on the coriander (orange zest and a light spicy nuttiness), and if smelling this blind, i would almost think that Im about to drink a white ale.  On further whiff however, its darker, toastier toffee bread malt character comes through, making this a highly interesting smelling beer.   The pour is fairly unremarkable a light fizzy head and medium appearing body but the color of the beer is a nice hue of dark mahogany.  Most aspects of the flavor match the aroma very well, and surprisingly this combination works very well together along with the other notes of fig, green apples, and a mild floral bitterness.  The mouthfeel is suberb as the drink hits with the right amount of punch to the let flavors capture your attention, but at the same time allowing them to run gently and smoothly down the back of your throat.  If i wouldnt have had bad connotations associated with past beer experiences with coriander prominence (aka witbier), i would have enjoyed this one even more.  With that said, this is still a very well made and unique piece of brewing that made for quite an enjoyable experience.

12oz bottle best before June 2017.  Pours an ugly muddy cola/ruby color with big fat clear beige bubbles lining the rim.  Aroma shows spice and mild barley.  Coriander I suppose.  Some floral and fruity elements become evident underneath.  Blueberries.  Maybe some vanilla. Blueberry pie. Interesting.  Flavor is similar to the aroma.  Mild, alcohol hidden very well.  Low carbonation with a silky mouthfeel.  This is all right but it did not blow me away.  Unique though.

A rather old bottle. Port-like aroma with lots of dark fruit. Sweet flavor with berries and other dark fruits. Slightly tart. Amazingly silky mouth feel, which was impressive at first then got annoying. Almost too smoothbut that was due to its age. An interesting and flavorful beer.

Bottle 330ml. Pours hazy very dark brown colour beer, with fast disappearing beige head. Aroma is...different. Has lots of malts, some spices (coriander) and sweetnes (kiwi?). Taste is smooth: mämmi, malts, raisin, rum. Some watery alcohol in the finish.

Nice old label that makes a reference to Bonnie Prince Charlie.  Black pour with quickly dropping, foamy head.  Pungent, malty aroma that has a rich floral presence.  Full honey and malt flavor that reminds me of Aventinus.  Sweetness and bitterness play on the tongue, with subtle coriander coming in at the close.  This is a a pricey import, but it is a very fine ale that moves right into my top 20. Excellent.
I drank this immediately after a family funeral and it did the trick; a complex, rich ale with lots of malts, w/stone-fruit overtones and a very long-lasting coriander aftertaste. Yes.

(Bottle) Deep ruby red and clear. Small fizzy white head. Malts, chocolate and caramell in aroma. Full bodied and bit oily palate with medium carbonation. Malts, chocolate, spices, roastedness, cherry, sweetness, bitterness and hint of coffee in taste. Chocolate, malts and bitterness in aftertaste.

Ive had Traquairs House Ale so many times Ive lost count. Ive only SEEN their Jacobite once and its in my hands and its time to rate it. Im glad I did because, like the House Ale, its quite enjoyable. 

The beer starts out with a dark brown/amber pour with a small/medium sized 1-finger thick cap. The aromas I could detect were slightly fruity (oranges and dates), a bit of brandy, toffee..even a bit of Pepsi somehow (strange). A nicely sweetend flavor with notes of roasted malts, rum soaked raisins or maybe cherries and brandy...vanilla pops up too. A great winter time beer. Picked the perfect time to drink it too. Best before 2014.

Brown bottle, 33 cl, best before APR 18, via Importations Privées Bièropholie, savoured on March 15 2009; eye: reddish brown, tiny ring of beige head, clear, no effervescence, no lacing; nose: malt, light peat, light smoke, liquorice, molasses, light burnt, dark small berries, light alcohol, spices; mouth: all nicely balanced, malt, slight peat, slight smoke, light molasses, light liquorice, spices, light candied fruits, light orange, finale in malt-molasses with presence of candied fruits, silky, slightly bitter, mildly sweet, medium body, below-average carbonation, slightly vinous texture; overall: quite likable

FRANÇAIS

Bouteille brune, 33 cl, meilleure avant APR 18, via Importations Privées Bièropholie, savourée le 15 mars 2009; il : brune rouge, petit anneau de mousse beige, claire, pas deffervescence, pas de dentelle; nez : malt, léger tourbe, léger fumé, réglisse, mélasse, léger brûlé, petits fruits foncés, léger alcool, épices; bouche : tout en harmonie, malt, très léger tourbe, très léger fumé, léger mélasse, léger réglisse, épices, léger fruits confits, léger orange, finale en malt-mélasse avec présence de fruits confits, soyeuse, très légèrement amère, moyennement sucrée, corps moyen, carbonatation sous la moyenne, texture légèrement vineuse; en résumé : bien aimé

330 ml bottle. Finland.
Dark brown almost black colour with no head. Aroma: spices, liquorice, fruits and sweetness. Flavour: spices, malts, coffee, dark chocolate and some alcohol warmness. Quite dry and rich but the coffee flavour bothers me a bit. Still enjoyable but not easy.

Bottle. Couldve sworn Ive rated this before, but at least I dont seem to have any rating of it on here... Thus:
Pours a deep, dark ruby, with a beautiful, (but sadly shortlived) petite foamy beige head.
Aroma is spicy, with molasses, malts, dark fruit, licorice and mocha.
