Very full body, with mild carbonation and clean mouthfeel.
Spicy, sweetish flavour, featuring malts, dark fruit, licorice, a hint of alcohol (though amazingly little considering the abv). Orange rind, perhaps? Alcohol returns slightly stronger in finish, together with a kind of fruity sourness (like apples rather than citrus).
Yuymmy, but perhaps not quite as yummy as I remembered it. Guess Ill have to try again in a couple of years.

What a beer.   
Extra dark brown color.   Small white head.
Subtle, but pleasant aroma. 

Rich, malty flavor - then coffee, coriander and plum.   Remarkably tasty.

Questa è una signora birra,di gran lunga tra le migliori dellarcipelago britannico e tra le mie favorite di ogni tempo.
Birra quasi nera con schiuma sottile e  beige.Laroma è complesso e piacevole: una certa dolcezza,di bacche, fragole e uno poco di alcool.Complesso è anche il sapore,un pò trappista,un pò vino secco e speziato.Complessa e nienaffatto noiosa.Grande birra

Almost black beer with small beige head. Aroma is complex and pleasant: some sweetness, berries, strawberries and hint of alcohol. Flavour is also complex, berries, slightly trappist-like, even like wine and quite dry and spicy in the end. Full-bodied and nicely slippery to drink. Appereance differs from aroma and flavor and that was surprise for me. Traquair Jacobite Ale is very complex beer and you cannot bore this beer.

UPDATED: JUN 28, 2010 Bottle. Dark brown colour with a very small off-white head. Spicy aroma with notes of liquorice, plum and some sweetness. The flavour is very spicy and malty with liquorice, pepper and toffee. Medium-bodied and smooth mouthfeel. Very good.

Havent been back since this place blew up so I will start by shooting off some half assed, non analytical reviews of my favorite beers. Hoo boy, this is lovely, the nose is so nicely spicy, chocolate, one of the most elegant bodies in beer I have encountered. I would pass a reasonably good lay for this. I am gay for beer.

330 ml bottle, Dark ruby pour. Aroma has fruits and berries. Quite flavorful without having any of the flavors is too strong or overwhelming Tiny hints of chocolate. Carbonation is just right, not too much. Delicious well balanced spiced ale.

Dark and very beutiful ruby color. Thin head is blond and quite creamy. The aroma is powerful. It has lots of malts, dark fruits (raisins, dates), sweet berries, wine qums and some alcohol in the finish with quite intense licorice aroma and darker malts. The flavor is vinous, strong on sweetish maltiness and chewy fruitiness. Alcohol is present in the finish. Low bitterness. The palate is slick,slightly syrupy, low carbonated and medium to full bodied.

ersma: sip slowly and remember the old toast "to the king o´er the water.", so stehts auf dem rücketikett in schöner schreibschrift.
ein sehr dunkles ale, fast schwarz. schäumt mächtig auf, aber der schaum verschwindet (ale-typisch) schnell wieder. 
das bier hat einen unglaublich würzigen geruch. was nicht weiter verwundert, sind doch auf der zutatenliste neben quellwasser, malz, hopfen und hefe auch gewürze aufgeführt. dazu malzige süße. der antrunk ist entsprechend: röstmalzig, süßlich und sehr würzig. kann die gewürze nicht näher spezifizieren, zimt, kardamom, die richtung. schokoladig schmeckts auch. da gibts bei bto berufenere nasen für die genaue analyse. jedenfalls passts prima zur weihnachtszeit. im unterton leichte hopfige herbe, die zur mitte ausgeprägter wird, aber ohne der dominanten süße konkurrenz machen zu können. das ende komt ausgewogen süßlich-herb, die gewürznote klingt langsam aus. ein traum von einem bier. die süffigkeit leidet ob der aromavielfalt. dieses bier verweigert ein reinkippen. siehe oben.
die flasche hat zwei schwarz-weisse etiketten, sieht alles handgemalt aus. wenn ichs recht verstanden habe, gibts bei dem haus ein tor, das zuletzt 1745 von bonnie prince charlie benutzt wurde. der ist vermutlich auch auf dem frontetikett gezeichnet. aus anlass der 250-jährigen torschließung wurde dieses bier 1995 aufgelegt. haltbar bis 2014, also durchaus noch am reifen.
fazit: das zweite bier aus dem hause traquair und ein weiterer volltreffer.

2007 Bottle - Pours a rich dark amber with a large off white head...aroma is spicy malt, a bit fruity...flavour is similarly dominated by dark malt syrup, I get the coriander, and a bit of anise...its a thick brew, and gets a bit cloying without any bitterness...good fun though...
330 ml bottle. Deep brown color, tan head. Some wood and alcohol in the aroma. Dark malt flavor with spicy licorice notes and alcohol. Full body, light carbonation. Im not impressed.

bottle 33cl from ølbutikken.
dark brown with a reddish hue, small thick fine brown head.
aroma of cheese, figs, peaches, alc. caramel. flavor is caramel, faint plums or raisins, spices, anise, well rounded and balanced flavor, some dark fruits in there too.id say its a barley wine tastewise. malts. bitterness and sweetness unite for a pleasant flavor experience. alc. is a little too noticeable.

Deep orange, syrupy brown color with smallish head, practically head only. Syrupy, sweet malty aroma with plums and hops. Sweet flavor is syrupy, licoricey, fruity and slightly Belgian style yeasty. Smooth palate is medium-bodied and slicky.

Bouteille de 330 ml. Nos yeux observent  une bière de couleur rubis très foncée et un col de mousse modeste. Au nez on découvre des arômes de fruits rouges secs, de grain torréfié, de gâteau aux fruits, de café et dagrumes. En bouche le corps est moyen avec une effervescence faible-moyenne. On goûte des saveurs de grain grillé, dagrumes, de fruits secs et de houblon. La finale présente une bonne amertume citronné.

33cl Bottle from De Bierkoning. Clear dark reddish brown colour, creamy off white head. Sweet aroma of molasses, chocolate, malts, candy, some alcohol. Flavour is sweet, malty, chocolate, with a slightly roasted, bitter alcohol finish. Soft carbonation. Good beer, but I expected it to be more fullbodied.

330 ml bottle. Deep dark ruby colour, very thin off-white head. Sweet aroma of dark fruits and berries, also some chocolate and roasted malts. Medium to full body, smooth carbonation. Plenty of liquorice and dark fruits in the flavour, warm and spicy finish. An excellent beer, complex and balanced.

33cl bottle, 07. Dark ruby, near black with a firm beige head. Buttery, sweet blackcurrant aroma, rye bread, musky liquorice and some herbs. Pretty different, though subtle. Intense old school salty liquorice flavor with old butter, black currants and earth. A bit ashy, herbal currant leafy finish. Almost full bodied, average soft carbonation. Interesting to see where this goes with age, now its still somewhat restrained. Goes nicely with some Incredible string band.

Pours to a dark brownish-red that glows when held to a light.  Tiny, quickly dissipating head.  Nose is sweet caramel and candy fruits.  Its very light on that palate making it very easy - and pleasurable - to drink.  For such light fair its complexity is impressive.  Its sweet, slightly spicy and just a little tart.  This beer is a dessert in itself, and masks its 8% ABV pretty well.
Bottled. Poured dark with a super thin head. Flavor was fruity and caramel, some raisins. Some malts, prety light for what it is.  Worth forking over 8 bucks at the ol supermarket.

Pours a very dark red with a thing fading head.  Big yeasty aroma of caramel, dark fruit, and bananas.  Flavor reminds me a lot of a Rochefort 8 with less alcohol and more of a Scotch ale twist.  The body is also much lighter than a trappist beer, almost watery, but not unpleasant.  A very complex and satisfying beer.

12 oz bottle

This has been sitting unintentionally in the cellar for a few months.  I finally discovered it the other day ad thought now was as good a time as any.  After trying it I would not mind having another bottle.  This time however I will pick it up when I am ready to drink it; let the store do the storage so I get one that is fresher.

Aroma / Appearance - A half finger foamy head combined with the ruby red body to create a picturesque beer.  A thin sheet of lacing hinted at the promise to come.  Cinnamon, spice, powdered chocolate, dates, and fig make it a sweet profile.  It seems like a less alcoholic old ale but that could be due to the cellaring.

Flavor / Palate - Persimmons and plum fill the palate.  Next comes an odd blend of dried mango, orange, and spice.  This one is hard to pigeonhole but whatever it is I like it.

Dark brown pour with ruby red tint.  Thin light tan head.  Malty aroma with cream.  Sweet oaky malt flavor with hints of chocolate caramel.  Light citrus notes complement the coriander nicely.  Very mild.  Hides the alcohol very well.  Some bitter hops on the finish.

Pours black with ruby edges and a tan head.
Intense sweet malt aroma plus a candy sweetness. Some leathery yeast. 
Chocolaty nose, with dried fruits as well as wild berries and cherry. 
Prune and cherry flavours dominate with a sweet malt. Quite fruity. 
Surprisingly clean. Awesome.

The pour was clear and mostly brown with some lighter hints at red.  A short off-white head popped up and produced streaks of lacing.  The aroma was very nice and quite diverse.  Light spice, tart fruit, thin coffee, hops, floral notes.  The flavor was nice too.  Light pine and floral hops, light tart fruit like a pear or an granny smith apple, thin caramel and spice.  Almost a watery mouthfeel but not in a negative way.  It was insanely drinkable.  Very enjoyable.

Best by June 2017.  A deep but clear dark brown ale with a quick thin dirty white head that leaves a nice ring.  Fantastic aroma, floral, spicy, soapy, lemon, and even light peaty blueberry notes.  Taste is more earthy peat, berries and a light pine spiciness.

Again, I write the disclaimer...Im a big sucker for "traditional ales", or recreations of older beer recipes from throughout history. Thus my rating of this beer would reflect that. With that said, this is a GREAT beer, very enjoyable in its own right. 

The Appearance is a dark chocolate/caramel brown, with a 1-finger tan head, not much lacing. The aroma was amazing; a mix of sweet caramel malts and fruit. Theres a slight bit of spicyness thrown in. The flavor is much like the aroma. This beer reminded me more of an English porter than a scotch ale. The flavor was sweet malts, chocolate, and included a piney flavor, as well as a slightly spicy quality. The mouthfeel is thick, and enjoyable. The finish has a sweetness well balanced by hops and other spices. Great beer overall.

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2009 Pours the deepest mahogany, almost opaque into the glass, with ruby hues to the fringes.  A minimal tan head appears, but diminishes soon thereafter.  The nose is very vinous, reminiscent of dessert wines (spot on for muscat / niagra grapes).  The flavor is similarly dry, with hints at a cab sav wine, earthy fruits, with some oak-aged tannins, spices and woody licorice to finish off the pull.  Although the texture is smooth and the mouthfeel slick, this is a complex brew, almost as a an appreciation of the wine aficionado.  Opinion of the style aside, this is definitely appreciated for the offering.  Kudos for the unique take on this ale... sommeliers are sure to be delighted!

Trade with nearbeer. Bottled 33cl. It pours a very dark beer with a small beige head. The nose is of plum, nutmeg, banana, pumpernickel, coconut, smoke, coriander, malt, Cadburys chocolate, toffee and roasted malt. Extremely pleasant, complex and distinct. Sweet malty taste of Cadburys chocolate, coriander, coconut and pumpernickel. Not much lacework. Lovely hints of molasses and ginger appearing. Some alcohol shwowing up with the swallow leaving hints of fennel. Some marmite and vitamin tablets in the finish. A bit dissapointing towards the end. Thanks a lot nearbeer for this beer!

33 cl bottle. Dark brown color, moderate beige head. Aroma is caramel, wood and malt. Flavor is lovely sweetness, caramel, roasted malt, spices, dried fruit and a hint of liqorice in the finish. Very nice.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Very complex aroma, sweet, vanilla, pear, laurel, licorice and cinnamon. Not unbalanced but too much on the sweet side. Very dark brown color, light brown small head, good lace. Sweet, bitter, licorice, vanilla, lightly roasted, hint of chocolate. Strange moving mouthfeel between thin and full, soft overall. I was expecting much more. Out of balance in the flavor, too much on the sweet spice side.

V - thin film of a head, nearly black hue, dark ruby 4
A - Unique aroma, blend of hops and grasses with a black licorice molasses syrup quality; barley 8
T - high in barley with a a heather-y
P - dry
O - very pleasant

Dark brown with a minimal head a nd little lacing, not surprising with 8% alcohol, though. 
Fruity and malty nose with some hint of spice.
Taste is earthy with dark malts and fruit. The corriander is noticeable, but not overpowering.
Smooth mouthfeel with light carbonation. Slight alcohol burn, but is pleasant and balances well with the overall beer.

Spiced aroma reminds me of mulling spices, pinecones and coffee.  Very dark clear brown, faint ring of a head in the glass.  Delicately complex, lots of dried wood, some orange peel.  Low carbonation, smooth elegant mouthfeel, only a hint of the alcohol comes through.
bottle.  Brown pour.  small head. Aroma is spicy, malty and has some notes of dark dried fruits.  Flavor is a bit sweet, with wood, raisins, booze, caramel and spices.  Nice.  Very nice.

Bottle 330ml. Poured a clear brown color with a small off-white head that diminished quickly. Good aroma of coriander, raisin and malt. Medium body with smooth texture. Good fruity bitter sweet flavor with long pleasing finish. Interesting brew.

Bottle from Nelsons Wines, drunk 4th Oct 08. Slightly hazy reddish dark brown. Fig, plum, alcohol on nose. Similar in the mouth, with liquorice, raisin, woodiness and a warmth at the end. Decently long finish. A good late night drink.

UPDATED: FEB 16, 2009 I think this is my first in this style pours medium brown with little to no head aromas of caramel malts and friuts taste is of sweet caramel malts and corrindor and friuts overall a very sweet after dinner brew hides alcohol very well  this one to be followed by hair of the dog adam  bottle thank to giascar

Poured a deep chestnut brown with very little dark tan head. Dark toffee and chocolate on the nose, spices. Remarkably enough the yeast almost adds a vegemite-like smell! Hoppy bitterness is tied in well with some roasted malts, as well as light pepper and clove. Again the yeast is very reminiscent of vegemite to me, and I dont mean in a bad way. Thick and smooth on the palate, very little carbonation.

bottle.  Aroma is fantastic.  Caramel, smokey damp wood, yeast, raisin, and brandy.  Deep amber chestnut brown with a small off-white frothy head that left no lace and mostly diminished.  Really liked the aroma and look but that is where the love affair ended.  Flavor is bitter with a sour finish.  Palate is light bodied and watery.  Man I thought this was going to be a gem but the palate was a real let down.  The flavor is average at best.  LAME!!

UPDATED: JAN 26, 2009 Pours dark brown/black with little to no head forming. Aromas of fruity apples, spice and some caramel malt in the background. 
A very smooth texture and flavour,  with flavours of spiced apple at the forefront blending smoothly into a spicy vanilla flavour and ending with some bitter chocolaty malt.

33 cl bottle courtesy of a trade with cgarvieuk.  Pours a deep chestnut with a thin-moderate off-white head that faded to a ring after the first sip and left a light coating of foam on the glass with each sip.  Very pleasant aroma of malt, raisins, plums, cherries and some mild alcohol vapors.  I am not picking up any spice in the aroma, but the fruit is quite lovely.  The flavor is malt with a bit of chocolate and some very scant dark fruit.  Definitely not as fruity or complex as the aroma.  As the beer warms, the alcohol becomes more pronounced, especially towards the finish.  Mild bitterness at the finish.  Light-medium bodied, I would almost call it a tad thin.  Glad I tried it.
Crushed with Jakebra.  Sweet nose.  Flavor aight.  Much deliciousness, but not quite that much.  Pretty aight.

Bottle at Bishops Arms, Karlstad, shared with Bananamaniac. Pours a dark brown color with a smell head. Aroma is spicy with notes of clove, malt, dried fruits, pine-needles and smoke. Flavour is first of all spicy, malty, slightly sweet, with notes of clove, pine-needles, dried fruits and smoke. Palate is smooth, filling, quite fullbodied and thick. Overall a very good beer, as all the other beers Ive had from Traquair.

Bottle at the Moon and Sixpence in Portland, OR. Very intriguing and beguiling brew that pours a murky brown with a tiny head. Strong scents of dried fruit and smoke, but with a smooth taste that leaves you very fulfilled. As a man with a degree in history I also greatly appreciate the name and story. Silly Stuarts.

Pours a dark brown with a minimal head. The aroma isn’t terribly strong, but it’s nice... lots of cola and dark malts. The flavor has lots of cola as well, but some of the coriander pops through also. Pretty similar to Trois Pistoles... a good beer, but the mouthfeel could be thicker.

Bottle shared at tasting.  Pours a medium to dark brown color with light beige head.  Smell is chocolate and smoky peatiness.  Taste is smoky, creamy and almost chocolatey but not quite.  Creamy but light body and a lot like a scotch ale.   Quite soft carbonation and a faint balance of hops.  Decent overall.

11oz bottle.  Pours a mostly clear dark brown with a fizzy beige head that dissipated quickly.  Nose held maple syrup, caramel, toffee and some spiced aromas.  Flavor was quite sweet and rich with toasted malts and candied dark fruits.  A medium bodied brew, great stuff.

My first ’product of Scotland’, very interesting and unique stuff.  Not much of a head to this dark murky reddish brew.  Chocolate + plums + smoke in the nose.  Sweet initial taste, along with small bubbles, followed by roasted notes that takes you down easy.  Enjoyable.

Sampled from a bottle provided by Øl Konsortiet  at EBF 08. Russet-like body colour with a moderate, beige head. Aroma of spiced fruits. Vinous taste of dark fruits and malts, herbs and liquorice. A touch of hop resin in the aftertaste. Ill go for a bottle of this one when I get the chance (night cap, late on 12.09.208).

11.2 oz bottle, BB 2014.  Clear crimson brown with a tan haze.  Nose is blueberry, plum brandy, fig and toffee.  Mediumish body with faint carb.  Taste is raisin, dates, wood and grape skins.  Dry bitter finish.  Sticky, not too sweet, kind of boring.

[EBF @ Copenhagen, September 2008] Bottle. Small foamy off-white head that mostly diminished. Spare display of lacework. Mahogany color. Aroma of grain, mild oak like, spice, toasted malt, chocolate, butterscotch, fruit. Medium to full bodied with an average carbonation and smooth texture. Moderated sweet flavor with some counter bitterness. Dried fruity and mild alcoholic warming finish. Well brewed.

Wonderful nose with a malty spice and a hint of a thoroughbred scotch.
It’s ABV is betrayed by a lightness to what would appear, by looks, to be a heavy beer.
Has a smooth finish that is long but without any bitter hues of aftertaste.  
Just a hint of carbonation leds the flavors bounce....dark, malty, chocolately even, but always with a persistent coriander bias.

Highly recommend even at relatively high price
Bottle:  Pretty good beer.  Hard to get a handle on.  Aroma of malts and spices.
bottle,walnut colored pour, head is small and tan, nose is spicy malt,flavor is a roasted malt and mild spice and cherry, finish is dry and smooth

Bottle.  Dark brownish-red color, sparse tan head.  Rich toasty malts, spicy with the coriander present but not overboard, light peat presence.  Great taste, very Scottish, a wave of caramel malts over moderate coriander presence, just enough to add spice to the heavy malts.  Will be picking this one up regularly.

Bottle. Pours a dark brown with a reddish hue and a thin biege head. Aroma is spicey and mildy sweet. Coriander and different spices on the tongue, along with dark fruits. The beer also had a nice full and chewy mouthfeel. This was definately a great beer.

Almost black brown with a touch of amber. Just a streak of lacing, no head at all. Aromas of raisons, coffee, corriander, tamarind. Lightly carbonated. Darkly malty, but not too sweet. Moderately spicy, fig, coffee, cocoa,

The Jacobite was a very dark wood brown pour.  Small foam almond head.  Like a spicy root beer although more complex and more character.  Nice malt quality, dark fruits but on the low down.  Smooth with the spiciness subdued and the ABV just right.  Worth a try for sure.

The experience starts with a light root beer color pour and a wonderful, nostalgic aroma that reminds me of old time spice stick candy and bazooka bubble gum. There is something else even more telling in there that remains just out of my grasp so I must try again.  The flavor was surprisingly simple, a malty sweet flavor without any unpleasantness.

330ml Bottle - Gravity Beer Market - Olympia, WA 
Aroma  Huge malt aroma with very little hops.  The spice and sweet aroma come through. Appearance  Black in color, thin head and clear. 
Flavor  Great dark roasty malt flavor.  Very spicy and dried fruit flavor.   
Palate  Nice Mouthfeel, good texture with a dry finish. 
Overall  This was a very good traditional dark ale.  Very tasty and tons of great malt flavors.
Black colored brew. Very nice sweet aroma of spices and fruits. Flavor has chocolate malts, spices and some fruits. Good hopbitterness. Overall a good brew.
Bottle, thx to NoiZe. Dark colour, small tan head. Aroma has fruits, spices and chocolate malts. Flavour has dark malts and spices. A nice hoppy bitterness to finish it off. Great!

Bottle (best before 2014): pours a dark reddish-brown with a frothy light tan head, aroma of cherry, caramel and malt, (kind of a Belgian beer aroma), taste is malty, chocolate, a bit of the alcohol and spices, leaves a bit of a watery feel in the back of the throat.

Pours a beautiful black color with froathy tan head that dissapates over time.  Aroma is sweet caramel and dark fruits with some desert spirit alcohol presence.  Reminds me of a rum filled chocolate candy in a way.  Flavor exceptionally good.  Medium mouthfeel, nice dark fruit flavors with mild coriander and spice, mild roasted malts.  Can’t tell the 8% at all.  One of the truely great beers.

11.2oz bottle.  Deep brown-black color.  Quite an interesting beer, a must try for one getting into the beer world.  Rugged old brandy and other sweet alcohol aromas, that are hard to get past.  Not unlike a Barleywine at first sip, but the coriander really balances the beer, giving it a nice sweet, drinkable character.  With the taste and aroma, you know you are ingesting serious alcohol, but at 8%, you arent really quite as phased as would be expected.  Quite enjoyable.  Would love to sample fresh.  Definitely mellows and becomes more enjoyable around 45-50% F.  This is a beer that wouldn’t get it’s justified rating from just a sample.  Great mellow sweet pecan malt finish.

Appearance: Pours a dark, chestnut brown body that picks up some reddish hints when held up to the light. Also, a thin, ivory-colored head!

Smell: Dark malt aroma yields a scent of caramel and brown sugar alongside notes of plums and oven-toasted coriander seeds, which, being a popular gin ingredient rightly has me thinking of gin.

Taste: Dark maltiness with tastes of dark brown sugar, maple syrup, and nuts. Pleasing, though never overwhelming sweetness. Faint dark fruitiness. Earthy, herbal coriander spice flavor, along with a mild bitterness and warming genever presence does a good job of tempering the malty sweetness. Leaves you with a lingering taste of pumpernickel bread.

Mouthfeel: Medium-plus body. Medium-low carbonation. Slight stickiness to the mouthfeel.

Drinkability: A fine spiced ale. Plenty of complexity as well as overall restraint and balance to deliver an interesting, tasty brew.
Lots of caramel in this one. Pours dark, nice aroma ... but ultimately not as satisfying to me as the Traquair House Ale. I’m willing to drink more, though, in the name of science.

Pours a murky, red brown with a medium khaki head that fades fast but rings the glass. Very spicy, caramel malt, and Belgian yeast bready aroma. Very sweet cherry, orange flavor for the start but then some dried spice flavors carry it over to a dry floral finish. Kind of tart and woody in a way too. Deep and revealing.

12 oz botlle from my secret santa. best before june 2014. pours deep dark brown with very little cabonation and no head. unique aroma. coriander, hops and dark malts. flavours are similar. i can honestly say ive never had a beer that tastes anything like this. id be interested in trying this one with a little age on it. some thinness held it back but overall very enjoyable and something i know i goin to want some time in the future. thanks santa.

In the bottle from HyVee CB. Pours such a dark brown that you’d confuse it for being black. Almost no head at all when poured, but once the beer is in the glass, if you swirl it, you can generate a nice reddish ochre looking head. The aroma is of plums and licorice. This is a flat beer that is medicine-like in a fowl way. I am greatly disappointed by this after reading all the hype. The spices just don’t seem to be pleasant to my taste. This is definitely thinner in body than I would have expected for a beer that is almost rated a 4. I’ll not likely ever drink this again.

(SCOTLAND) Pours a nice dark brown color with a sm white head. The aroma is of coco beans, dark fruit, and molasses. The taste is very malty with some vanilla, and licorice notes !!! You dont taste the 8% in this brew which is very nice. So i must say this one was a total suprise for me, Do yourself a favor a get some.  :)
Dark brown, Flat, malty, caramel, chocolate, little dark fruits, nutty, and spice.  It kind of reminds me of flat cola.  Must be a off bottle.  Still not bad.

Appearance: Very dark brown. Very little head. Slightly hazy.
Aroma: Dark fruit and malt. Some alcohol.
Taste: Malt and spices/herbs. Nice, strong aftertaste
Info: 330ml bottle, 17/7-2008, 195/500

Bottle.  Pours a dark brown with a small tan head.  Aroma of raisin, dark fruits, brown sugar, very sweet.  Flavor strongly of brown sugar, raisins.  Thick mouthfeel.  This beer is sweet but not oppressing, reminds me of a calmer/more complex/less intense DFH Raison D’extra.  Quite good.

Bottle, best before June 2014. Aroma of earthy, dark fruits, the darkest of the dark, rich, sweet malt, richest of the rich. Flavor brings no surprises, continues its quest of decadence. Somehow manages to avoid becoming overly sweet, but it’s hanging right on the edge the whole time. A sipper, and a good one.
Dark brown pour with a small head.  Nutty aroma.  Sweet malt taste.  Some bitterness.
Dark brown color with small tan head and no lacing. Aroma and flavor have strong malts and light chocolate and raisin notes. Good but expensive

UPDATED: JUL 11, 2008 Pours true brown with a white ring for a head. Scent of chocolate, oranges, and bread. The flavor follows the nose seamlessly with sweet malts, chocolate, bread, subdued citrus and finishes with a little alcohol. The palate really works with the flavors, smooth and delicate  (but never watery) for a refreshing touch and balance that reflects the other components. This is a total knockout.
Hmm Hmm Hmm. Very impressed, chocolate, orange, liqourice, you could probably pick anything out of here. Well, I could...Bang on that is.

12 oz bottle into pint glass.  Pours a dark dark brown, almost black, with a creamy and tall beige head that unfortunately fades pretty quick.  Aroma of molasses, candy sugar, sweet dark malt, cherries, molasses, honey, and more - subtle aromas keep coming out as it warms.  Its flavors are also subtle and just as extensive - cherries, oak, vanilla, sweet malt, ... - really delicious and probably great with age.  No signs of any alcohol, which is pretty stunning for the abv.  This brew is unbelievably silky soft on the palate (the only reason I gave it a 4 instead of a 5 was because it could be a bit thicker).  Very soft carbonation.  Overall: this stuff is tasty and might prove the be great with age.
0.33l - Pours a dark, cloudy red, fleeting small head, slight licorice on nose, licorice and caramel on palate.  OK.

Pours opaque brown with a thin tan head. Aroma is wine and licorice with a bit of plum. Taste adds a malt and caramel component to the fruit flavor of the nose. Licorice is still there as well. Very nice beer.

Bottle (in NZ, at Galbraiths Alehouse), pours black with a bubbly yellow-brown head. A rich fruit aroma with lots of licorice and slightly salty. A deliciously thick palate, with roasted malt at the front of the tongue, sweeter syrupy malt at the back of the mouth, combining with molasses and tobacco flavours - complex! The oily finish carries dark berries before bittering nicely and leaving some smokey malt lingering long in the mouth. Just brilliant.

Bottle. Pours a blackish brown colour with a thin off-white head. The aroma is refreshing with distinct notes of...chewing gum (is it the swedish chewing gum jenka?). There are also notes of berries and some spices. Very odd - but it a good way! The flavour is quite sweet and malty with notes of berries and some fruits. There are also some roasted notes and a freshness. Very odd beer - but oh so good!

Bottle.  Pours a very dark brown with reddish hues.  Aroma is spicy, a little grassy, a sweet molasses.  The  alcohol comes through in the smell.  Taste is sweet and spicy, with hints of berries (maybe blueberry). and very well-balanced.  Goes down very smooth, with a subtly spicy aftertaste.

bottle at Gallows Bird Espoo June
Color:dark reddish transparent bit head
Scent:sweet dark malts
Taste:fizzy, at first dark malts full bodied, sweetshortish aftertaste. Tasted many times perhaps 10 years ago first time still favorite
lovely beer, definitely will seek this one out. smells wonderful and one youll remember, but at $5 a bottle, not something Id buy all the time.

Bottle. Pours deep brown with no head. Aroma is dark, sweet malt with an herbal quality i cant put my finger on, probably the coriander. Taste is big dark, sweet roasted malt, with a hint of coriander on the finish. Theres a soft underlying carbonation there that is belied by the complete lack of head. I can imagine this beer being perfect for a nicely charred, medium rare steak. beautiful.

Bottle best before June 2014. Pours a dark brown, kind of cola colored, with not much of a head at all. The aroma is sweet up front with not much spice to speak of. I do detect low levels of coriander, but it seems more like something that would be imparted from yeast rather than the actual seed. I found this one to be a bit sweeter than I would like an old ale, but it does have tasty hints of tobacco and pork. Hints at mead, dates, and figs are also present. This is a very drinkable beer but at quite a high price for what it is. Id easily rather have a HoD Adam at this cost.

Pours brown, slightly hazy, with a medium tan head.  Nose is spicy coriander, dates, molasses.  Flavor is more of the same, with some cooked cherries and roasted malt flavors.  I felt the mouthfeel was slightly sticky.  Quite sweet.  No hops character present.  Very good.

Thanks to Capones in PA for introducing this one to me.

One of the more unique brews Ive had in a long time.  Opened the bottle and gave it a sniff and was blown away by strong spices (coriander).  Forced my mind to expect a lighter spring ale type of beer.  Imagine my surprise then, when I poured it and saw a deep caramel brew with a thick white/off-white head.  Gorgeous.  And shocking!

Flavor was consistent with the aroma.  Strong spiciness, complemented with sweet malt and some other smooth flavors - brown sugar and/or molasses perhaps?  Delicious.  Smooth finish.  Highly recommended.

From the bottle, pours deep brown with a two finger off white head. Nose is very nice and complex, with spice and malt. The coriander stands out in both aroma and flavor. There is also caramel and molasses in the flavor, which is very smooth. The mouthfeel is lively, yet creamy. Interesting and excellent ale.

Pours cola brown with tan head. Aroma of malts and some spices. Roasted malt flavor with corriander and slightly sweet. Alcohol comes through a little, but doesnt take away from the flavor. Medium to full body with mild carbonation and a smooth creamy mouthfeel. An interesting brew, definately worth a try.

Dark brown with mahogeny tinge.  Moderate head that dissappears really quick.  Malty brown sugar aroma.  Muted flavors.  Brown sugar, dark fruit and nuttiness with slight earthy/herbalness and spice.  No hops to speak of or write about. Mildly roasted with a slight peat/wood tinge.  A little alcohol in the finish.  I wanted to like this more; so Im going to have to try this again.
Bottle. Dark amber coloiur with a medium beige head. Aroma and taste of roasted malts, fruit, spice and smoke. Nice palate.

Bottled. a dark amber beer with a beige head. Aroma is very malty and sweety, notes of brown sugar, some smoke. Taste is very malty and spicy. Roasted notes and caramel. Very nice mouthfeel, full body. Very good beer.

Bottle from Utobeer. Dark chestnut in colour with a short lived tan head. Big malt aroma with plenty of dark fruit, molasses and spice. Mouth feel was vinous, almost oily. Flavours of caramel, a slight smoky woodiness, coriander, nutmeg, cinnamon  and liquorice. Finish was slightly dry with some nuttiness and warming alcohol. Beautifully balanced.
Sample at Aarhus beerfestival. Nice head with good duration. Color is dark brown. Aroma and taste are roast malt, oak, caramel with a balanced amount of alcohol.
Bottle at Aarhus Beer festival: Pours dark brown with a creamy off white head. Aroma is dark fruits & caramel malts & bread. Lovely smooth mouthfeel. Round & full! Warmh from alcohol! Just super!

Bottle. Deep brown with red tint. Lovely aromatic bouquet: musk, dandelion, wildflowers galore, witchs herbs, and a thick slab of Black Forest cake hold the icing--all black cherries and chocolate and no fluff. Nice. Also, nose and mouth offer up Viennese pastry. Mouthfeel is thin in this bottle--too bad! Flavors are round, smooth. Sweet-tart, bold yet understated. More black forest cake and Viennese pastry. Loads of homemade mincemeat!! made with raisin, dates, allspice, walnut, cola, sasparilla, and nutmeg. Totally pleasant, fulfilling brew. Yum!
Pours very dark, verly light brown head. Smells of licorice and soil. You can really taste the coriander. Wonderful beer.

Bottle. Creamy off-white good mostly deminishing head. Dark brown amber colour. Powerfull speicey aroma with cinamon notes leading. Moderate bitter flavor, spicey prune notes. Long nice finish. Creamy palate. Excellent brew.

Pours a rather shallow head that disappears abruptly leaving a partial canopy and a thin ring. Strong aromas of cocoa, pecans, roasted coffee, mild soy sauce,  beautiful!. Medium nectar with good carbonation for an average mouthfeel. Splendid flavor aroma follow through. Tastes just like it smells. The roasted coffee and cocoa  steal the show while this nutty character of pecans sprawls out. The coriander adds a mild spice definition. It an interesting combo. The finish really hangs in there with strong coffee/cocoaness. For as light in body this brew is it sure is rich. I couldnt drink more than 9. Killer brew!

Pours a dark brow almost porter color. The smell is great with coriander, dark fruits, roasted malts, and licorice. Licorice corriander cherry and roasted malt are the more dominant flavors. Carbonation is very light and has a slick finish. This is a very drinkable beer.

330ml bottle. pours just like coca-cola, an opaque brown with a thin fizzy tan head that quickly recedes into a collection of bubbles. nose is apricot and berries. taste is floral with some of the aforementioned apricot and a touch of malt sweetness. some chocolate emerges mid-glass. finishes pretty dry with the floral characteristic remaining behind. it is definitely interesting but not my style.

Dark ruby with a bubbly lasting tan head. Deep malt aroma, with dried fruit, some port and unknown herbs. A dry, fruity malt flavour, notes of licorice, and some alcohol showing. Big mouthfeel and warming alcohol.

Poured an opaque ebony brown with a thin, fizzy carpet of foam that disappeared leaving a flat brown slick. The nose was nutty and malty with a strong, rich, burnt cocoa aroma. The flavor starts with thick molasses like malts, biscuit and chocolate. Then a strong coriander spiciness comes forward and remains until the finish. The feel was full and robust. Im not a huge fan of Scotch and Spiced Ales. However this does have some intriging qualities. Its full-on, in your face style is appaeling. I would recomed giving it a shot.

12oz bottle from Knightly Spirits. Pours a dark red almost black, awesome looking in the glass with a small beige head. Nose is caramel, chocolate and anise. No smoke which is a bit suprising. Wow, what a unique tasting beer. This is definitely a maltheads beer. Cinnamon and anise up front that give way to carmel and chocolate malts. Almost no bitterness aside from a light hop bite that is gone almost immediately. Moderate palate but considering the abv this is a really easy drinking beer. Absolutely unique and incredibly good. Another stellar offering from this fine brewery.

Dark brown pour with moderate head and lacing.  Good strong spicey aroma.  The flavor in this was really strong spices, moderate doppelbock like earthy malts and strong yeastiness.  The beer had a decent carbonation level.  This was ok, but just wasnt totally doing it for me.

Dark cherry brown with thin head. Aroma is mostly corriander and fruit. Taste is a wonder of complexity. Corriander, pepper, malty sweetness and toasted malt. Very dry, slightly bitter finish. Love it.

Quite dark brownish red pour with large big-bubbly head.  Malt, licorice, coriander, roasty notes are all quite present.  This is a sipping ale, especially considering the price.  Quite complex.  One of my favorite labels, too.
Dark brown and not fizzy, tastes mostly like coffee. There is an underlying richness to it, its velvety somewhat. It was fairly good but I was disappointed. Very high price.

33 cL bottle. Pours dark brown with a deep redish hue and diminished light tan head. Plum fruity aroma. Mild malt, caramel and minor liqourice note too. Flavour is roasted malt with chocolate smoothness and bitterness. Light bitter and liqourice like bite following. Growing overripe fruity plum notes which gives reminiscence of Belgian trappist brews like Westmalle, Rochefort and a bit of St Sixtus. Dry yeasty spiced finish with a lingering fruit note. Nice one.

Bottle from Bitter Virtue.  Darkish ruby colour.
Liquorice edge to the roasted malts slightly sweet with musty earthy
undertones which add a slightly aged vinous feel to the beer.  This is
quite subtly flavoured with different mouthfeels revealing new woody and
fruity flavours. Not overly sweet and with nicely integrated layers of
flavour.  Much better than the others Ive tasted.

Pours with a light brown, creamy, head, good lacing. Clear dark brown body. Aroma of coriander, curacao liqueur, tangarines, and some malts. Taste is of very refreshing bitter citrus. Ultra creamy mouthfeel with delicate carbonation. Great stuff.

Pours dark caramel with a reddish tinge.  Minimal heads that fades quickly to a ring. Aroma of cherries, chocolate and caramel.  Sweet malts present right up front, folloiwing throuch a whiskey taste to a finish of cherries and warming alcohol with slight bitterness.  Very tasty ale.

Bottle - A much darker color than I imagined.  Pours a dark brown with reddish tint.  Tan head that did go away quickly.  Very complex nose of raisen, malt, nuts and molasses.  Very complex flavor with spice, pepper, alcohol and a coffee like bitter finish.  Very warming and delicious.
Sweet caramel nose.  Nice malty body with plenty of coriander.  Brown color with faint head.

Bottle pours a deep dark brown, with a  vanishing off white head. Rich aroma with notes of coffee, chocolate , grape, mollasess. Smooth and full bodied , packs a big heavy, and complex taste. The spiciness entwined with the alcohol is lingering and very warmly satisfying.
Lovely to sip indoors with the snow falling outside as it is now.  Top notch jock brew.

33cl bottle at home. This dark ruby beauty has to be aproached gently, because she does have a kick. mainly a spicy, cinnamon one, with hints of orange and coffee. you can actually feel it down your throat. yumm.

Pours a dark nut brown color with a small white head.  Aroma is of roasted coffee malt with caramel and spice.  Flavor is absolutely delicious with notes of roasted malt, coffee, chocolate, caramel, spice (coriander), alcohol, and slightly bitter.  A little thin on the mouthfeel.

12 oz. bottle.

Pours a ruddy brown with almost non-existent tan head but persistent if spotty lacing.  Nose is dominated by coriander, with a sweet-lemon-pepper quality, along with rum-soaked raisins.  Brown sugar malts show up quickly on the somewhat thin palate, before plummy fruits and lemongrass zest towards a sweet syrup finish. An intriguing and uncategorizable beer.

Bottled. Pours clear dark brown with beige bubbles and minimal head / lacing. Aroma of cinnamon and toffee, with some raisin, maple wood and plum. A slight metallic taint on the aroma keeps it from being above-average. Coriander is mostly apparent in the flavor, mixed in with peppery roasted malts, more toffee and a touch of ginger. Like a big spicy Scottish ale thats been toned down a notch. Fairly thin mouth feel, but it makes for easy drinking if youre in the mood for this style of beer. Pretty good.
The best beer brewed with coriander that I have ever tried.  I really wish it was cheaper though.  Its spiced, but the spice is not the focus at all.  The beer is the focus.

Pours dark burgundy with a fully receding tan head. Aroma of raisins, plums, toffee, rum. Tastes of raisin, dark bread, coriander, pepper, delicate phenols, and dark fruits. Mouthfeel is full bodied with lush carbonation. Very elegant and delicious beer.

Pours dark brown with reddish highlights and a short tan head that quickly turns into a ring of bubbles.  Prunes, sugar, molasses, and coriander in the nose.  Earthy malt with the same dark fruits, spice, and caramel dominate the taste.  Hints of butterscotch, pepper, cinnamon, and herbs.  Very different beer, almost like an aperitif.

pours dark chocolate with a light tan head. aroma is sweet, spicy, malty.  the flavor isthick and malty, with pepery spices floating around.  the palate is thick and yeasty.  teh spice does not detract from the scottish ale-ness.  this is not a favorite style of mine.

Bottle from Magnum, swindon, UK. Now this is interesting. the aroma made me go "oh...?" Coriander seed is added im sure of that and maybe nutmeg but not sure. the spice sits on top of the huge earthy, musty damp smell. brown sugar and alcohol also. quite belgian. tight, slightly sweet flavour lingers with the spice.

330ml botlle acquired from Coldbrewky.  Pours a hazy brown with tan head. Lazy rings of lace coat my glass. Carbonation is moderate leading to a lively mouthfeel. Nose is dark fruits & sugary candy. Butterscotch lifesavers maybe. Flavors is  sweet and sugary. Cinnamon cookie? Also tastes of raisin & dates. At 8% the alcohol is well hidden. An interesting tasty brew.

Poured from a 330ml bottle and served in a shaker.  This beer poured a dark brown with a few mahogany highlights and a one-finger thick head of tan foam that settled down to a thin layer that lasted throughout most of the glass.  Some nice looking lacing was left behind.  The aroma of the beer was made up of stong coriander, dates, raisins, sweet caramel, and brown sugar.  Sweet and spicy!  The flavor consisted of coriander, a strong, earthy, herbal note, dried fruits, mild citrus, chocolate, caramelized sugar, cinnamon, and a touch of alcohol.  The mouthfeel was full-bodied with moderate carbonation.  A very interesting beer.  Maybe a touch sweet, but not cloying.  Really, really tasty!!!

UPDATED: MAR 7, 2010 Clear dark brown body with a tiny beige head, quickly fades. Freshly ground coriander dominates the nose with some rye bread, toffee and dark fruits. The flavor is raisins, prunes, coriander, grainy bread and toffee. Medium/full body is round with light carbonation.

330ml Bottle:  Sweet aroma.  Smells of sweet malts, floral hops, fruits, grapes, berries, raisins, and a hint of smoke.  Poured dark brown/ruby in color with a medium-sized, light brown head that diminished quickly.  Clear.  Sparkling.  No lacing.  Flavor is vinous.  Tastes of grapes, berries, alcohol, light malts, raisins, and plastic.  Light to medium body.  Sticky texture.  Soft carbonation.  Chalky alcohol finish.  Alcohol burn; boo.

UPDATED: JUL 15, 2008 Nirvana in a bottle.  While Scottish, this brew is, in no way, representative of most Scottish ales.
Somewhat like its sister (Traquair House Ale), but a bit darker, a bit more flavor and a bit more alcohol.  While this brew uses almost the same ingredients, its just more "grown up"...  more depth... colorwise, aromawise, and flavorwise.  The Traquair brewmaster shows off his skill in the surprising use of coriander... whereas most people immediately link spices such as coriander with Belgian brews, he deftly uses it in this brew... just enough... barely there flavorwise... it seems as though hes using it more for its ability to lighten things up... metamorphosing a beer that most people would expect to be heavy into a surprisingly light and easy to drink ale.
Next time I go to Scotland Im definately giving a visit to the Traquair House.
Ultra expensive in America (if youre lucky enough to find it)... but, well worth it.
Smelled sweet, like a bourban. Color is a dark brown, not much of a head. No lacing. Malt is the main flavor.  Also some brown sugar. A little watery to be honest. Over all a good beer.

Bottle @ Craig´s, november 07. Strong, perfumey, coriander aroma with spicy notes. Sweet, coriander, citric flavor with some rummy notes. Medium mouthfeel, some flowery/ spicy notes plus some caramel touches with a well rounded finish. Clear, beatifull ruby color with some orange hues and a white rim around the beer. Nice, dark trippel-like ale.

Sampled at Cellars WIne & Spirits weekly beer tasting in St Paul, MN. Pours a clear dark cola brown brew with a fast dissolving beige head that dissipates to a fine film ring. Aroma of roasted dark malt, some tropical fruit, brown sugar, and coriander. Taste is medium bodied, with roasted malt, coriander, and brown sugar flavors. Finish is semi-sweet, with a herbal spice and chocolate aftertaste. Good balance of alcohol and flavor.

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2008 Dark brown with thin brown head. Spicy roasted malts are the first thing to strike you before the smell warms you with the aroma of alcohol. Very low carbonation and smooth mouth feel. Almost a molasses rum kind of taste. A very long lasting spicy taste. Also in the taste are bread, choc. and roasted malts. Quite unusual.

Bottle, pours dark brown... aroma is a malty chocolaty mix.  Some hops on the back end, but mostly this is a creamy, sweet beer, that doesnt come across TOO sweet.  Chocolaty flavors throughout, with very little roasty flavor I can tell... a true mix-up of a beer that works wonders.

Best before June 2014.  Pours a dark rootbeer brown, though not toooo dark.  With a decent offwhite head.  Rather fruity!  A bit of that Orval-like sweet tropical fruit thing.  A good dose of darker malt, though, not roast.  Some lemon, coriander and maybe a hint of wheat.  Rather sweet, but not overwhelming.  Quite a complex nose, I must say.  a smoth creamy body with a bit of that diacetyl butteriness.  Rather sweet, but even more so its very fruity.  A good dose of toast.  A shot of that coriander spice.  I still think this resembles Orval in terms of the yeasty sorts of flavors.  I have to believe there is brett in here.  A hint of caramelly chocolate.  Some alcohol, for sure.  This beer is such a hodgepodge, I cant believe it actually mostly works.  I may grab a bottle to sit on for a while, this could open up nicely.

Pours dark brown almost opaque and bubbles thick like a stout. The head has big bubbles and is tan in color. It settles down to 1 inch and lasts. The aroma is very strong of brown sugar malt. The aroma also reeks a bit of alcohol. The flavor is complex and very strong of malt, yeast, and corriander. It has a thick mouthfeel and is a meal of a beer. Very, very sweet beer, like a pop.

Dark brown with a loose head. The aroma has notes of yeast, malt and port wine. The flavour is full, round and complex. It has notes of roasted malt, fruit, caramel and weak hints of spice and licorice. An exciting and very tasty beer.

11.2 oz bottle pours a dark mahogany with a small khaki head. Aroma of smoky peat, toffee, and coriander. Medium body supports earthy flavors, some anise, smoke, and dark fruits. Lots of spicy and earthy hop bitteress. Very interesting.

12 oz bottle, via magic_dave6.  Pours a clear mahogany brown body with a small fizzy beige head that faded quickly to a thin ring.  The nose is sweet and fruity with lots of yeast derived esters.  Some spices, vanilla, light alcohol, and chocolate notes.  Very vinous overall.  The flavor has a nice balance between the sweet malt and the spicing, keeping it from being too cloying.  Lots of banana and dark fruit on the finish before the lingering herbal notes come on.  Mouthfeel is full bodied and slightly thick, but not syrupy.  Moderately fine fizzy carbonation, and quite mouthcoating.  Overall, this is always a nice beer, but I wish that it werent filtered so heavily.

12 oz. bottle poured into my trusty stein- poured transparent slightly hazy very dark red brown (to the point where it was almost black), tiny white whisps floating around for a head, aroma of toffee, roasted malts, and earthy spices.  Hits the mouth with a well defined medium body, that malt along with the coriander are more pronounced, finish of darkened molasses.  Makes the mouth sticky after a few sips.  Good.
cream soda, toffee, spices, malt faint hopiness. Pours deep copper colour beer with a small firm head. Thick, sticky mouthfeel,  malty, wheaty, dates. Molasses. A really nice beer.
Very dark pour with a small head. Flavor is complex and changing. Spices, fruits, malts, sweets, and earth tones all come forth. Could be a little smoother.

UPDATED: FEB 14, 2008 Bottle. Pours a dark red that borders on black with a tiny head. The aroma is mostly spices, some dark fruits and old dusty tomes (David Hume perhaps). The taste is somewhat smooth but stands out as original; coriander, raisins, some smoke off a peat burning fire, malts and some alcohol. Nice. Sort of hard to judge due to complexity. Overall, just great.

Pours a dark brown with a mahogany tint and a small bubbly beige head.  Aroma of tea, coriander, dark fruit and smoked meat.    Taste of dark fruit soaked in coriander with hints of smoked beef jerky and tea.  Quite an interesting brew.
This ia a wonderful beer. Its delightfully complex. This beer is by far one of the most professionally done brews around.

Unlike any ale from Scotland that I have ever tried. Scotish ales tend to have a slight bitterness under the flavor...but this ale is very unique. Very crisp aroma....sort of a fresh spiciness (slighty floral, or maybe earthy is a better term) with tones of corriander, malt and another spice that is very similar to Grains of Paradise. The flavor is just as complex....a plethora  of spices, particularly corriander (of course, since they brew with it!) as well as allspice, maybe a hint of something like Grains of Paradise. Also a nice malty backbone, not too roasted, but not too sweet...it complements the spiciness very well. A very unique beer that is worth at least one try.
Pours a murcky medium brown with a thin layer of foam. Aroma of spices, coriander, and caramel. Complex flavor, alcohol is hidden fairly well.

Bottle (purchased at the brasserie): Clear, deep amber colored, smaller tanned foamy head, sweet dark and toasted malt in the nose, underpinned by coriander; solid sweetish flavour, quite full bodied, soft creamy MF; strong malty finish with heavy influences of coriander. Good, spicy and well balanced brew..........
Hazy brown with winy head. Sweet spicy aroma with notes of chocolate, cinnamon, caramel and toffee. Complex flavor with sweet roasted malt, spices, chocolate and corriander. Lovely!
Dark brown ale with a small tan head; rich malt/toffee aroma; flavor is molasses and malt.  Good ale.

330 ml bottle. Very dark reddish body with a small beige head. Aroma is very complex, sweet malt, liquorices, spices and raw alcohol. Flavor is also complex, malt, liquorices, caramel, vanilla and spices. Not very different to a trappist beer.

Bottle. Great beer. Very nice. Dark brown with small palebrown head. Aroma beginning with floral and grassy hop notes, licorice afterwards and roasted malts.
Taste licorice and malt, uhmm nice. Wauw this is a great beer.
Pours very very dark, opaque, nearly black.  Almost no head in this bottle, and very little carbonation.  Very faint aroma of maple syrup.  Marvelous, rich flavor which is very delicious yet refined.

Pours deep mahogany brown, almost black, but with some very nice red tones. Head is about 1/2 inch of very dense tan bubbles. Aroma is dark roasted malt with hints of chocolate, backed by some coriander, and hints of licorice. Mouthfeel is rich and oily. Flavor is big malty, with more licorice and a subtle coriander. Tail is all roast malt and licorice. Really nice spiced Wee Heavy.

UPDATED: MAR 8, 2010 [Bottle 12.31.07] 9 / 4 / 9 / 5 / 19
Dark brown pour, not a lot of bubbles, medium tan creamy head.  Very sweet aroma of malt, savory smoke, flowers, pepper and coriander.  Completely unique flavor.   Delicious licorice/toasted malt flavors with lots of spice on top.   Not annoyingly spiced like a lot of winter ales, but rather in perfect combination with the malts.  Cinnamon and brown sugar in there too.  Also gives the impression of wood aging, although I dont know if it is?  Not a sipping beer for me... gulping this down...very drinkable the palate is full bodied but light drinking...perfect . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 


[Rerate 9/30/08]  9 / 4 / 9 / 4 / 18  Pours a thin but dark and murky brown/black with a very small head.  Aroma is very sweet fruity and floral with lots of licorice.  First taste is straight  black licorice, followed by extra-dry woody malt, finishing with bitter and spicy coriander/licorice.   Some pepper and a bit vinous, a bit of soy and what seems like black malt.  Smooth lightly carbonation medium body, slightly creamy but very flat in the mouth.   Definitely one of the most unique beers in the world!  . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . [2009 bottle rated 3.8.10] Pours a somewhat hazy dark tea color with a thin bubbly light tan froth.  Aroma is very fragrant, strong coriander and floral notes, some dark molasses,  maybe anise, dark fruit, nice as it warms, the alcohol helps give it a great edge, some robust caramelization.  Flavor is much the same, strong coriander, anise, dark fruit, plum, lots of plum, tannic bitterness, soft brown sugar, a bit floral. Floral pumpernickel aftertaste, tannic chalky bitterness.  Medium bodied, chalky sugary, easy drinking, a touch milky, soft carbonation.  8.4.8.4.17
murky, dark, golden brown pour with some lacings on top.  sweet malt scent along with some fruit.  interesting roasted malt taste with a nice finish of coriander

Im wondering if I got a bad bottle of this, because there is NO way this beer can be rated this high. Aroma was huge and delicious. Sour raisins in a potent flower garden is the best way to describe this. Pour was a dirty dark brown with a thin off white ring for a head. The taste was very complex but weak. No carbonation. Raisin, strong spiciness and almost a scotch aftertaste. The flavor is gone as soon as you swallow. No alcohol detectable while cold, but the burn comes out as it warms. Interesting.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: The scotch know a lot about barley malt. Traquair Jacobite is exhibit A.  Rich, dark, somewhat sweet, filled with ripe raisin aroma! Truly a elicious and hearty brew. Toast one with some friends!!

330 ml bottle.  Pours a dark brown with very thin white head which disappeared except for around the edge.  The remaining head produced some lacing.  The aroma was sweet malt with a hint of alcohol.  Flavor was sweet malt, spices, raisins and a little alcohol.  Alcohol was not detrimental to the flavor or mouthfeel.  Mouthfeel was medium and a little sticky.  Pleasant drink.  Very nice malty brew.

Almost black with a fast disappearing head. Very peculiar nose, a mix of flowery notes and mild spices gives this beer a really original bouquet, mingling with a good mix of roast and caramel malts. Its little more than watery, so its very drinkable.

12 oz bottle poured dark brown with a small white head that qiucky disapates Aromas of berries and fruit, malts and chocolate . Medium mouthfeel almost no carbonation flavors of spices and sweet malts with nice finish to it. A very interesting ale . will drink it again  .
Bottle from Valley Farms Market. Pours a dark ruby/brownish color. Aroma of dark fruit. Some raisin and a little vermouth. Light carbonation. Somewhat vinous and a little sweet. Some roasted malts.

(33 cl bottle at Haket, Göteborg)
Very dark brown color, small tan head.
Smooth chocolate scent.
Raissin, sweet and vinous taste.
Tart aftertaste, also smoke. 
Smoothmouthfeel, medium bitterness.
Purchased on December 12, 2007.
8/3/8/4/16=3.9

Pours a nice head that dissapates right away and leaves a strong lacing with a thin layer of head that later dissapears with the lacing leaving nothing. Its scent is very light and a little sweet. Smells lightly of a fruity complex that is coupled with a slightly bitter, but more mellow hoppy flavor. Its a bit nutty, and it goes well with mellow hops and fruityness. I noticed at the end of this beer theres a slight coffee undertone that finishes nicely.

12oz bottle from Rons in Farmington. Translucent brown-copper body with virtually no off-white head that dissipates quickly. Fruit/berries seem to dominate the aroma, with chocolate and caramel malts playing a big roll too. Tastes fruity too, prodominantly, with a roasty chocolate/caramel malt presence and some peatiness present too. Medium bodied with only a moderate amount of carbonation help to make this a pretty drinkable wee-heavy. Definitely unique, and unlike any other example of the style Ive encountered. Very good - definitely picking this one up again if I can find it.

Bottle:  Pours a deeper brown with a tannish head.  Nose is of grape lolly pops candi sugar.  I dont sense any corriander maybe some nutmeg and orange peel.  Cardamom on the fringe.  Slim rings of lace.  After sugary introduction the medium maltiness is dicernable.  A smooth mellow finish.

Pours dark brown with no head. This beer has coriander written all over it. The aroma the flavor all say coriander. There is some malt in there to help balance the spice but not a whole lot. Body is full, alcohol is unapparent. Im glad I tried it because it is so different... but I wouldnt order it again.

Bottled. An unclear dark brown beer with a very nice small brown head. Very interesting nose with coriander, chocolate and other spices. The flavour is malty and spicy with notes of coriander and chocolate again plus some molasses and roasted malt. Medium body, average carbonation, medium bitterness in a finish thats quite long. The alcohol is well hidden, so this beer is very complex and flavourful and yet drinkable. Unusual British beer (but maybe unusual in general), some flavours remember a Belgian beer. I want another one.

Bottle. Poured a very dark ruby brown color with a half finger of head. Smells as interesting as it tastes. Very malty, sweet smell, powerful hints of corriander. Unlike anything Ive ever had. Ive had this before but didnt like it as much as I did this last time. Very interesting flavors when paired with pepperjack cheese and crackers.

Wow this one was differet. Pours a dark almost black color with a tan small bubbly head that dissapates quickly. Smells of boysenberries and malt. Tastes like boysenberries and some spices and a dash of chocolate. A very refreshing and different beer.
Heavy malty aroma. Large frothy, light brown head. Good lacing. Clear amber body. Heavy sweet flavor. Medium palate.

A delicious ale, but not at all what I expected. Far sweeter and delicate than most Scottish beers Ive had. Pours with a nice, but quickly diminishing head, not much lace. Strongly spicy aroma, reminds me of (dare I say) pizza. Flavors of liquorice, faint chocolate, honey and lots of spices, the coriander is very strong. Not much alcohol flavor. Mouthfeel is delicate and very pleasant, recommended.

10/24/07 From the bottle.  Aroma is sweet and perfumy, with a complex mix of honey, malt, ginger and coriander.  Excellent.  Flavor is very malty, with a roast/toast character forward, with a nice coriander blend, low bittering, and a slightly peaty finish.  Mouthfeel is medium/high bodied with a medium carb feel.  Overall, a very cool beer that quite easy drinking for being so rich, with a great blending of flavors.

Bouteille de 330 ml obtenue via Importations Privées Bièropholie. Arôme: Odeur de mélasse, dépices et de petits fruits foncés. Apparence: La couleur est brune opaque avec une faible densité de bulle. Présence dun mince col beige mousseux et dune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de caramel foncé et dépices avec une pointe de malt. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement vineuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Arrière goût légèrement chocolaté. (Rating #1330)

26/10 0.33 l bottle at Tolkiens House...served with a trappist glass, but fine... Poured dark brown body with medium brownish head. Wonderful aroma with caramel, chocolate, forest fruits, surely some other things...yeap this is a real 10. Flavor doesnt stand a lot besides, too, fantastic, quite complex as well with more or less same things as in aroma, specially chocolate is felt. Full bodied, but is goes down pretty smoothly. Alcohol is felt but not much. Great finish, with some pleasant coffee dominating this time. Interesting. Really, an exquisite beer, great surprise and surely Ill have it again as soon I get the chance!

Bottle, Pint glass, Aroma is pure malty goodness, pours a nice deep mahgony red color, with a thin brown head. Rich chocolate and mild coffee roasts dominate the palate. Liqorice, sweet malts that finish dry. Corriander is slight and well desirved. Palate is just a touch lighter than I expected. Good, very good, A touch of hops but nothing massive, just delicious malts, that very from strong roast but only in light amounts, to raisins, plums, cherries, in greater volumes. A bit of old world breadiness. Quite nice.

Nice clear blood red ale with an alright head. It has a nice clean and light fragrance, but the beer.......not so much. The ear wax-like bitterness just hits so fast and dies so slow it really don’t give you time to explore the other flavors. To bad, I think this could have been a great beer.
Bottle. Semi clear dark brown in colour with a medium sized tan head. Malty and a bit sweet with notes of ryebread, dried berries, chocolate and spices. Very well balanced.
Bottle at Bager (Herre-frokost). Clear dark brown - offwhite head. Ryebread, licorice, berries, sweetness, chokolate, high malty.Ok Nice.
Deep, dark reddish amber color. Coriander nose with roasted malts and some spice. Taste is light and nicely balanced, although the body is a bit thin. Not bad.

$4.99 bottle from Tip Top.  Best before June 2014.  No yeast sediment.  No head, but small bubbles climb the sides of the glass and disappear on the surface.  Deep dark amber red color, nearly black.  Light aroma of some corriander and malt.  Maybe the lightest amount of cardboard, but its hard to tell.  Flavor is kind of light (watery).  Alchohol is well hidden (unless you search for it).  Leans dry. Maybe the smallest hint of sourness, but basically flavorless.  Maybe this bottle is past its prime. I wouldnt doubt it is from 2004, making it 3 yrs old.  Not very tasty.

12 ounce bottle from SS summer 2007
Pour dark brown with some ruby highlights.  No real head except for a ring around the edges.
The corriander really dominates this beer.  I get a smidge of roasted character.  But most of the character is herbal citrus.  I even get the leaves of cilantro.
It also seems fairly watery.  Medium carbonation.  Dry finish.
Certainly one of the more interesting beers Ive ever tried.

Pours dark brown with a little bit of ruby when held up to the light, but I still cant see through it by any means. Small, yellowish-white head that fades leaving a nice ring of lace. The aroma is like nothing I have ever smelled.  Begins with some dark malts, a little molasses and spices, but quickly moves to something almost salty that makes me think of pizza dough for some strange reason.. As I take the first sip, the saltiness is all gone and the full on malt attack begins. The malts are very nice here--not too sweet and they are balanced very nicely with the coriander and hops. Alcohol is all but hidden in the flavor. This is a very nice, unique, and interesting beer.  Glad I finally gave it a try. Thanks for the bringing it up Ryan and Paul!
Dark black body with a medium frothy tan head that quickly diminishes. Huge coriander aroma with a lot of spice. Huge syrupy molassas flavor with tons of coriander and spice.
Bottle. Pours dark brown/red. Small / minimal beige head which disappears rather quickly. Chocolate / spice / caramel aroma. Has a fairly full body with long lasting fruity finish.

Bottle. Very dark reddy brown, tight thin beige head. Rich rum-raisin chocolate aroma. Sweet spice - coriander - above a very rich and mellow malty backdrop. Smooth creamy texture. Other christmassy hints - nutmeg, and dried peel. Some really dark richly roasted burnt tastes also come through. No way is this 8%. Impossible to suggest any modifications to improve the taste!

Pours a dark brown with a small, light brown head.  You really can smell that big coriander spice mixed in with syrupy malts and molasses.  The taste is very spicy, very malty, with a little kick to the finish.  The alcohol comes through in the end and leaves a little heat on the palate.  The malts leave a slight bitterness in the finish, but relatively smooth going down.  Quite a different beer.  Not sure I liked it a whole lot, but certainly didnt dislike it.

Medium beige head. Deep dark red body. Sugary spicy peppery licorice aroma with chocolatey notes. Slightly earthy and stale. Deep sweet milky licorice and chocolate taste with toffeeish notes. Mild, smooth, and clean mouthfeel. No aftertaste; just fades out. Some alcohol heat, but no alcohol taste. Lingering papery caramelly taste. Excellent, a really good beer. (0.33l bottle from gr0ve.)

Aromas dominated by caramel, almost candy like, with a coffee, roasty and herbs touch.
Pours black, but is rather clear and sparkling. The head is minimal ans short lived. Looks like cola...
The flavor is definitively sweet, maby a bit too sweet, but a bitter aftertaste counterbalance it in the end.
It has a full body, with a very creamy texture, almost aerial like whipping cream, oily. The carbonation is fizzy with a long finish.
The flavor is intense, which is good, however a few things counterbalances it so it is not as easy to drink as I expected.
Its like a very chic piece of clothing that you cant wear without an occasion.
very dark, deliecious fruity flavour, wonderful corriander aftertaste. Head disappears quickly.

UPDATED: JUN 18, 2015 Nov 04 2007 Bottle at home ... deep brown/red , sweet fruityness little raspberry, very sweet fruity nice character and depth 4.1 bottle at home Dec 10 ... dark copper brown ... thin tight tan head ... very fruity ... hints of raspberry ...soft sweet toffee ... really nice nose ...deep sweet fruits ... increadibly fruity ... again hints of raspberry ... light toffee roast ... light carbionation ... nice soft body ... alcohol is well hidden ... and while sweet its mostly fruity  but can get a little wearing in the end 4.0

bottle at home ... June 2015 .. bbf 2016 (think 8-9 year old) ...deep brown ... thin tan head ... soft licorice raspberry ... deep fruit nose ... juicy roast ... soft malts .. big berries ... soft sweet blackcurrant licorice fruits ... soft malts ... wow 4.2

Date: 10/01/1998
Mode: Bottle
Source: Ale Atlanta

strong floral aroma, very unusual malt flavor
-------- />
Date: 06/01/2005

dark brown, whispy head, sweet complex buttery toffee malt aroma with slightly smokey molasses and ripe fruits, rich malt flavor with lots of tartness, big bitter finish, great aroma with a mediocre flavor

Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 13/20
Rating: 3.2/5.0Score: **+/4
-------- />
The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

botte, 0.33.
Dark golden, brown foam.
Fantastic Aroma: Coriand, chocolate, caramel...Very Sweet..
 Little bitter in ther end.
Very good. The Best Uks beer I have drink.

33 cl bottle via trade with dankman38 - Pours a hazy brown color with a thin light tan head that faded quickly.  Aroma is full of dark esters.  Flavor is toasted malt and esters.  Fruit flavors linger on the palate.  Medium body.  A good beer.  Thanks Mike.
Bottle. Pretty nose: plums, dates, raisins, cherries, malt. Nice! Quite flavorful. Coriander, chocolate, cherries and malt on the palate. Finishes almost wine-like. Fairly full bodied.

Pours ruby-brown with a fizzy tan head that diminishes in an instant to an island of tiny bubbles and a ring around the edge of the glass. An enticing aroma hits you with dark fruits and deep roasted maltiness, anise, black cherries and spicy rum cake. Medium to full-bodied and slick with a dry bitter finish and a hint of alcohol warmth. Vinous and rich with notes of coriander, chocolate, black cherry, dry red wine, pepper and roasted malts, finishing quite dry and spicy. A very nice beer and one that lends itself well to experimentation with food pairings.

11.2oz Bottle
$2.99
Sams Downers Grove

Traquair Jacobite pours a clear garnet with glowing mahogany highlights when held directly to the light. One finger ecru head forms on the pour that falls to a skim coat rather quickly. Good looking brew.

This beer smells fantastic. Nothing at all like I thought it would smell. Jacobite has the usual aromas of roasted malts and a slight hint of chocolate. The big difference here is the coriander. It leaves an unbelievable refreshing orange aroma that makes this beer utterly unique.

Flavor is right along the lines of the aroma. Some toasted and roasted malts show themselves in the flavor. Theres a tremendous burst of flavor mid-palate from the generous amount of coriander used. Great refreshing orange and herbal character. Finishes with a solid dose of hops to balance things out.

This beer is about as easy drinking as you can find. The high abv is the only reason its not getting the highest rating possible. Very refreshing.

This beer just blows my mind. I expected nothing along these lines. The addition of coriander adds an amazing needed refreshing quality. This is a superb beer.

8/13/07
Very little head. Wonderful aroma largely due to the added coriander. Nice smooth taste. Not as much depth as I would like. Avery good drinkable beer.
Deep ruby amber almost mahogany hue with a little white head. Nose of caramel and subtle hops.  Notes of cantalope and cherries with a robust earthy finish.  Flavorful and quite refreshing!

UPDATED: AUG 18, 2007 Bottiglia da 33cl comprata da Squillari; ambrata molto scura con schiuma leggera ma persistente di colore beige. Aroma fruttato quasi marmellatoso, cioccolato; sapore molto simile allinizio con finale amarognolo che contrasta un poco con il dolce sul palato, con tocchi di caffè e zucchero bruciato. Grande birra per le giornate dinverno e per i temporali estivi,  un bicchiera a cui avvicinarsi con grande rispetto. Solo un poco stucchevole alla lunga.

UPDATED: AUG 5, 2007 Bottle -- Dark ruby-tinged black with a small beige head without much retention. The aroma is wonderful, almost too much to fit up my nose: over-ripe fruit, steamed pudding with caramel sauce, chocolate and some earthy roastedness. Vageuly oily medium to full palate with a little water as well. Flavour is so good: more over-ripe fruit, sweet earthy maltiness, chocolate and a little more roastedness. I loved it!
Bottle.  Prune-apple and strong coriander aroma.  Dark brown color with minimal head.  Apple, orange, and coriander flavor.  Fruity and spicy.

Nearly opaque dark brown with ruby highlights. Medium and lasting, deliciously creamy tan noggin on this one. Nose is spicy coriander and raisins in chocolate sauce. Flavor is similar, with less chocolate than raisin and coriander. Barely noticeable alcohol, and a delicate touch of bittering grassy herbs on the end. Palate is medium-bodied, smooth and just a little more watery than expected. Excellent dessert beer.
not too much for me a bit like christmas and a bit sweet. cool bottle maybe it would be better cold? I usually like the strong ones

Pours dark brown/black with almost no head.  Malty, and the coriander spice is featured and well integrated into the brew.  Lemony-citrus hints combine with rounded fruity notes, lightly toasted malts and chocolate to combine for a very interesting and complex brew, worth trying.
scura ampia gamma di profumi ed aromi miele pepe spezie legno molto complessa

330ml bottle. Pint glass. Mahogany with a tan head. Aroma of sweet malt and fruit especially blueberry. Flavor had notes of dark fruit and bourbon and a hint of smoke. Mouthfeel was a bit more thin than I expected. Just a touch of bitterness.

Poured a clear dark brown-amber with a thin loose head.  Spice and earth in the aroma with some malt characteristics.  Deep flavor profile with roasted malt, spice, earth, and herbal notes.  Lighter in the mouth but still huge and complex and a bit unwieldy which leaves the impression of imbalance.  The alcohol is well-masked, however.  Overall, quite an interesting beer but not for casual drinking.

Poured clear amber with weak off white head. The aroma just jumps out of the glass when poured. Smells like a load of coriander but it isnt too bright. That aroma seems to mix with a pronounced raisin note as well as lesser amounts of dark chocolate and something vaguely smoky. Interesting flavor with the smooth coriander, a bag full of raisins, dried plums, dark chocolate and hints of smoke. Certainly an interesting combination.

Bottle, courtesy of HogTownHarry. Poured a thick & somewhat dark. The nose is hit with toffee, caramel, coffee and brown sugar. The taste really takes after its aroma with the addition of molasses, minus the coffee. I enjoyed this beer quite somewhat. Though, pairing it with a sirloin burger is not recommended.
Rich, sweet toffee aroma.  Sweetness on the entry, but it finishes dry with spices.

Pours a very dark amber with a small light tan head that quickly fades. Aroma is of malt, coriander, spice. Flavor is malt, licorice, spice, and ripened fruits. Mouthfeel seemed just a tad thin but still overall very nice.

(Bottle BBE 05/2017) Pleasant aroma of roasted malt, caramel, alcohol, licorice and anise. Dark red brown colour and brownish, small head with a hint of lacing. Roasted malty, spicy (anise) and licorice flavour. Lively carbonated, oily, slightly alcoholic and medium to full-bodied palate. Tasty brew! 24/06/07

11.2oz bottle-pours a foamy tan head and dark mahogany color.  Aroma is medium malt-molasses, dark fruit-cherry.  Taste is medium malt-molasses, dark fruit-cherry, some acidity, anise, faint hops, coriander.  Medium body.  OK/mild carbonation.

330 ml bottle. Reddish dark with a small light brown head. Aroma has a lot of caramel in it blended with coffee. Roasted flavor with hints of caramel and some dark chocolate. Leaves a bit bitter finish but at the same time a very tasteful experience when you get used to the taste. I cant say that it stands out but is one of the better ales out there.

Bottle poured a clear deep dark brown with ruby highlights and a small lasting amber head leaving behind nice lacing as I drink the beer.Aromas of carmel, rum, dark fruit, coriander and some vanilla and cocoa notes. Palate was light bodied and smooth. Flavors of toffee, coriander, dark fruit, rum, light vanilla and a hint of milk chocolate with a smooth lingering spice finish.

Deep brown with a thin tan head.  Aroma is dark fruits, wine, cherries, caramel, and a litle alcohol.  Smooth mouth.  Flavor is very fun/unique.  Coriander, caramel, cherries, dark fruits, and some malt.  Finishes dry with a little biterness.  Not much else like it, very enjoyable.

Sampled in Glasgow, found at a speciality shop.  Couldnt ever find it in the US.  Had an excellent flavor, almost like a red ale, as traditional ales are not common in the US.  Definitely a slow sipping drink with excellent use of mild hops.

One of my favorite beers.  Period. 
A  deep profile of chocolate, caramel, coriander, and dark fruit- cherries.  
I am not saying this is the best beer out there by any means, but still one of my nostalgic favorites.

UPDATED: DEC 2, 2007 Pours a dark brown; minimal head.  Had a cola look to it.  Aroma definitely has some coriander; but quite different from other beers.  Some caramel malt as well; and maybe some fruit/earthiness.  Very good smell.  Very light on the palate with not much carbonation.  That fact, and the unique flavor, caught me a little off guard.  However, definitely warmed up to this beer.  Coriander, caramel malt, chocolate, fruit and cherries.  Very distinct and enjoyable.  Surprised that this is 8%.  My complaint is that the flavor could have been more assertive; but still this is quality.
Pours dark brown smells like corriander.  Lots of stuff going on here Caramel malty, corriander and a cherry finish.  This beer is simply amazing!!!!

bottled
