Brown with  minimal head. aroma  coriander, caramel malt, mustard.  Relatively full body, chocolate hints, caramel, and a massive coriander attack. Stunning beer

Rated 2/11/07:  Coffee colored pour, mild head that dwindled down leaving little lacing. Rich aroma with some smoked roasted malt and spicy coriander. Rich and filling mouthfeel, smooth finish with a very slight alcohol note. Very interesting flavor, addictive and intriquing. Burnt flavors with some notes of maple and black licorice. The coriander is very noticeable and boy does it work well in this ale. A mild smoke flavor is present as in the aroma. Nice bitterness to counter the spice. Alcohol is well hidden. Very enjoyable.

330 ml Bottle.  Purchased at Blue Max Liquors in Burnsville, MN.  Best before date is June 2011.  Based on the best by dates of recent reviews, I believe this one may be at least 5 years in age.  Pour is a murky brown and red with only a slight soapy head.  Aroma is very malty, quite strong.  I get a bit of earthiness in the nose as well.  Taste is real big, with a BIG malt presence, fruit (dates, raisins) and burnt sugar.  It has a very nice "booziness" to it.  Not that it has a bunch of alcohol in the taste, just that it has the texture and silkiness of some whiskys I have had.  A really nice finish on this one.  At the very end, detected some roast and smoke.  Complexity is revealed with the range of flavors in this as it warms.  Agree with previous reviews, not real sure if I could sense the coriander listed on the label.

UPDATED: MAR 4, 2009 Bottle. I tried feeling the coriander, and I didnt find it in the aroma. I even took some spices from the kitchen to be able to compare, and ginger and cardmon are quite noticable in this one. Dark colour, small disappearing head. Nice and foamy, silky on the palate. Taste sparklingly dry, but nothing that speciall really. Quite short finish, was expecting more.

Bottle at home. Wow. This is another excellent Scottish ale, very enjoyable. Black colour with tan foam. Strong, dark and spicy, with tastes of chocolate, caramel, coffee, toffee, raisins, honey and bread. Very malty with spicy finish.

Bottle picked up from Evesham farm shop, 28-05-07, best before date of May 2016. Poured very dark in colour with beige head, aromas were spicey, warming alcohol, and some burnt notes along with the taste I really thought that I was in Belgium what a stunner. The taste was smooth, retsrained but amazingly complex, dark fruits, burnt sugars, cherry, warming alcohol again, spices, great malts, wonderful smooth creaminess, what a beer, fantastic.

Dark mahogany murky body, long lasting head, not much lacing. Fruity and spicy aroma, cherries upfront, deep and malty with nice hops in the background. Some aniseed, some liqourice, some vanilla and caramel too. Malty taste, with liqourice, dark sugar, some cherry, and a strong yeastiness. Surprisingly light on the palate, with low carbonation. Quite good.

Well, well, well. This really is a cheeky little specimen. Inky pour with ruby tints and a halo of beige suds. Big, distinctly Belgian snout humming of liquorice, honey, coriander and strawberryish hops. Smooth, roasty, spicy and hoppy. Black pepper and vanilla. A complex beer skillfully juggling an array of flavours. Echoes of Barbar Dunkel and Tripel Karmeliet. Silkily honeyish and medicinal with a gently roasty, liquorice-accented finish. Some marmite yeastiness in the aftertaste. Not to mention a great big glug of spice. Lovely stuff.
Bottle. Red brown / black colour with a beige head. Aroma is licorice, burned, sweet, coffee, alcohol. Flavour is licorice, burned, sweet, coffee, alcohol, spices. Very nice beer.

11.2oz bottle, best before 6/2014. thanks to el jefe for this. pours dense, murky dark reddish brown with very thin white head. nose is odd and unique, mint nutmeg, caramel, chocolate milk, and wheat. flavors are sweet almost cloying, subtle mint, caramel, sweet plums, and orange. alcohol well hidden. this is really an odd mess of flavors. cant say i liked it at all. a drain pour for a $6 bottle isnt what you want at all.

Bottle. Clear, reddish brown with a beige to tan head. Peat, alcohol, beefstock, licorice and spruce in the aroma. The flavor reminds me of a bitter, the spirits, not the beer, and has a distinct spicyness. Full to medium body and a long finish with smoke, peat, spicenotes, alcohol and bitterness. A really unusual beer, but very nice. (070427)

Bottle from the Winking Lizard. Poured very dark brown, no head. Smelled like licorice! Taste was very sweet malts, I LOVE MALTS!! And this had plenty. Also some fruit, plums, cherries, and licorice...The alcohol on this one comes in at the end, and it does let you know its there. This was a delightful brew!

Bottle.  Very small, off-white, fizzy head (lasted less time than it took me to describe).  Clear dark brown hue to body.  Aroma is....wow that is different...smoke, cherries, malts, corriander, and probably much more than my meager abilities can desypher.  Flavor is malty sweet through and through.  Finish-you think it is diminshes quickly but it lingers lightly on the tounge for a very long time.  Light to medium bodied.  Soft but very present carbonation.  Alcohol warming also present.  Best damn tradational sytled ale I have ever had (which might not be saying that much)
Deep brown body with a medium head.  The aroma is very malty with plenty of toffee scents.  Huge malt flavor--lots of toffee, caramel, and some hints of spice.  Very enjoyable.
Dark fruits,caramel and some roasted malt.Pours dark brown with a medium tan head.Got some slight chocolate,sweet malt and caramel in the flavor. Mouthfeel was medium with a sweet very smooth finish.
Bottle @ Alen Street Hardware. Black & murky. Interesting. Dark fruit malts sweetness. Will have to have again

This didnt have a pop at all when I opened it but it poured with a little head. Aroma was a little odd. Fruit loops, jolly ranchers, caramel, and some light citrus. Flavor was caramely malt and some coriander. Had a light body and I couldnt taste the alcohol at all. Left an odd aftertaste on the tongue.

Pours deep brown with a dark red / bronze hue with a generous, but short lasting brown head.  The aroma is wonderful and unique - sweet dark fruits (cherries, raisins), rich soda-shop malt, light spice, roasted caramel, milk and more.  Medium / thick body with a milk-like smoothness at the beginning with a light finish with a bit of fizzy carbonation.  The taste is very good, but not up to the amazing aroma.  It starts with sharp spice, tinny anise, sweet toasted malt, light nuttiness and a bit of wateriness.  The finish has more black licorice, coriander and a pleasing sweetness.  Very nice beer that gets a  hearty thumbs up.   Highly recommended unique beer.

330 ml bottle, best before Jun 14.  Pours brownish black with a thin off white head.  Aroma is sweet fruit, smoke, chocolate, slight coriander.  Very good aroma.  Taste at first reminds me of apple juice, but then the smoke, chocolate and coriander spice comes in.    Thinner then I thought it would be from the looks, watery and very little to no carbonation.  Finish has a little cigar tobacco taste.    This might go well with a stogie.  Very good and interesting.

I think I first had this one at Volo, and have sampled it many times since. Pours a very dark almost opaque brown. Has a strong corriander nose with a full malty spicey taste, with hints of chocolate and liquorice. Is a tad alcoholic in taste, but a wonderful sipping beer. This is really a unique beer.
Bottle. Reddish brown colour with a tan head. Aroma is spicy & floral. Taste is spicy and a bit alcoholic. Quite good.

33 cL bottle from CapFlu.  Pours muddy, lightly particulate mahagony with spare off-white rocky head, moslty diminishing.  Aroma is heavy malt (caramel, nutty, meal), light hops (herbs), average yeast (dough) with notes of toffee, honey, pear and spices.  Medium bodied, sticky texture, average carbonation and a metallic finish.  Moderate sweetness, light acidity and bitterness; hearbal roasted caramel flavor.

Bottle.  Sweet nose bursts with chocolate and spice, malt, toffee, and a little funk.  Coriander and light floral notes.  Dark dark ruby body with no head but a strange counterclockwise swirling vortex effect.  Taste is sweet and lightly smoked with heavy but well-blended coriander.  Very floral, led by the coriander (floriander?).  Touch of flat but really well made root beer.  Medium-full velvety body.  Spice paradise?  A complex, delicious sipper.

11.2oz bottle. Pours a clear dark brown with amber highlights with a small short lived light tan head that leaves minimal lacing. Aroma of coriander and sweet caramel malt with a hint of toasted malt. Taste is the same leaning towards the sweet malt with a dry spicy finish. Very different but very good.

Pours a dark, murky brown with no head save for a thin, filmy thing and a touch of white lacing around the edge. Aroma of coriander over sweet candied sugar and lightly toasted malt. Maybe a hint of raisin. Flavor is much the same, very spicy and darkly sweet. Subtle bittersweet finish.Very nice. Refreshing and different.
UPDATED: OCT 28, 2008 Dark brown of color with an off-white head. An aroma with tobacco, liqurice, plums, raisins and spice. The flavor is with liqurice, sweet, tobacco and spice.

Best before June 2009. Aroma of dark fruits with spice. Hazy pruney color with a passing head that laced a bit in its travels. Starts with dark malt and plumminess, passing on to fairly spicey notes (coriander plus something else?). The mouthfeel is substantial. There seems to be some hop to go along with the malt and spice, but it all works simultaneously. The aftertaste is reminiscent of that of old fashioned Guinness, but not roasted/burnt enough to overcome the other flavors. Really great ale.
Bottle. Fruity malty nose with no head. The taste was malty and smooth with apricot and various spices coming thru . Alcohol well hidden. Interesting beer.

"A most interesting selection, sir."  Beer seekers need to try this one sooner or later.  Its something like a strong old ale with, of course, the prominent coriander character.  So thats what coriander character is like.  Dont waste time reading this trying to figure out what its like; just try it yourself.  Swirl it around in your tulip glass.  Savor it.  Sip it.  Do it until the end of the glass.  By close to the end, when youve one or two sips left, youre really getting somewhere.
A flavourful beer of chocolate, figs and spices, great young to excellent when aged. Page 461 of Michael Jacksons Great Beer Guide and only 234 of his 500 Classic Brews to go.

UPDATED: MAR 29, 2007 wow, this is one interesting brew.  an aggresive pour leaves almost zero head, just some lacing.  Aroma is incredible, fresh fruit, plum, incredibly floral, almost like expensive perfume.  Taste doesnt disappoint, sweet fruits, floral, almost like an incredibly fruity tea, as well as some caramel, small hops and spice.  Ive never tasted anything like this before.  It is made with coriander, so I assume that is a lot of the interesting smell and taste.  I give this beer points for originality.  This brew is a must try.
Pours black/brown with very little head. Strong aroma of citrus, maybe lemon, and a light floral quality. Understated hop bitterness that comes up toward the end, with citrus, molasses, and flowers.

Pours a dark mahogony with a small head.  Nice spicy nose with hints of dark fruit as well as ripe fruit, anise, and the corriander is very pronounced.  Great powerful mouthfeel with anise and corriander dominating, but there are hints of a light hoppiy nature.  Great malt backbone with a nice spicy balance.
user_location: Farewell Minny; Hello Puyallup, Washington, USA

text: Bottle poured showing nearly no head.  Dark caramel appearance.  Perhaps a complex mix of tastes that came across to me as plain. I guess since it comes from Scotland Ill say all the flavors equalled a "plaid."  Minimal carbonation.

UPDATED: AUG 20, 2010 An unusual specimen: very dark, very murky chestnut brown, hardly any head or lacing. Chocolate, licorice in the nose with moderately toasted malts and a very noticeable but still not "hot" alcohol presence. Very smooth, perhaps undercarbonated, but refreshing and drinkable. Hard to pinpoint, but has a certain purity of taste and smell that clearly indicates exceptional quality and craftmanship. A perfect ale for cold winters eve.

Bottle. Nice brown colour with a medium rather short lasting head. Aroma of coriander indeed, nice maltiness and caramel. Flavour has coriander, toasty malts, sweet caramel, slight liquorice and some spices. Very tasty ale.

Served in a brandy snifter for no reason other that I saw it first.  Bottle makes best before June 2014.  1 finger rapidly dissipitating head, no lace. Clear, dark reddish brown color.  Pungent malty aroma with a hint of spice and dark fruit. Medium mouthfeel, mild carbonation.  Twangy malty aroma, a bit of sweet smokiness, mild malty finish.

33 cL bottle via Lubiere, served at cellar temp. in a tulip glass. FE 21/07
App.:  clear, very deep red-brown, mocha head. 
 
Aroma:  strong molasses and dark dried fruits, roasted malts, licorice, a certain nuttiness, alcohol is present, some chocolate and vanilla.  Deep, dark beer!  

Palate:  full body, smooth and syrupy, a bit powdery and almost no carbonation.  

Flav.:  very similar to the nose: raisins, milk chocolate, molasses, licorice, deep roasted malts.  Nice!  A touch sweet and salty with a hint of alcohol and some bitterness on the finish.

Beautiful stuff.

Bottle-Poured a dark, ruby red/brown color w/a minimal head. Sweet spiced aroma. Strong alcohol flavor w/traces of orange, colander, cloves, cinnamon, licorice, brandy, & brown sugar. This beer was pretty potent & had a lot going on, really got your attention. Too strong to drink with a meal, more of an after dinner drink, something to sip on. Long sweet/spicey finish w/quite a kick.
Bottle sampled with Stegosaurus. Pours dark with an off-white head. Aroma of spices, fruit, and coriander.  The flavor contains spices, fruit, alcohol, and coriander.

Year-old bottle.

Pours a deep and elegant ruby-brown with a very modest head. Fascinating spicy aroma, of coriander and rum, bubblegum and peaches - marvellous. The flavor comes on strongly, tons of licorice, again coriander, very spicy, some fascinating abbey dubbel flavors,  bubblegum, smoky whiskey malt, enough force to catch me by surprise and make my first sip less than enjoyable. But as I proceed and my palate grows used to the beer, I become impressed and start to really enjoy not only the rich smooth mouthfeel but the complex interplay of strong flavors as well.

This is a very different beer, and a very interesting one, worth revisiting upon occasion.

UPDATED: JUL 23, 2007 Bottle sampled with Beerded_one. Pours dark brown with a thin off-white head. Aroma of spices, fruit, coriander, and brown sugar. The flavor is spices, fruit, brown sugar, alcohol, very smooth alcohol. Good brew.

Bottle dated best before June 2014.  Dark mahogany brown pour with little to no head.  Dark fruit and brandy aroma with some sweet brown sugar and spices (maybe some clove and cinnamon.  Flavor is fruity and spicy with a good dose of Belgian candi sugar, some roastiness.  Medium-thin body, creamy, and a moderate amount of carbonation.

UPDATED: MAR 22, 2007 Bottle. Dark brown with an off-white head that quickly disappears. Fruity and spicy with hints of clove and juniper. Smooth silky mouthfeel and perhaps a little thin. Not much bitterness, but the sweetness is still on the right side . A very interesting and enjoyable brew.

Best before June 2011.

Pours a very dark brown with deep amber highlights. Theres a quarter inch head that fades rapidly to a thin spotty cap, with a fairly thin ring that leaves behind a tattered bit of lace.

Smell; the smell is very fruity with a little orange peel, plums, dates and apples. Theres pleasant smokey spiciness, with chocolate and caramel mixed in.

Taste; the orange comes out more strongly in the flavor, with the plums, berries and apples falling in behind. The roasted malts and smokey/peat flavors play off of the spices very nicely, and finishes with a rich chocolatey flavor. Mouthfeel is medium to full bodied, and with almost no bitterness, this goes down very easy.
user_location: Where the hell am I?, Nebraska, USA

text: Nice dark red color..a little hazy without any head. I was really trying to like this beer but am a little disappointed. Not alot of flavour, quite thin. Its just okay.

(bottle - 11.2 oz) Dark ruby red color without any head to speak of. Aroma is very complex. Lots of sweetness, some cherries possibly mixed with brown sugar, some coriander, honey, and even some chocolate. Flavor is sweet at the beginning with a middle of honey, earth notes, mixed with some orange zest, and some tangy dark fruits. Loaded with different flavors but they dont mix all that well. Not very fizzy.

Loving this ale - beautiful but subdued in every respect.  It has all the goods but makes you work in order for them to truly appear; this makes it all the more pleasing.  A deep red-brown with basically no head; the aroma emanating from this brew is out-of-this-world:  caramel, floral pollen, brown sugar, bitter orange peel, wildflower honey.  In the mouth some of these aromas fade out considerably, leaving a mild taste dominated by sweetness through brown sugar, oranges, flowers.  Little to no bitterness but a strange sweet finish that I havent ever experienced before. The ale is smooth on the tongue but seemed to me a little bit flat; not exactly syrupy but not as put-together on the tongue as I wouldve hoped.  Overall a tremendous ale.

BottleABSOLUTELY gorgeous ale.  Dark, clean red, near black, very creamy tan/white head.  Smells fantastic, as is well known.  Spices like orange peel --mostly coriander, strong coriander, which is great.  This is the smoothest palated ale Ive ever drank...very sweet, as it leaves a tangy, bitterness of sorts on the tongue when finished.  Really, of all the expensive bottles Ive sampled and experimented with, this one YOU HAVE TO TRY.
The coriander and malt provide a great flavor and palate sensation. The oak character is obvious, but balanced nicely by the roundness of the herbal infusion.

Pours a loamy red.  Herbal mint aroma.  Many tiny white bubbles around rim of glass.  Sweet brown malt flavour with just a hint of alcohol.  A bare hint, really, quite impressive for eight percent.  It is pretty sweet though.

Near black colored, slight red hints. Medium sized beige head. Chocolate, nuts, mild vinous tones, even some oak in aroma. Medium to full bodied. Flavor is strongly sweet with vinous touch and berries, mild alcohol and some tangy biting sourness there also. Too sweet flavored.

Bottle. Incredible delicious aroma of dried fruit, alcohol, caramel with hints of coffee. The flavor is dominated by caramel and butter leading to a flowery finish and a short raisiny aftertaste with hints of bitterness. Very dark brown with shades of read and a small café au lait colored head. Perfect Co2 for the style and beautifully balanced flavor. The only thing I think detracts from this brew is that it is a but a bit thin in the mouth like it was filtered. Excellent!

Bottle; nose of spices, plums, caramel, and sweetness; hazy brown with a ring of beige bubbles encircling the glass; flavor has corriander, caramel, molasses, and sweet fruitiness in a medium body with a tiny alcohol finish.
Brown with small head.  Aroma is strange perfumy spice, sweet fruit, and sugar.  Flavor is the same with plum and spice.  Corriander is apparent.  Meduim/light palate.
sampled with mate: aroma is spicy with lots of dark roasted malt character, with carmel and malasses, and some dark dried fruits.  Nice spicey yeast as well kind of like a belgian ale.

Huge aroma. Deep malty, spicy and deep flowery. The colour is dark brown and the creamy head is lasting all the way through.
The taste is slight burned with an initial caramel note. Slight taste of cloves, coriander and a lot of spices, that I just cant pinpoint. Its complex and extremely well balanced and has a heveanly feel good mellowness.
The palate is just perfect. Body is just big enough and the carbonation couldnt be better for this style.
Its a real treat, and theres so many things going on in this beer that it would take pages just to narrow it down. Really amazing!!!!
Bottle. pours a near black dark colour. Thin fizzy white head that dies a fast death. very sweet aroma, somewhat sugary. Bitter flavour. too much sweetness for me. bitter finish.

Bottle. Pours a very dark ruby-brown, with a thin tan head that disappears quickly. Nose is malty, coriander, pepper, sweet with a hint of woodsmoke. Mouth is coriander, slightly sweet, peppery, touch of molasses, malty. Smooth, slightly bitter and peppery finish. Very good, disguises alcohol well. Nice rounded ale, slightly lacking in palate, but makes up for it in spice.

Interesting dark (nearly black) ale spiced with coriander. Small head fizzed away quickly. I thought the aroma was sweet and reminscent of cherries, although my partner (she of the better nose) said "No". Maybe its the coriander. Full bodied, with a bit of an oily feel. Taste sweet, spicy and bitter, all at the same time - overly sweet for my palate though

UPDATED: DEC 11, 2006 Bottle. Pours a dark brown color with a minimal off white head that disaapears rather quickly. Aroma of malt, molasses, and coriander. Taste is slightly sweet with a bit of a rotten fruit flavor. Finishes with an unpleasent aftertaste.

Poured a dark brown brew with a small short lived tan head. The aroma was very fruity. Had hints of molasses and raisin/prune. The taste had a lot more of the molasses and prune taste. Definitely a unique beer. The palate was smooth and full. Not as impressed as i expected.
Dark brown murky look....low low ring o head.....sweet tar fudge coriander alcohol plums BERRY slight pepperiness in taste....big berry taste as it warms up...this is a classic!

Bottle. Pours a very dark brown with a small dense head. Aromas of vanilla, oak, cedar, molasses, coriander and a little prune. Fairly malty, heavy mouthfeel with a good amount of pine in taste with a biting aftertaste.

11/10/06: Bottle.  Aroma of licorice and orange pulp.  Deep black cherry body.  Very tranquil looking.  Abundant flavors: molasses, roasted malt, vanilla and coriander.  Chewy palate.  Wowzers!  I believe there are gum drop tones interesting.  Finish is slightly sour with notes of cherry.  Alcohol more present as beer warms.  Also noted, tongue numbing.

12 OZ bottle via footbalm (thanks eric!). Pours a clear dark brown with a large beige head.Aroma is butterscotch, vanilla, band aid, alcohol.Tastes just like it smells and the bandaid comes through strong in the aftertaste. Tastes like old stale boiled colliflower...Thin body. Crappy beer....maybe it is the coriander that ruins it for me?
Pours a clear red with a tanned head. Smells flowery. Slightly sour and winey.Quite spicy. Well hidden alcohol. Full bodied. Dry, very flowery finish with some residual sugars.

Pours to a dark oily brown, wit hints of red. Had a very thin off-white head that left virtually no lacing. Nice strong aroma of malty dark fruit, with undertones of chocolate and toffee, with hints of spices. Taste was definitely more of the same found in the aroma, though the alcohol was more pronounced as the beer warmed. Finish was an interesting mix of sweet and dry. I really enjoyed this beer, although it actually reminded me somewhat of a barley wine.

UPDATED: SEP 24, 2007 Fantastic potent aroma - sweet, fruity, and floral. Pours a dark, almost opaque reddish-black. Small bubbly head and some lace. Fruity, spicy taste,  sweet malt flavour, strong presence of alcohol, notes of berries. Slightly thin but creamy body with low carbonation. Fantastic coriander & caramel aftertaste. What a treat of a beer!

12oz bottle courtesy of HogTownHarry.  Thanks, Harry!  Cola-brown appearance; off-white head with retention at the edges and decent lacing.  Plenty of coriander and sweet malts in the aroma; smells slightly hot / boozy; red fruit and maple syrup.  Full mouthfeel: maple syrup, cotton candy, a healthy dose (well done) of coriander, some milk chocolate; slightly hot; medium finish showing candy sweetness, some roasted malts and spice.

Bottle from Haket. Very spicy, wuite a variety of tastes that I couldnt quite identify. Beautiful aftertaste. Hint of cherry without the sourness. What a cherry ripe might taste like if it were alcoholic and cost $100. Actually reminded me a bit of a muscat.

12oz bottle pours dark brown with a fair beige head that didnt stay very long.  Aromas of plums, raisins, caramel, roasted malts, and chocolate.  Flavor is raisins, roasted malts, plums, caramel, and chocolate.  Medium body.. Not much carbonation.  Soft mouthfeel.  Alcohol covered well but there is warmth after the glass is finished..

Not sure if its supposed to be this way but had no head whatsoever.  Minimal carbonation.  Perhaps a bad bottle? Flavor is good though, smooth, good roasted malty flavor.  May have to get another to compare.

Dark brown-reddish hue, with a diminishing beige head, nice sweet toasted malt nose, with a strong coriander spiciness, toffeeish accent, caramel and chocolatey notes, and dark dried fruits in the aroma follows through on a full-bodied palate with a sweet toasted malt character, with a hint of black coffee, dried dark fruits of plums, raisins, dates, spicy coriander, and faint anise, toffee note, leading towards a sweet malt graininess, in a lingering spiciness finish.
Bottled. Dark amber colour, big beige head. Aroma is plum, berries, slight roast and raisins. Flavour is smooth raisins, dark fruits and berries. Quite smooth, and lovely.

UPDATED: APR 7, 2009 Bottled.
Dark ruby, decent off-white head. Toasted, roasted aroma. Very malty, dark malts, roasted, hides ABV well. My "easiest non-rated good beer" was slightly dissapointing. (7/4/7/3/13 3.4). 
Re-rated bottle from Alko. 
Dark ruby color, small tan head. Lots of raisins in the nose together with some alcohol. Very soft palate. Dark fruits - dates, raisins, plums. Sweet edge and some alcohol. Rounded sipping brew - needs some ageing. ((7/4/7/4/15 3.7)

Dark reddish brown coloration... almost black except for around the edges.  No head and just a bit of fizz on the surface.  Aroma is a work of art.  Sweet sugary notes with dark fruit, molasses and maybe some berry scents, too.  Flavor is a bit crisper and thinner than I expected.  There is a lot more wood/earth/peat type flavoring than the nose let on.  That said, this all blends together extremely well.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: UPDATED: OCT 10, 2006 (Bottle at Haket, Göteborg) Pours dark red with a light brown head. Fruity aroma with berries and wet tobacco. Red apples. Very sweet. Syrup and fudge. Dried fruit and sweet malt flavour with a nice afterbitterness and yeast character. Spicey. Medium to big body.
Bottle. Pours ruby brown with virtually no head. Aroma is apricot, plum, malt. Flavor is plum, earth, sour, and herbal.

Pours a deep red/brown color that becomes near black as the glass fills, but you can tell its not a stout.  This beer tried to pour a head, but somehow the foam resembled only larger soapy-looking bubbles.  However, the stuck around and formed a nice lacing, and it was rather amusing to tilt the glass and watch the bubbles slowly crawl to the surface of this thick beer.  Anyway, the aroma was very rich in spices and toffee notes.  The flavor is pretty sweet upfront, almost like a German chocolate cake, but nuttier.  The finish had minimal bitterness, but there was still plenty to taste, with different spice flavors guiding the beer down, as well as an almost hazelnut-like finish.  After a few minutes though, the aftertaste can be a little much, but thats almost to be expected with such a unique flavor.  This beer packed a lot of malty and spice flavors, and I can see why its rating is so high.  Every flavor was delightful, and everthing was balanced.

Pours a syrupy deep amber/brown with a thin head. Spicey and herbal aroma, with lots of thick sweet caramel malts, nutty and hints of chocolate.  Piney flavor with more herbs and spice, thick malts, moslty sweet with an herbal/piney hop bitterness.  Kind of like a spiced barleywine.  Very nice.
Smell like the medicinbox, apricot, a little christmas, the alcohol in the taste together with som spices and bitterness

Bottle, at Haket, Göteborg. Deep reddish brown colour, creamy head. Herbal aroma, quite nice. Sweetish and herbal flavour, sourish in the finish. Not bad, but is it worth the price? Traquair House Ale is better!

Nice brown color is a bit ruddy with relatively no head.  Aroma is clean and spicy with malt and chocolate present.  Taste is a nice blend of spices with coriander standing out, plum, chocolate, coffee, and raison flavors.  Complex and enjoyable ale.  Too bad its $4.99/bottle at the local Co-Op...

woody, bourbon, malty, chocolate, licorice, aroma.  dark murky brown appearence with just a ring of head around the edge of the glass.  thick looking pour.  flavor is smokey, caramel, and malty but also fruity with notes of green apples and spices.  extremely smooth with a full body and a big palate.  great brewery.

Malt,spice aroma, with hints of licorice and tea, light,spicey peppery taste, slightly sweet at first ,drying out in the finish. Corriander and alcohol just barely detectable. Surprisingly light,very refreshing,except for the 8% you could drink a lot of these

330 ml bottle. Very dark brown, hints of gray. Seemingly hazy, but it is difficult to tell in this light. Very little head, only some white islands the edges. Complex spice aroma. Plummy, grainy, raisiny aroma with some complex alcohols. Biscuits. Dark chocolate and cocoa powder at first. Light sourish in the mouth. Quite a bit of chocolate flavours combined with dried fruits. Light-bodied with a powdery texture. Some oxidized notes. Little hop aroma to be found, but a distinct hop bitterness throughout. Finishes very drying.
Pours a cola like dark brown with a small tan head. Aroma was dominated by alcohol, but the flavor was not as hot. Cocoa, malt, and a velvet texture made this a very nice brew.

Purple color, low carbonation, large bubbles, small head receding to a coffee like cream. Aroma of coriander and blackcurrant. Initially very sweet, shifts to a pleasant roastiness reminiscent of coffee. Mouthfeel was at the same time round and watery. Strange but reminds me of an hybrid between Crush grape soda, rootbeer and coffee!? Interesting.

Ive only tried this in bottle form as it was brought back from Scotland as a gift.  After reading the label and seeing its volume of alcohol (8%), I was skeptical, but after tasting it, I was both surprised and impressed.  You can taste the alcohol, but it doesnt at all violate.  You get the sense that this ale isnt an ale that is made for the sheer purpose of getting the drinker drunk -- the high alcohol content adds to the bite.

This ale is very thick and dark, and its taste/smell is somewhat reminiscent of black liquorice.  But dont let this throw you off, I dislike black liquorice, but love this ale.  The ingredients read: Spring Water, Malt, Hops, Yeast & Spices.  A quality ale, without a doubt.
pours with a nice frothy head which disappears quickly, lovely nose. tastes of port, coffe and dark chocolate. nice spicyness, slight aftertaste. one of my favourites

The beer pours to a very deep garnet colored body with a very thick and tall chocolate milk foam colored head. The aroma is port wine, coriander, grain dust, blueberries. The flavor is chocolatey, oatmeal-like, peat, tobacco, and powdered sugar. The palate is rich, lightly smokey, creamy, good feeling.
Black cola coloured body, short lasting head, smooth and medium body which is sweet and almost chocolatey, spice.  Didnt notice the alcohoI and I thought this was a lovely drop.

11.2-oz. Gorgeous ebony pour, though essentially headless after a few seconds under a game but overmatched thin white film. Roasty aromas jump out of the snifter like frogs from a pot--it almost smells skunked at first if youre not paying attention. Rich smoke, piney hop, and malty sweetness accentuate the roast nose, but theyre running way back in the pack. There are some garnet/brown highlights under light, but theyre not prominent. The bodys watery, but its a clean and drinkable wateriness, not a haphazardly-brewed wateriness. Spicy mid-palate after a roasty, toasty attack, with some mild bitterness in the finish and a perfectly modulated malt underpinning. Very, very well considered beer.

330ml bottle, best before June 2011. Mahogany with a decent tan head. Nose somewhat sweet, vinous, a bit of sloe gin, berries and coriander. Wow, this is wierd. Spicy flavors, hard to get a handle on. More sloe gin, a berrylike flavor (raspberries and blueberries) and coriander. Smooth, slightly creamy mouthfeel, kinda slick. Alcohol apparent at the end. Mildly dry once its down the gullet. A wierd and wonderful beer!

Best Before June 2011.  The beer pours to a very deep garnet colored body with a very thick and tall chocolate milk foam colored head.  The aroma is port wine, coriander, grain dust, blueberries.  Really strange.  The flavor is chocolatey, oatmeal-like, peat, tobacco, and powdered sugar.  75+% similar to a Scotch or Scottish ale with some flair added for uniqueness.  The palate is rich, lightly smokey, creamy, good feeling.  Took me about 45 minutes to decide how to rate this unique beer.
Bottle. Dark brown. Almost no head. Aroma of caramel, malt and port, quite spicy. Taste is caramel with spices, some alcool, maltiness, some bitterness. Medium body. Good scottish ale.

A very nice Scottish style ale, with just enough coriander to be noticed.
Deep amber color with a medium head. Smooth drinking with caramel notes  and medium maltiness. Not too strong on the alcohol front or the smoky front, so easily drunk.

Dark brown color with some red hues and only a brief thin head. No lacing at all. The aroma had a lot going on, some alcohol, but mostly malty spicey scents. The flavor was intersting: spices (coriander), dark fruits, licorice, some chocolate, and rich maltiness, very balanced sweetness, spices, and light bitterness. The mouthfeel, however, was kinda thin, coming off like a weak porter or thin Scottish ale. Bump the ABV a bit and this is like some eisbocks Ive had.

UPDATED: NOV 12, 2007 12 oz bottle. Clear reddish-brown color. The thin off white head dissipated quickly into nothingness and left absolutely no lace. Not a trace. Attractive aroma and flavor which can be summarized in one word: blueberries. There are none in there, I realize, but it is blueberries nonetheless. You also occasionally get whiffs of corinader, alcohol, and grape candy. Smooth and slightly sweet on the tongue. Very good beer.

Dark ruby-red to mahogany colour with clear limited head. Aromas of nuts, berries, spices (cardemum, koriander, anis and some apple). Taste is wonderfully complex with tones of alcohol (giving it more body), more spices and then sweetness until it finishes slightly bitter.

A nice dark black-brown hue.
Rich aromas have an anise and chocolate character that follows through on a smooth and creamy, full-bodied palate.  Spice notes linger on in the finish.
This is truly one of the best scottish ales that I have ever tried.  Very full bodied and flavourful with a fine head.

Pours a very dark reddish-brown color with a thick tan head.  Aroma is of dried fruit, spice, corriander,  and a hint of chocolate and hops.  Flavor is strong of corriander and the other spices with chocolate, dried fruit, molasses, and a slight finish of hops.  Pleasantly surprised by this brew, very delicious.

Chocolate color. No head which was disappointing. Malty sweet aroma. 
little chocolate in the nose too. Slightly dry palate. Sweet flavor with a bit of a spicy aftertaste. Interesting mix with the coriander.

Muddy dark brown, nearly black. A rapid pour produced only a misty, bubbly, cap that flattened out super quickly. A semi oily residue coats the glass as only a few small strings and spots of tannish lace decides to stick.

Aroma is big and beautiful. Complexly dark and smokey with super dark, charred raisin and plum. Deeply tangy with a heavy set dark, thick molasses with a wonderfully little punch of peaty smokened alcoholic wamth within the nose thats quite portly.

Taste is just as good with a smooth display of darkened things that smoke and cinder on the palate with melting dark fruityness and saturated maltyness. Paled tang in sense with molasses, raisin, and plum. Bold, yet giving way to a smoothness of caramel, roasties of fruit skins, and a smokey alluring finish of twisted dark toffee and some weird root beer like spice. Vanilla and chocolate notes along with some peat and tarry tobacco-like flavors meld into a pudding of warmth as it soaks up the soft corpuscles of the palate leaving a smoothly manufactured fullness in the mouth.

Feel is slowly medium and quite dark with a dullish tang that hangs around for length as it gets all complex and fun with the flavors. Seems a bit thin at the front but builds and then lasts for one stretched out volume of mouth coating warmth and smooth oilyness.

A long lasting sipper that dawns its own grace in acceptance for flavor, body, and warmth.
Quite a nice brew. 
Recommended.
Nice ale, dark red body.lots of foam. Nice balance Chocolate and spices fruits, alcohol who has a nice bitternes,  long finish.

Bottle: Brown color, almost no head, off-color.  Aroma of blueberries, spices, dark fruit, some alcohol, some hops.  Taste of spices, fruits.  I dont know what coriander tastes like.  Very spicy taste in the back of my throat.  Lots of flavor.

Courtoisie de HogTownHarry, but dans un tumbler. Cest spécial cette bière, bizzard même. Couleur de cola, avec un petit collet qui dure. LÉgé arome de vanille et de réglisse noir. Le goût; un peu fumé, bonbon, réglisse noir, caramel, etc.. Une mélage de choses intéressante.

UPDATED: APR 28, 2006 Weird, wonderful brew, with lots going on here, some of which is difficult to define...so different is this beer.  (Note to El_Borracho:  THIS beer should be enough to indicate why it makes no sense to "top out" your ratings at 500 (or any number really!)....because every once in a while  a strange (and in this case, I mean STRANGE) beer comes along that knocks all your senses for a loop, turns your appreciation for beer on its ear, and makes you rethink  just what we are really doing by reviewing a constant stream of new and unusual beers.  It is, after all, The League of Strange Beer Drinkers, not The League of the Same Beer Daily)    This one, from Scotland, has strange intertwined flavors of smoke, intense spiciness (coriander), roasted caramel and molasses, candi sugar, alcohol, licorice, dried fruits like fig and dates, dark chocolate and cocoa.   Great creamy mouthfeel.  This is really spectacular!   Whyd I wait so long to sample this baby!?!

Pours a deep mahaogany brown with no head.  There is some strong alcohol in the aroma, almost like a scotch.  There is also hints of medicine, licorice, raisin, spices, and nuts.  Wow, this has a very unique, delicous taste.  Its hard to pinpoint the very complex flavors.  There is a wonderful spicy tartness to this beer.  There are hints of grapes and earthy tones, as well as blueberries and pine and even some cocoa.  The palate is great - creamy and smooth with a bitter spiciness in the finish.  Overall this is a fantastic spiced beer with an excellent complex taste.

Low carbonation and an aroma of alcohol and spices. Looks like very strong tea in the glass and has an almost pleasant medicine taste (you know the kind where you look forward to the next dose). A good mouth feel with a taste to complex for my inexperienced palate to seperate. I will try it again just to be sure its not better than I thought it was.

Bottle. Off-white creamy low but lasting head. Clear dark red body.  Aroma of alcohol and berries. Complex flavor with a good balance between the high alcohol percentage and grapefruit and berries tastes.

This brew pours like a cola, medium translucent brown and somewhat fizzy with a big but short-lived tannish head.  The aroma is clean, earthy, with hints of both fruit and green vegetables.  The taste is sweet, a bit astringent and spicy, with too many flavors to try to separate.  There are hints of grape peel, dirt, cloves, and cocoa/chocolate.  Its a very pleasant blend with only a little bitterness.  It reminds me somewhat of the wild grape vines I used to find as a child, how fruity and astringent they were.  I would think this was more than 8 percent alcohol, and not because of the strength but more because of the cooling and drying effects.  The body is medium, with a spicy finish.  Im not sure I like this as much as some of the reviewers seem to, but it IS different in a good way and I will buy it again if I can find it!

A nice ruddy brown pour with a thick creamy khaki head.  The aroma is great, white grapes, peppermint, grape double bubble gum, and cloves. Sweet flavor of olive oil, lemons, cotton candy, and an earthy sweet mushroom flavor. Finishes with lemons and mint, with lingering clove flavor emerging later on. The mouth feel is reminiscent of the feeling I get after eating carrot cake.
Ap-4 ar-9 tas-7 pal-4 ov-16

Dark body with tight head bubbles.  Nose is sweet fruits, blueberry syrup and corriander (very supprising). Mouthh is skim milk.  Flavour is blanaced fruitiness and bitterness.  Green vegtable bitterness follows the tounge.

Deep rich mahogany brown with a tall tan head. Huge aromas of blueberries, bergamot, and chocolate. Smooth creamy palate with raisins, berries, cocoa, and buttery malt. The alcohol remains well hidden. This is absolutely fantastic-- the best Scottish beer Ive tried by a long shot, and one I would strongly recommend for its uniqueness. Fantastic!
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: Bottle.  Best before June 2014.  Pours nice enough.  Very dark mahaogany with a fluffy head atop.  Aroma is rather bland.  Some chocolate, some dark fruit and some spices.  At first, it seems rather bland in the mouth, as well, but theres a subtlety to it that takes a bit to notice.  Fruity and subtle spices as well as a dark chocolate that provides a great foundation.  It has a strange astringency, almost like a dry gin.  Around mid bottle, the fruit start to organize themselves ... dark fruit mostly, and blueberry was the most noticeable, but I also got a sense of cherry.  It finished somewhat spicy.

Dark brown color with mahogany edges, moderate white head and light lacing. Aroma is sweet nutty malt with very noticeable chocolaty and spicy tones. Flavor is sweet and malty with increasinly powerfull chocolate tones. As it warms dark raspberry fruitiness, licorice, and fig come through. Finshes very lightly bitter, quite sweet with a noticeable alcohol presence and leaves a coriander spicieness on the palate.

Bottle.  Virtually no head....none.  Very murky brown body.  Strong alcohol nose with licorice, raisin, chocolate, spices...pretty complex.  Not much hops though.  Taste:  first thing I notice is low carbonation, tastes flat.  I asked my wife what coriander is supposed to taste like, and she said she thought licorice which makes sense.  I think this would be very good if it didnt taste flat.  I guess I prefer to have carbonation in a beer.  It would have balanced the extreme sweetness in this one.  I felt by the end of this that the flavor became cloying.  This is definitely a unique beer and with some slight changes could have been much better IMO.

Bottle from Texas Wine Cellars in Fredericksburg, Texas   Pours a rich, deep brown with a small, short-lived head.  Aroma is thick with sweet malt, candy, and a touch of bourbon and wine.  Flavor is a sweet, peachy malt that exudes a bit of tang in the finish.  The ingredients and the flavors flow along the tongue quite nicely.  This beer could be obscene as far as too much flavor, but it levels off before anything too weird happens.  This is a good thing.  Palate is silky and slippery.  A very nice brew, one to enjoy again.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: Deep dark pour with almost no head.  Looked like a glass of Coke.  Strong scent right off the pour.  Malty blueberry? spices.  Malty thick taste.  Spicey with caramel and lots of smokey malts.  Slight bitter aftertaste.  The strong Alcohol wasfound in the taste and suprised me when I learned the 8%.  Reminded me a bit of a Barley Wine and of many Belgians.  Kind of like a 1/2 Barly Wine 1/2 Belgian Strong Mix.  Really enjoyed this.

Bottle at MacNivens. Served in snifter. No head formation even when poured correctly. Black body. Aroma was godly. Berries, liquorice, pear, soy sauce, to name a few. Taste was very complex and very available.  I was not sure what coriander tasted like, but since this was brewed with coriander, I will assume the unique flavor I got was that. In addition was raisin, liquorice, and clove. Really sweetened as it warmed. Not very often Ive had an intense and complex beer be so easy to enjoy. Palate was thick, but had a light quality which did not allow a sticky feel. Very interesting.

Aroma: malt, sweet, vanilla, coffee, dried fruit, oak cask, bit musty, alcohol, apple, bread-sourish, caraway and fennel

Appearance: deep red brown, clear, white beige head

Flavor: bittersweet, a bit burnt, well-balanced, rich, very bitter

Palate: odd, smooth, the sweetness is an illusion???, creamy, slightly viscous

Bottle.  Pours a dark amber, thin wispy white head that dissipates within a minute.  Defininately fruity, and definitely a scotch-like.  A bit dry on the aftertaste, which was unexpected given the fruit.  Probably much better from the source and not after the trip overseas, but very good nonetheless.

Pours a dark brown with no head--a couple bubbles that appear to be light tan.  Spicy and fruity aromas, alcohol--smells somewhat like a wit, but is way too dark and other funky flavors are going on.  Funk is a good word for this.  Slight bitterness up front, some sweetness in the middle, and a dry finish.Very strange beer--but good.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: Pours a very dark amber/maroon and has a beautiful small off white head (shortly lasting).  Aroma is absolutely top notch...tons of crazy spices and honey...I could smell it from a foot and a half away.  Taste is very interesting.  Tons of that crazy spice in the flavor (no idea what it is)...a little malt, chocolate, fresh grape/fruit, molasses, and a touch of grass (with a bunch of other flavors...very complex, but very manageable).  Mouthfeel is initally very dry and starchy...but it takes a good amount of time for it to go down.  Very light bodied and lightly carbonated.

Poured like thick cola with a creamy head.  Immediate spiced cola aroma that developed notes of soy sauce as it warmed.  Medium-full bodied with a velvety smooth mouthfeel.  Complex flavors changed with each passing minute.  Prunes, soy, spice, semi-sweet chocolate and enough of a complexion to notice other flavors with the next bottle.  All the flavors are just on the border toying with becomming powerfull or slightly tiresome but never quite get there, which is the mark of a great beer IMO.  Quick and dry finish adds yet another interesting quality to a beer that you would assume to have a lingering sweet finish.

Bottle. Looks exactly like a violently poured Dr. Pepper. Big frothy head that quickly fades into an island of bubbles, with CO2 bubbles coating the entire glass at the liquid/glass contact. Nose-raisin, fig, dark malt extract. Taste-the coriander is there and well balanced throughout. The coriander is all over without being dominant. Bitter, fruit gum, apple, clove, and anise. lychee, watermelon, black pepper. There is a flavor here that I cannot describe (it is akin to the coriander) that is just AWESOME! It is like melon, coriander, and pine all rolled into one gentle flavor. I like this a whole lot more than I thought I would. Excellent.

Bottle: Pours a dark mahogany with a thin tan head that fades. 
Dark fruit and licorice aroma with a spicy bready malt undertone.
Fruity dry bitter flavour that has good depth but I could not successfully cogitate over at the time.

Happy Day after St. Pattys Day!  After finishing up at the Smokehouse last night, we
meandered over to the Winking Lizard.  This was my fifth brew of St. Pattys Day.  Ive
been wanting to try this one for years, but Ive only been able to secure the House ale
from Traquair for my sampling pleasure up until now.  Perfect nose of  sweet malt &
spice, bubblegum & butterscotch.  The brew pours with a nice stout-ish cascade that
blooms into a thick, dense rocky beige head with fair retention and lace.  The brew is a 
dark clear brown with copper highlights.  The flavor so awesome that Im just going to
say it will hit your G-Spot right on the center circle of the bulls eye.  The full body is
creamy and soft.  With a slightly better head and lace this brew would be an easy 5.  Worth the long wait, WOW!

Bott.  Strong brown sugar coriander licorice aroma, spicy sweet, inviting.  Deep opaque brown-black with a few tan bubbles.  Medium-light bodied.  Flavor is as aroma, very coriander licorice, maybe too strong on the coriander and too sweet.   Almost cola-ish.  This is probably the kind of stuff Tim Webb had in mind when he said "Coriander soup."

Small head on a dark brown body. Very filling, it has all sorts of intertwine flavours. Pretty complex in fact. It leaves a very tasty aftertaste. Not for the faint of heart, thoug. Very pleasant altogether.

This is my first beer of this style. When I opened it first I was not certain what to think of it the spices seemed overpowering. However while finishing it I came to appreciate the complexity of the beer. It pours a dark brown with a red tint. There was a small tan head which quickly diminishes to a ring. There are a lot of aromas in there is fruit, spices and an over all sweetness. The flavour it of malt and you can taste the alcohol in there. I want to thank Oakes for this one I will have to try some other spice beers to see how they rank in comparison to this one.

I was pleasantly surprised by this beer the first time I had it.  Coriander spiciness predominates the nose.  An almost orangely quality, but not quite citric, permeates the flavor.  A rich brown with quickly disipating offwhite head.

Wow, never had a beer like this one. pours dark brown/black with smallish head. aroma is very spicey, with pine and pepper notes. The best way to describe the flavor is that it taste like really strong Earl Grey tea. which happens to be my favorite tea. has a slight alcohol bite which is nice. very nice mouth feel. a very good unique beer. wish it was cheeper

UPDATED: MAR 8, 2006 Pours mahogany brown into a tumbler.  Very effervesent with quickly receding mocha-colored head.  Date and plum aromas - dare I say play dough?  Burnt caramel and molasses with a slightly bitter, dry lasting finish.  Very similar to a trappist ale, but not quite as full-bodied.

Mahogony pour with a thin milky head. Fruity and spicy aroma with nettles and corriander. The perfume corriander flavor is couched by mild caramel malt. Well balanced and pleasing ale, though simpler than I had anticipated. Would go well with Beef Madras.
Dark body. Off-white head. Little weinous and strong peppery taste. The  malt is heavy on this on.
Deep red/brown with no head.  Nice lacing and very very smooth.  Little sweet and very little coriander.  Again, its very easy going down but not much taste.

UPDATED: APR 17, 2007 rerate:  This beer is not what I initially pegged it to be.  The corriander gives it a very weird flavor but it is not that complimenting.  I can taste some caramel malt but that is overtaken by the coriander and Im not sure I like that.  this is not a very bad beer, but it could have been so much better!  Cheers!

This ones for John, Misty and their family.  May your father-in-law find peace and forever be a part of you.  Though I didnt personally know the man, I know he must be proud of you, and how youve been so hospitable to so many of us, welcoming us into your hearts and home.Deep, muddy scarlet brown in color with a mossy growth formation and a distant galaxy shaped head.  Aroma is one of a kind - prunes, plums, nutmeg, coriander and liquefied brown sugar, not to mention the medicinal rum raisin, syrupy boysenberries and angel food cake.  Flavor delivers parallel accents, pulling out plum pudding and concord grape jam.  Notions of chocolate and peat give the honor of a big malt backbone, serving as a tribute to one that God welcomed into his Grace most recently.  Scotch, coriander and pepper round out a spicy profile.  Wholesome, invigorating spice fills the mouths outer rim.  Carbonation is gentle as can be, massaging the malt make-up so passionately.  Juniper, spicy buttery toffee, plum candies and scotch bring up the rear. A fitting anthem to our local leader, his family, and the one who had a profound influence on him and consequently, our local group and so many others on this Web site.  God bless.

poured a deep mahogony red with very little carbonation.  Aroma is very much of coriander with hints of vanilla, cocoa, and some hop character.  Flavor is smooth coriander infused caramel with hints of oak, vanilla, alcohol, and nutmeg.  The lack of carbonation gives a soothness to the beer that is very welcomed.  Definitely unique and worth tasting again.

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2006 Fine nose with tones of caramel, cinnamon, milk chocolate and sweet yoghurt after a little time in the glass; It has a medium body (I expected more), with a bitter sweetness to it. It lacks a hole lot of depth and complexity to be a really good beer; The finish is medium in body, not very long and too bitter.

330ml bottle, Smokeless Joe, Toronto. Deep brown to black pour. Almost no head. Chocolate aroma, sweet. Flavour had some bold malt, more chocolate notes. Light roasted character, sour and burnt notes and some alcohol.

(11.2 oz bottle ("best before June 11") from <A HREF=http://www.ratebeer.com/Place/maine/portland/ target=blank>Downeast Beverage Co.) Pours a murky brown with a small biege head that fades rather quickly. Aroma is sweetish, brown sugar and raisins. Not much lacing. Mouthfeel quite smooth, a bit prickly. Taste: a 2-part experience: part 1 is good, but not extraordinary - mildly sweet with nice mixture of brown sugar and malt, and then part 2, the finish: this is where the beer swoops in for the kill. Oh my never tasted anything like this in a beer - this must be the coriander - its great! Amazing that you dont taste it until the finish. Very nice. No alcohol apparency in flavor whatsoever (despite the 8%). Great.

Bottle. Opaque ruby brown with a large beige head. Nice complex aroma; spices, chocolate, malts and dark fruit. Flavours dont disappoint; chocolate, roasted malts, spices and quite some bitterness near the end. Excellent full body, smooth with some late warming alcohol. Excellent stuff.

Pours Dark brown with a rddish hue. Little to no head or film. Aromas were earthy, spicy and licorice. Some hints of pepper and corrianderas well. Nice complex flavor Dark fruit and sweet malt up front with a nice finish of licorice and smokey malt with some alcohol burn at the end.

UPDATED: FEB 24, 2006 Bottle. Almost completely black with ruby red highlights, a tan head and creamy lacing. Nice floral, malt, bread dough and licorice nose. Good licorice and malt flavor with a some roast/smokey notes a slight hop bitterness to balance things out.  Medium in body with a chewy texture. Great beer
Update:New bottle (It just became available in Texas). The coriander nose sticks out in the nose in a younger sample. It also has a brighter malt flavor when young. I does get much better as it ages. Time to cellar some of this beer.
Interesting aroma, some licoricce, anise.  Pours a very dark brown.  The flavor is very interesting too, spicey, malty, and fruity, some pomegranite.

Pours dark brown and when the head settles, almost black.  Aroma is reminiscent of a barleywine with a hint of something exra.  Beer has slight carbonation and a nice complex and interesting mouth.  Definitely would like to try this again.  Coriander adds some multilayered spice to this brew.

Dark brown with hints of ruby red. Nice foamy head, that disappears sooner than expected.  The nose is sweet and full of dark rye bread, dried fruit (prunes) and chocolate fudge. Taste is roasted and sweet at first with dark bread, fruit and spices (coriander, cardamom?), definitely a hint of licorice. The sweetness is, after a while, balanced by a maltiness with nuts (hazel?) and more spices. Not a very hoppy beer, but very nice and warming (especially on a cold January evening).

Tasted 23/01/2005.  330ml bottle from RW&S, Wellington.  Filtered but unpasteurised.
Deep brown with ruby hints.  Tan head disappears immediately, leaving an oily looking liquid with no noticeable carbonation or lacing.  Big dried apricot aroma, picked up by Fritha, also hints at raisins, chocolate and rum - all in all its a fruitcake.  In the mouth it is sweet, dark-fruits and a hint of bubblegum up front; dry, winey, medicinal herbs and warmly alcoholic through the middle; and long-lingering cinammon and cloes in the finish.  Med-heavy mouthfeel, vaguely tingley carbonation. Would go down well with Haggis...

Deep ruby red, almost black colour. The head looks nice for a few moments, then it sinks. Salty liquorice aroma. Sweet, full-bodied, herbal flavour with notes of hazel-nuts and black currants. Some alcohol flavour shows up in the finish.

BottleHoppy herbal aroma, with notes of chocolate and some dark dried fruits. Salty liqourice is my first impression this time, of this beer I have had many a times. Big body. Molasses? Dark fruits. Hard dark toffee. Lactic sugars. Very soft with a slightly sharp and herbal aftertaste.

Aroma is toasty, of carrots, sweet malt, and dark fruit.  Extreme spicy flavor , salty, and of graham crackers  Mouthfeel is coating with a great aftertaste that last for a while.  Carbonation is low, which I think is appropriate.  Great drinking experience.

Dark brown/ruby. Dense, tan head. Rich, roasty malt, herbal corriander, and spices-aroma. Same kind of flavors with some subtle lactic character, chocolate, dark berry like fruits and alcohol, also. Just had a burp that tasted like a strawberry milk shake. Full, smooth body. Burnt, roasty aftertaste. Excellent.

Red cherry brown ale with a thin moka head, sweet malt and cardamom aroma with licorice notes and grand marnier. Spiced up scotch ale with sweet malt, intense herbal qualities and alcohol warmth. Thin yet complex. Shot but orgasmic while it lasts. Tasted 28/01/05 at Institut Scotch Ale tasting.
Smells like chocolate with fruit.  Very dark with a thick tan head.  Tastes like chocolate right up front with some fruit and sweetness in the finish.  Thick mouthfeel with a lingering flavor.

Brownish amber in colour with fairly low carbonation. Strong aromas of black licorice, coriander, plums, and tar. Its got a very complex flavor profile as well: with more licorice and coriander, orange peel, chocolate, molasses, and some kind of hardwood. The flavors didnt marry quite as well as I would have liked, and I found the finish a bit on the astringent side, but this is one hell of a unique piece of brewing. Merci Lubiere!

Poured a dark brown colour with a small tan head. Aroma of spicies, licourice and malt. Flavor is a little sweet and spicy. Hints of licourice and orange peels too. Some bitterness in the aftertaste with hints of the spices. Very nice!

UPDATED: FEB 16, 2006 Wow, talk about being sorely disappointed in a beer... With a percentile score of 99 Id had high hopes for it. After all, RateBeer has never let me down before. No carbonation.. No head.. Tasted like a flat, malty soda pop.. Maybe I got a bad bottle.. Will try to find another and give it a second chance... 

UPDATE 2/10/06: Ok, tried another bottle of this last night and though better than the first one it was still (IMO) nothing to get excited about. This bottle had a little more carbonation than the first but I was still unable to get any kind of head from it (Oooh... that sounded bad). Also there was a terrible sour taste that permeated my mouth about 3/4 through the glass..

So, this beer is definitely not for me.. Think Ill stick to my Belgians and Trappists...

From a bottle into a snifter. I brought this puppy all the home with me from Hawaii in my carry-on and it seems that it was well-worth the trouble. Beer pours a murky, nearly opaque dark-ash brown with a large, mostly lasting, off-white head. The beer is quite aromatic: The coriander is heavy and backed with moderate malty notes of chocolate, molasses and lightly smokey peat. Theres a yeasty note of fresh-baked bread, a light note of cellar and neat miscellaneous notes of cola and redwood. The flavor starts off moderately sweet and ends with a gentle flip into a lightly bitter finish that terminates with a touch of sourness. The body is medium, the texture is velvety and the carbonation is soft. Yes ... this was a great souviner.

Bottle @ Olney Ale House - Deep crimson brown, thin off white head.  Nice nose of candied spiced orange peel, coriander, and caramel,  with very light peat smoke and earth tones.  Flavor was spicy malt, woodsy, toffee-like, with a  light citrus bitterness rounding this out.  Medium bodied, soft carbonation, malty, spiced finish.  Very nice and absolutely worth a try....

33 cl bottle. Dark brown colour with nice but fast disappearing head. Great sweet aroma of dried fruit, spice and toffee. Nice flavour of herbs and spice combined with notes of caramel and malt. Very pleasant and its hard to detect the alcohol.

Bottle: Poured a deep copper color ale with a huge off-white foamy head with good retention. Aroma of spices, which probably include some coriander and some liquorice, is one of the most enjoyable ever. Taste is also quite distinguishable with the spices mix that marries very well with the molasses malts. One truly unique beer that doesnt disappoint.

saved this one to start the new years celebrations on the eve.  poured a very dark brown, almost black with very minimal head and lacing.  aroma is of soy and a sweetness which ill call mollassas.  taste starts off with malt and finishes with hops.  very balanced with some sweetness as well.  alcohol can be detected in both smell and taste.

A small, tan head is creamy over a deeply cola-colored base. A resounding alcohol presence initially hides any flavorful aspects of the beer, including the coriander and citrus. A revelation of diversity occurs later as the aroma opens up to the aforementioned as well as whisky, pear and caramel. Flavor is slightly sweet, in the way that a whisky can have sweet, rounded edges. Potency prevails but fruitiness definitely competes. Malted qualities really come out as it warms. A syrupy start dissapears in astringency, producing a thinner mouthfeel than at first perceived. Aftertaste is lightly spiced but is mainly only esters.


<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Wine & Spirits, Countryside, IL 60525<font size=-1>

Rich, sweet dark chocolate and roasted malt aroma. Smells delicious! Nearly opaque, dark brown body with very small, although mostly lasting, off-white head. No lace. Very unique flavor. Bitter-sweet chocolate, not unlike the small chocolate wafer I had at the Garden Court Hotel in Palo Alto, CA last weekend. Im not overly familiar with the flavor of coriander, so I cant comment intelligently on whether or not coriander is evident in this brew. However, I can say that it is very well done and possibly worth the $6.49 I paid for a 330ml bottle of it. Dryer in taste than the aroma would suggest, and some sourness from the bitter-sweet aspect. Becomes really nice when it warms.

Dark brown with a bubbly head. Exotic, complex spicy aroma with sweet, sugary background notes. The taste is caressing and gentle with liquorice, raisins and honey. Youd never guess this came from Scotland.

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2007 Very dark brown colour with thin white head. Nice choc orange aroma. Good raisins too, gorgeous smell on this beer. The fruit is intense with good dry malty flavour. Finish has juicy dark fruits and oranges. Great beer and touch of ginger spice. 4.8/5.0

Re-rate: bottle from Utobeer.  I love the aroma, I love the big smile it puts on my face.  But its a 4.4/5 and not as high as I had it before.  But I do love it.  I love the ginger spice and wide/deep malts.  But mostly cos it makes me smile.

Huge wonderful, yet subtle, spicey nose.  Poured flat (2009 edition) and dark amber.  The flavor is slight and light -- impressive, but not the huge malt bomb that most beers from scotland hit you with.

Wonderful lack of sweetness too.

Bottle - sampled at the Copenhagen beerfestival 2005
Dark chestnut, low tanned head.
Lovely honeyish and fruity aroma.
Fruity tropical, wild flower tastenotes - a bit wood.
Medium body, mouthfeel could be slightly fatter.

Deep redish brown color with a nice dark head.  Very herbal aroma, the coriander really stands out. It also stands out in the flavor.  Sometimes this can take away from a beer but Traquair draws a nice balance between the herbals and the maltiness of Scottish ale.  Nice as a pre-meal beer.  Im not sure how well it would work with food.  Might be nice to cook with however.

Complex flavour for certain, particularly if one likes things that reek of chemicals upon opening, and taste as though someone left a moldy ham sandwich in the bottle.  Quite unpleasant, bordering on toxic.  One wonders how this might EVER be good; no doubt I may have gotten a poor bottle (said good until July 2011...love that freshness marking!), but its difficult for me to believe that there could be anything redeeming to this.

Bottle: Pours kind of a deep red/brown. medium sized light colored head. You can smell the corriander, and certainly taste it. Very little, if any hop presence. It does feel a bit more like a wine, but that doesnt bother me any.

Pours medium purple, very wine-like texture. Light head and carbonation. Beautiful coloring. Borders on a 5.

Nose is a complex bouquet of floral esters and faint hints of grape. Hard to explain, but almost like the worlds greatest air freshener. Unlike any other beer Ive ever come across, and if Traquair ever comes out with "new car" Im all aboard.

Mouthfeel: thin and lightly carbonated.

Goes down almost like wine with very littly carbonation and zero hop presence. Most of the action is in the malt and coriander flavoring. The malt increases as the swallow finishes and this is what offsets the mildly cloying sweetness, thereby giving the beer its backbone. The initial taste almost feels like flavored soda water.

With a great balance of abv and solid but not overwhelming taste, I could drink this all day, or at least until nappy nappy time.
It would be a fantastic ale, if it wasnt for the corriander. Which gave the entire ale something extra that it trully did not need.
Complex flavor -- probably supposed to be spicy, but I find it more like drinking perfume.  Strange -- this is a highly rated beer. Maybe I got a bad bottle... The colour is nice though.

Bottled:
Parfumed, sweet malty flavor. Astringent, light sourly. Dry , light hoppy finish.

Bouteille-Une brune aux reflets rouge. Odeur caramelisé et de fruits. Mousse inexistante. Fort goût dalcool et de fruits sauvages.--Bottle-Brown with red reflections. Caramilzed and wild frits aromas. No head. Strong taste of alcool and wild fruits.

Bottled.
Clear brown coloured with a medium sized off white head.
Sweet aroma of malts, caramel and spices.
Sweet flavour of spices, butterscotch, liquorice and alcohol with notes of dried fruits.

pronounced woody, well-balanced not dominant in bitterness or sweetness, chocolate malt, toffee,barley, spice, smoke. Rich, well-carbonated. Medium mouthfeel, not overwhelming in spicyness, but its there: corriander, orange peel, and a drop of cinammon, pepper and cloves.

UPDATED: NOV 19, 2005 A dark brown/ black hue.  Very thin white lacing lingering. Aroma of spices and brown sugar. Tastes of dark fruits(raisins, plum, cherries) and maybe some chocolate.  Palate is thin, but seems to balance the unique flavors of the beer nicely.  Youre kind of glad the feel isnt syrupy or thick.  This beer seems very balanced.  Never had anything like it.

Rating #200. Pours a very deep brown with little head. Massive aroma of coriander comes flying out at you and continues to throughout the life of the beer. Closer inspection shows other spices, maltiness, cherry. Flavor is thick, caramelly malt, coriander, toffee, maybe a touch of cherry and plum. Palate initially came off as being thin but the more I drink the better it seems to suit the beer. A special treat Im glad I chose for 200.

bottle. Ciros. copper-ruby body with a small short-lasting off-white head. very nice aroma that fills the room and senses - there is some lactic acidity, cherry, chocolate, caramel, and liberal spices. complex full body - light chocolate with a dominant fruit component. a very well spiced beer - very tasty. soft malt and comforting warm alcohol. very nice.

Bottle 330ml. Poured a clear brown color with a small off-white head that diminished quickly. Good aroma of coriander, raisin and malt. Medium body with smooth texture. Good fruity bitter sweet flavor with long pleasing finish. Interesting brew.

Bottle. Pours a surprisingly dark, cloudy amber with very small head. It smells of coriander, malt, and raisin. The flavor is very sweet, like brown sugar, up front. Following that are barley, some coriander (though not as much as in the nose), and quite a bit of wood. There is a bit of alcohol in the finish. Definitely unique, this.

Bottle. Pours a very dark brown with red hues and a small light-brown head. Aroma is very fruity, particularly dark fruit along with spices, caramel malt and a hint of molasses. What a delightful aroma that is. The flavour is nothing to scoff at either: a complex mix of spices, dark fruit, malt and maybe even some chocolate -- quite hard to pin down but it tastes great. Full bodied, goes down really easy and theres no sign of that 8% alcohol. A truly unique and tasty beer and one I look forward to having again.

330 ml bottle.  Dark Dark pour with no head.  Aromas were very much molassas and dark cherry/currant.  Flavors really brought in the spice.  More currant to make it a bit vinous.  Pretty tasty to the finish.  Good Stuff.
UPDATED: FEB 8, 2006 At last I could try it, it was dark, nice, like toasted barleys, but not sure. A little sweet but just in a backtaste.

Traquair has a nice floral aroma.  The color is a deep cloudy black.  However there was almost no head.  The taste of coriander comes through nicely and the finish has a roasted coffee quality.  The aftertaste is pleasent and lingers.

Hazy, very dark brown with some lacing and wisps.  Very floral aroma with some corriander, sherry and dark, sweet malt.  Fairly sweet flavour with woody bitterness and extremely floral.  Corriander.  Some dark malt character, molasses, medicinal anise.  Excellent balance of bitter and sweet and, if anything, too floral.  Medium body, moderate carbonation with a lingering anise flavour.

Bottle. Dark mahogony beer with a little beige head. Spice and malt aroma. Rich stone fruit, malt, and slight spice flavor. Low carbonation. Nice simple, but full mouthfeel. Very good - if anytyhing, it could use more depth, but thats nitpicking.

UPDATED: MAY 21, 2009 A Mes rate: 
33cl bottle from Utobeer. Wow. Ok I am still new to good quality British beer but this is clearly a stormer. Aroma is all over the place with spice (nutmeg and cinnamon), celary salt, Terrys chocoalte orange and lots of other good stuff. Appearance wise it is the deepest red, almost black and opaque. The head vanished quickly otherwise it may have been my first for a 5. This is complex stuff. I almost dont know where to start. The coriander is fairly apparent as is spice, heather, orange zest, christmas pudding, liquorice and lots of other wonderful flavours. Sweet and heavy on the alcohol without ever being offensive. Mouthfeel is equally impressive, all chunky and warm. Finish is as good as anything I can think of and lasts for days!. A sweet and creamy kick of alcohol followed by all the spices and mellowing out to orange (and ginger maybe?) and eventually that of a whisky (well it is Scottish). Damn I could go on all day. The warmth in my belly just wraps it up. So so very very good.

The aroma is toasted malt, coffee and caramel. The appearance is cloudy and brown and it has a small head. The flavor is bitter with coffee and chocolate and coriander. Palate is thick and the aftertaste is quite herbal. An interesting beer but overrated here.

Very dark brown body with a small head that disappears quickly. Complex aroma with malts, herbs, crème bruleé..full sweet taste with those herbs again (Im just bad in naming those) and roasted malts to finish..lovely..pretty wellbodied. Very good beer!

12oz - best before June 2011 - Aroma is sweet coriander, carmel malt, clove, and candi sugar.  Pours a deep brown with a medium off-white head and great lacing.  Flavor is spicier than the aroma.  Pepper, clove, corinader, carmel malt, and even a little roasted chocolate malt.  Palate is creamy and smooth.  A very nice drinking brew.
Dark brown color with minimal tan head.  Spicy malty aroma.  Coriander adds a long bitter aftertaste that is better than it sounds.  OK beer.
Dark, deep brown color with a reasonably steady head. Both aroma and flavor are wonderfully rich. Lots of dried fruit and a great balance.

My first beer for the style. Dark reddish brown, small head. Aroma is floral and chocolatey. Also spicy... obviously. Still, I wasnt a fan of this. I had this next to JW Lees Harvest Ale 2001 and this one was easily worse for me. I probably dont have the palate for this style yet as its my first, and this is the 100th percentile... meaning its probably pretty complex.

A really outstanding ale. Roasted malt, a hint of smoke, some aniseed, too. Warming like a shot of whisky or a glass of port. Bittersweet, rich and malty. The hops are hard to identify, but they are there balancing the brew. I wouldnt want many at one sitting, but this ale has entered my top 20. Alcohol content of 8%, and this is needed to carry the maximum flavour. Hard to classify, this, but it is definetely a beer for grownups.

Sampled from a bottle, I believe an 04 vintage. Sampling this one, frankly, was a bit of a letdown. Ive thoroughly enjoyed the likes of Town Hall Wee Heavy in the past and other more readily available Scotish styles such as Founders Dirty Bastard and Robert the Bruce. This one reminded me quite a bit of Lake Louies Warped Speed, yet without some of the more positive characteristics of WS. Perhaps its the coriander Im objecting to, although in general it seemed this lacked the depth of some of the other Scotchs. On the palate, brown sugar and caramel and date. Some maple syrup and dried cherry sweetness on the finish with a bit of a hop bite to keep things lingering. Not bad, but certainly not my first choice for a $5 bottle.
No head.  Coca Cola Color.  Smells like stewed prunes.  Taste is sweet meld of Coriander and spicey sweet pruney malt.

UPDATED: SEP 26, 2005 Pours an opaque dark brown, to dark amber color.  It is topped by a wispy brown head that is barely there.  The aroma is a mix of earthy spice notes and rich concentrated fruit notes.  I get aromatic notes of fig, prunes, dried cranberries, raisins, coriander, and cherry liquor.  The aroma is quite nice and rich, and quite intrigueing, I am definitely spending quite a bit of time just smelling the wonderful aroma on this beer.  The beer is only lightly sweet, but still finishes with the rich fruity notes that were found in the nose.  The finish also has that earthy spice note of coriander.  The taste does not quite live up to the wonderful aroma, but it is still quite satisfying.  I get notes of prunes, raisins, and figs.  This beer is quite good, though I would certainly wish that the flavor was as rich and intrigueing as the aroma.

<font size=-4>Purchased via mail order: <a href=http://www.liquidsolutions.ws/main/>Liq Solutions<font size=-1>

Quite the ale. Deep garnet and molasses. White headed and coated with small treacly bubbles. Head dissipates. Cherries, caramel and brand, slight vanilla rum edge. The coriander is immensely prevalent in the nose adding a floral, citrus presence to the butterscotch and peat. Massive maraschino cherries.
The coriander lays very flat on the tongue, almost as an afterthought behind the stickiness of the malt. Sweet and yet earthy. Carbonated and yet slick as motor oil. Mysterious. Aftertaste lingers with dripping cherries.
Excellent brew.
G

Pour is a very muddy looking brown.  Aroma is sweet and fruity with lots of dark fruit esters and toped off with a citrusy coriander.  Flavor is very complex.  Very sweet on the swallow and then the spices hit you.   Coriander and a bit of dark plum rests on your tounge after the swallow. There is a lot more in here but i have not made up my mind as to what it is.   A very nice but pricy beer experience.  Every swallow is a different pleasure for the sences.

33ml ($5.99) mahagony almost purple color. thin head that disapates rapidly. fruity esters in nose, dates, plums, and rasberries.  fruit up front with caramel and malt backbone, with a warming ethanol finish. much thinner on the mouth than I would have expected. great beer.

At chesters in Hamilton, Ontario with Joey Capps and Jadoreblanche. Body is opaque black, with a thin off white head. Aromas are minty, candies, roasted caramel malt. Awesome. Taste is sweet, cotton candy, minty. Caramel. Finish is smooth. Full bodied, complex, and a great beer. Wow! Thanks for suggesting this one Joe!

Bottled, stored for 3 years.
Opaque, black with thin beige head.
Flowery aroma witth notes of chocolate, heather, roasted malt, licorice and a hint of smoke.
Flowery flavorwith notes of pepper, pears, tropical fruits, syrup. Some sweetness. Dry with a decent bitterness.

The bottle poured a deep garnet slightly cloudy beer. It was bottle conditioned. The head was frothy and didnt last long leaving no lacing on the glass. The aroma is a wonderful sweet-spicy mixture. The coriander comes through loud and clear accompanied by sweet dried fruits and pepper. The body was full with light carbonation and a smooth texture. The flavor starts off with an almost sweet candy-like taste that matures toward the middle revealing the alcohol warmth and pepper. The finish is very long but gentle.
