UPDATED: NOV 3, 2005 Robe auburn foncée et claire aux reflets roux surmontée dune mousse beige qui sestompe. Arômês de scotch, de cassis et dépices. Saveurs de cassis, de sucre brun, de vin et dépices. Corps bien présent.

VERY dark, good bead resulting in a big frothy long lasting head, which leaves a nice lacework. Nose is delicately spiced, whereas the palate is big and quite complex, with the spice character coming to the fore...and lasting through to the finish. A distinctive, powerful brew from the back of beyond. FANTASTIC!!!!

bottle best before 2011. pours black with minimal head no lacing. aroma is dark fruits taste is fairly nonexistent. after taste is plums and a little coriander.you can taste the alcohol. there is barley any carbonation. i am shocked this ranked so high. or mabye its just me.
Bottle. Aromas of plums, prunes, red grapes and a hint of coriander. In the mouth this is not fullbodied - it is massive! Soft and thick. A great brew.

Pours a dark brown with a very thin head. The aroma of coriander was apparent even during the pour. What the hell is coriander anyway? The result was a toasted sweet malt with a yeasty spice pumpkin bread smell. Wow! The taste immediately transported me back to my Scottish origins and I had an image of sitting at an old country B&B and having ordered this magnificant brew on tap and revelling in the coup of this unexpected experience. This stuff is great and I can sense wildly addictive. This glass disappointently disappeared in the ether of existance and begged to be revisited. This is the best beer Ive ever drank and even as subjective as that is, I stand by it. I also need more...
bottled, dark brown w/ biege head.  intense nose of malt and caramel w/ a hint of spice.  complex, malty body.

Pours very dark reddish-brown with a one-finger off-white head. Slight lacing. Very floral and spicy aroma, with rosemary and heather vying for dominance. Some toffee and cola is there, as well. Toward the middle of the glass, bready malts are coaxed out with some swirling. The rosemary is in the flavor, this time side-by-side with coriander. Slight roasted malt flavors. No hoppiness to speak of. My burps taste like rose petals. Full mouthfeel but a flavor thats a bit of a let-down after the excellent aroma. Still very good. Surprisingly drinkable, unless you consider the price.
nice and spicy. very thick and sat well in my mouth. had hints of corriander and pepper but was a bit salty.

UPDATED: JUN 14, 2007 This smells good. I dont know what coriander smells like so Ill guess that, but there is ample caramel/chocolate and dark fruit as well. This is really a fantastic smelling beer. Garnet brown in color. Close to headless. Wow that is good. Huge black licorice flavors....more coriander-something I cant peg whatever it is....THIS IS TASTY!  Anise, chocolate/caramel and prunes and raisins. Wow man I feel like an arse for waiting so long to try this. I had the chance about a million times. Very good mouth feel too. This is a great beer!

Burgandy pour with a little creamy head.  Aroma was dominated by the coriander, with was quite pleasant.  Very complex flavor with some spices including light coriander, caramel, and a little bread.  Nicely balanced malt backbone.  Very smooth mouthfeel.  Coriander came back in the nice long finish.

Wow, what a delicious beer. I had trouble finding this for a little while, but it was certainly worth the wait. Flavor is rich, complex, and spicy. I also got some smokey hints too. One of the best I have had in a while.

Aroma:Big caramel aroma.....
Appearance:Redish brown,good head....
Flavor:Caramel,i not found the coriander....

Good till 2011! I might have to go buy a few more just to age them. Nice dark pour, almost stout like with a medium head and not much lacing. Taste is smooth and soft with and end of small bitter. Lots of blended citrus with caramel, and coriander. Roasted nuts, and some licorice layed in there over a scotch like finish. mmm..only bad thing I could find about this thing is the price. 4.99 (O_O)

UPDATED: AUG 15, 2005 Bottle (330ml).  Dark amber pour, delicate lace head, complex aromas and tastes.  Very sweet.  Blend of vanilla (faint), Pez candy(!) and burnt or roasted malt with a complex of spices in the finish.  Not quite a dessert beer, but one to savour when up for something different.

Poured a mahogany red color with a small, off white head that left light lacing on the glass.  Aroma of caramel malts, orange peel, and coriander.  Taste of more citrus and coriander, caramel, light smoke and roast, no alcohol present, and a velvetty mouthfeel.

Pours a dark waknut color body with a medium, tan head.  Aroma is molasses, carmel, and oranges.  Flavors are toasted malts, carmel, pecans, molasses, black licorice, and oranges with peels.  An awesome Scotch with quite a unique twist!

Pours a deep rusted brown, hazy.  Decent head that dissapears quickly.  Aroma is spicy and dark, dark malts, caramel, licorice, coriander, maple, and a hint of orange.  Flavor is nearly identical, licorice prominent as is coriander.  Very good.

UPDATED: SEP 11, 2007 Poured into a lager glass. Deep reddish brown color. Not quite opaque. Moderately thick head that went down into a consistent yet small off white head. Molasses is apparent in the aroma. The flavor starts out with that same obvious molasses flavor. But the finish is all spicey coriander and it rounds this beer off nicely. I feel like each sip challenges my tastebuds. A beer such as this gives me a new appreciation of the art of beer.

UPDATED: AUG 24, 2005 I cant help but be dissapointed here, in the nicest possible way. I coming from scotland should probably think this is the best scotish beer as every1 else seems to think so. But its just too....hardcore...for lack of words.
Aroma is molasses, grassey, stable yard, corriander and bready, all in 1 swoop.
Taste is stupidly complex, gettin on a good rochefort 10 for complexness. Alcohol is very well hidden aswel, but i just find the bitter sweetness of the dark chocolate taste overpowering and hard to finish.
Ill need to try it again to see how it goes, nice beer and im proud of its complexness concidering the brewary is less the 50 miles away, but just not for me i suppose.
UPDATED: MAY 20, 2005 Sweet smell but a suprisingly less sweet taste. coriander.  Great mouthfeel, dry, thick pallate.

UPDATED: JUL 3, 2005 (Bottle 33 cl) Very dark, but not black - theres a reddish tint in there somewhere. The head is pretty much non-exiisting and the level of carbonation is very low. Pleasant, spicy nose. Dry, malty and slightly bitter with some indefinable but very delicate spices in the aroma. Reminds me of some of the best Belgian trappists. And I just read, that a "Blair Ale" has been brewed in support of the Labour Party election campaign. Way to go - it worked.... 200405

The first of 2 top 100 beers Ill be sampling tonight.  This ones label says "Best before June 2011."  Pours burnt sienna (deep brown, not copper or amber) with medium, nice-looking off-white head.  Aroma of caramel malt, dark fruit, nuts, cognac, earthy peaty, spices.  Complex aroma.  Tastes caramel malty, with a chocolaty, dark fruit and spice presence.  The mouthfeel is velvety and complex.  As it warms, more nuts and spices emerge to couple with the dark fruit.  Unique, complex, and delicious!

Deep ruby chestnut brown, this beer has a malty nose. A quickly dissipating white head floats on the ample body of this brew. Slightly tart with malty sweetness throughout, the coriander spiciness blends well. Smooth and thick, this brew is a glassfull of malty goodness. Molasses plays a prominent role.
Dark ruby with fast disapearing head. Aroma has hints of fruits and anis. Balanced sweetness with spices and lasting aftertaste

11.2 oz. bottle.  Best before June 2011.  Dark brown pour with small light-tan creamy head.  Aroma of milk chocolate, licorice, coriander and some alcohol.  Smells a little like a Cadbury Creme Egg.  My girlfriend says it smells like soy sauce.  This is smooth and thick.  The coriander is definitely there in the taste.  Also present is some milk chocolate, cocoa, some molasses and anise.  Nice and sweet and malty with a little bitterness.  A bit of a warming sensation at the end.  Unique and excellent stuff.

Pours dark brown with almost a reddish hue.  Thin tan head.  Nose is licorice, spicy and tones of maltiness.  Flavor is corriander, nutmeg and banana.  Reminiscent of a good German Hefeweizen.  But just then, tha flavor turns to chocolate and caremel.  Nice dry finish.

The simple black and white label in classic old fashioned woodcut style speaks of an era, long gone. Im preparing for a new horizon in beer, pairing my (current) favorite style Scotch Ale, with the musky enjoyable coriander. This lady pours deep and dark, with that lovely ruby glint in the corner of the glass. Held to the light, its more off a blood red glow, with a fastly diminishing head riding shotgun. My nose fails to detect much of a beamingly distinct aroma. Faintly wafting up my nostrils is a puckery stale malt. This beer has coriander in it? Maybe its not supposed to overshadow the rich tones of the malt, but this beer is really stretching to have coriander in its register. Im mostly detecting it as it smacks on a my palate, a little of that musty spice aftertaste. Sourness prevails right away, smoothing out into a slightly bitter toasted coating. Butter. Its there. This is a quality that I think Ive found in beers that have a high alcohol content, but have seen too much time on a store shelf. It goes along with a meaty quality described in some aged beers. That coriander is coming out a little more now, as a venerable limey hint on my tounge. Im just noticing the stillness of this beer. I wish I could say better things, but this beer doesnt light my fire. Maybe it saw too much florescent light.

Bottle from Hogs Back. Pours a strange clear coke colour with a little, thin and sparse head. Wonderful aroma of spice and herbal sweetness. Flavour is suprisingly mild and with only medium spice presence (very balanced with it), malt sweetness, apparent alcohol and some background coffee. Smooth and suprisingly good.

UPDATED: JAN 28, 2007 Pours brown with a small head that lingers.  Nose is strong with elements of raisins, prunes, coffee and nuts.  Taste is of coconuts, nutmeg, bananas, coriander, rosted malts and afterhints of pepper and spices.  This ones a great beer and my personal favorite to date!

Wow, I guess there is coriander in this puppy.  Smells mildly like a wit, but it also has chocolate notes in the nose as well.  Quite sweet and almost candy-like aroma.  Perhaps there is some mintiness as well.  This thing has a very unique and wonderful aroma.  Moderately opaque mahogany color with a small light tan head.  Wow, this is a very different beer.  Mild hints of lemony coriander, turning chocolatey/coffee-ish with nice thick roasted notes.  Finishes late late with a smoked roastiness and mild chocolates.  The coriander also lingers on and on.  I like this A LOT more than their House Ale.  Very complex, roasty, and tasty!!

UPDATED: MAY 23, 2005 [bottle: peckhams]  pours dark, almost black with a medium tan head. the nose is molasses, roasted carrots, spices, a little caramel, slightly meaty with the faintest notes of coffee and liquorice. exceptionally well bodied with a long finish.
dark brown pour with a thin tan head.  sweet malty nose of spice.  milly rich palate full bodied, fruitcake, spice and brown sugar molasses. quite good and a nice surprise.

Pours dark brown with a tall tan head. Malt and plenty of hop aroma with spicy and herby tones. Sweet malty flavor with a good spicyness. Soft and well-balanced with a dry finish. Low on carbonation. Good one!

Opaque dark brown w/ reddish hue. Light brown foam. Sweet, malty, spicy aroma w/ hints of licorice, caramel, & smoke. Thick, chewy, slightly syrupy feel. Complex, spicy flavour of licorice, molasses, caramel, port, dried fruit, & chocolate. Dry, peppery finish.
Dark brown/red with a nice frothy head. A complex aroma, some citrus, spicies and lots of herbs. Flavour is citrus, herbs and chocolate.  A lot going on.  Ends dry.

Bottled.  Pours a reddish brown color with no head.  Without tasting it, Id guess its going to taste watery for some reason.  Spicy aromas with notes of hairspray...yes, hairspray.  Big malt sweetness with tons of spice and chocolate although I dont really pick out the coriander. Syrupy sweet mouth feel.  Its definitely not watery.  A little too carbonated IMHO.

Pours very dark brown with a small lasting tan head. Strong toffee and herb aroma. Lovely sweet toffee flavour, yet not in any way cloying! Full bodied, quite smooth too. Some great spicy herbal notes, and quite fruity too. Really tasty stuff.
Pours dark chocolate brown. Rich sweet, spiced grassy aroma. Full bodied, nice texture. Full flavored but not bold. Rather soft, complex approach.
Pours dark brown with no head. The aroma is very spicy with corianders, coffee lakrids and a bit of smoke. Very soft, not much carbonation. Great schottish ale!
Purple-black liquor with a creamy, off-white, mostly diminishing head.  The aroma is malty, rooty and coffee-like and the body is mildly sweet with a lingering spice.
Dark brown with a hint of red, some nice head.  Taste is clovey,  fruitcake as mentioned, brown sugar and liqorice. Alcohol is very well hidden, this goes down smooth.

This was a really nice brew, pours a dark copper with a thin off-white head that lasts. Smells kinda like rum raisin cake, lots of brown sugar, alcohol, dark fruits, kinda smokey and rummy. Taste starts with some smokey malts, warming on the palate brings out dark fruit and a big sweetness. Finishes very well balanced for all the sweetness.
Very strange aroma - nuts?  Beautiful cream head w/brown color.  I dont know what coriander is, but i think it might be raspberries. Very good.

Pouring a deep, near solid brown with a light dusting of a tan head, this has a rich, earthy malt aroma.  Thick mothfeel with a rough edge nonetheless, this has a huge malty flavor with some caramel notes and some serious perppery spicing to it.  With its dry alcohol finish, this is a real warmer.  Why the light coriander spicing turns this into a "Spice/Herb/Vegetable" is beyond me.  This is a great tasting Scotch ale.
UPDATED: MAR 13, 2005 Very rich and spicy, with a powerful coriander flavor. I wouldve liked it to be less syrupy, and more refreshing.  Still very good.

Thanks to Kawa for sending this one my way!  Dark brown, cola like appearance, slight head.  Different aroma from anything else Ive ever encountered, sort of a molasses, spice, vegetal thing that I couldnt quite get my head around, including an alcohol note.  Flavor was even more surprising.  A bit of cola, but the predominant flavor was tootsie roll, sort of like Kahlua and chocolate liquor mixed with some curacao.  Also a note of toffee.  Glad to have tried this, would be interesting to age out.

Pour is a brownish red that is very deep in appearance.  No head whatsoever.  Looks flat.  Nice pleasent berry flavor.  There is no  carbonation.  I dont know if this bottle leaked or what, but its completely flat.  This killed it for me.
Pours dark brown with no head. Coriander all over the place. Hard to taste anything else. Strangely I like this brew overall even though its a bit one-dimensional.
Dark brown colour with light brown head. Malty and spicy aroma with hints of anis. Flavor is sweet and spicy with hints of licorice.

Poured a cloudy, dark brown with an orange tint at the edges. Small off white head. Aromas and tastes of molasses, spices, soy sauce, and light lemon. Additional flavors of dark fruits (plums and raisins). A little earthy. Light alcohol in the finish.

01.16.05  Bottle best by 06/09  Dark, ruby brown pour with small tan head.  Tasty aromas of orange and spice, black tea, lemon, herbal, yummm!  Flavors are woodsy and orangey with some soy and light pitch.  Good stuff, can be simple or complex as mood dictates, earthy and eminently enjoyable.

this was an awesome brew to drink at the end of my session.  sweet spicy smell as well as taste.  red colored pour resembling that of a scotch ale.  rich and very sweet, almost too sweet, this is one to be consumed in low quantities.  certainly not a session beer.  very interesting and hugely complex brew.  not bad at all.

Not a lot to look at with a tan, anemic head and only a soft aroma of molasses and Cointreau.  Mouth  is warm and sharp, with flavor (as the previous poster stated) of burnt oranges.  I also add chocolate-orange candy with a lingering complex assortment of Whitmans Sampler flavors of dried fruit candies.  Also a bit of biscuits and a hint of smoke.  Put me up in a castle with a cask of this, a boar and a spit and some ladies in waiting and Im set.

Deep dark opaque brown with burnt-orange edges, barely any head even with a vigorous pour, obvious coriander flavor with other spice notes, dark fruits, cola, herbaceous hop flavor, interesting balanced ale, flavor combinations unusual but enjoyable and warming.

Bottle:  Real nice balance of malt, fruit, cola syrup, and spice aromas.  Pours a semi-transparent dark red with a nice tan head with very good retention.   Flavors are not as strong as I expected based on the aroma.   Lightly malty (a little cherry) with a nice spice finish.  Spice finish is peppery and ginger..

Pours a dark opaque brownish red with decent light brown head that dissipates quickly.  Very complex aroma of malts, spices, fruits, and licorice.  Very bizzare flavors of coriander and spice, although I cant figure out what it is.  No hop aromas or flavors discernible.  Has a definite twang in the afteraste that leaves me smacking the roof of my mouth with my tongue.  Does have an alcohol warmth to it.  Overall a good interesting brew, but I dont think I could drink more than one in a sitting.

poured into a pint glass and gave off a murky top with a lovely drak red bottom.i got an aroma of twizzlers (as dr nate said.very well put sir)coriander,and malts.no head to speak of.i was perpelxed by the flavor.i was given coriander,licorice,butterscotch,abd malts.this is very interesting,and pretty damn good.

Mild sweet aroma, spicy, licorice, Twizzlers, coriander. Good malty base but subdued, floral nose. Dark brown wih some haze, thin lacing tan head. Medium heavy watery body with medium carbonation. A bit thin, starts with mild sweetness, floral and spicy. Low acidity and licorice coriander biterness. Chocolate herbal notes throughout. Really reminds me of Belgian strong ale, abt. Good bitter finish and after but not too deep in character.

bottle, thanks duff. dark purple. pretty massive aroma - paw paw, rockmelon, coriander, ginger, cardamom, even a bit of lemongrass. very tasty - raisins, chocolate, mango. not much sign of alcohol and quite a spicy lemongrass finish. delicious

Very nice. Aroma was strongly tinged with coriander and other spices. 

Coriander was also strong in the flavor but complimented a well-crafted ale. 

This isnt one of my favorite styles of ale, but this is definitely well-worth trying, if you can find it.

deep hazy brown, light solid head.  very spicy aroma, not unlike bells eccentric ale.  brown sugar, molasses, light hops.  very interesting flavor, molasses again, with other sweet spices surfacing. some fruits like cherry and raspberry worth a shot to drink once or twice.  very solid beer but not a standout.  tastes better as it warms, giving off some interesting cotton candy notes.

I am glad that I am drinking this in the northern hemisphere. There is a distinct mulled wine note to this one. It could be interesting to warm this up and drink it as such. Good appearance despite the disappearing head. Distinct coriander spiciness on the nose and subtle background of toffee. The ABV is clear in the mouthfeel and warming characterisitcs as it goes down. This is one of those beers that is one an occasion only. I am drinking this with some pate and Danish blue cheese which holds its own against both. I think this is more of an interesting beer than a top 2 percentiler.
user_location: Potts Point, New South Wales, AUSTRALIA

text: Pours a dark brownish red with a head that disappears quickly. Aroma of sweet red wine, caramel, cirtus, amd a slight spice. Flavor is malt, caramel, sweet red wine, dark fruits, toffee, and a slight spice.

Solid aroma that is a mix of styles (dubbel, porter, traditional ale).  The pour isreddish black with s thing ring of lasting and lacing head.  The flavor matches the nose (raisins, prune, spice), then dives immediately into a dry, smoked peat - like an old cigar.  The tobacco is what ultimately remains on the tongue, but only briefly.  There is so much going on herem that Id add detail with every bottle.  Unfortunately, the taste was far short of the expense, so there wont be many more opportunities with this one.

Dark Red.  Aroma of dried fruits (raisins), baby puke, ginger, plums and sharp coriander.  Very flavorful.  Notes of fruits (plums, coriander, wood, other spices, melon and ginger.  Complex malt body.  A complex beer in general and a very nice sampling.

Brown with ruby highlights, minimal head. Nice aroma with the obvious coriander, caramel malt, mustard. More of that in the flavor. Similar to the house ale, but better. The coriander confuses the brain into thinking you are drinking a Belgian white, with brown food color apparently. Relatively full body, chocolate hints, caramel, and a massive coriander attack. Just that simple ingredient addition really changes this beer. A great beer.
A nice complex brew that favors a little age. I found the brew had a pleasant aroma and a good mouthfeel. It reminded me of some belgians but frankly better.

Dark dark brown opaque pour, little/no head.  Great aroma laced with cocoa and some rich spices.  Medium body, first pull is very malts and spice, with a skrait up long and spicy aftertaste.  Further indulgence reveals more hops and a rich full flavor well blended.  A most enjoyable beer, though a bit pricey.

dark brown/rootbeer brown appearance; thin to medium palate; aroma is abundant of spices, some sour and some fruity hints; flavor is quite similar with definite spices, and some citrus hints (lemon?)  very good beer

Deep brown body with orange-red highlights at the edges.  Thin light tan head.  Very spicy aroma with soy, wood, and fresh bread dough complimenting the coriander.  Heavily spiced flavor with earthy yeast flavors, a touch of soy, and woody neutral malts.  Kind of like a pumpernickel bread with coriander.  Quite good.

This is just one of those beers that I have had so exceedingly available that I was never intrigued enough too sit down, drink and rate. What a fool I was! 
I have aged this one bottle for over a year. I stuck it in my cellar, looked at it every day when I opened the door, and just never decided to crack the capt.
Pours a full-bodied brown with edges of amber and a delicate light tan head. The aroma and flavor convey a magnificent brilliance of toffee, caramel, coco, the toasty yeastiness of a fresh pumpernickel loaf, a sweetness of Coca Cola syrup, the sweet smokiness of molasses, hints of home ground of coconut, a light touch of coffee bean, the Unforgettable spiciness of fresh ginger, and most notably, a renowned semi muted addition of coriander its F-ing Phenomenal! I wish the body were just a bit more creamy, but man, this beer is TOTALLY addicting! I even pick up a hint of vanilla. WOW! I wish I had not put this rating off for the past 12 months because this beers uniqueness places it as a World Class beer in my books!

Wow - what the hell is going on in that aroma. Its full of ginger and nutmeg and molasses and rich dark fruits and then some more spices. Rich brown colour that pulls you in like the light. Flavour moves around too, from the maltiness to a bitter-tinged spiciness. Slightly sweet finish with evident alcohol. Very nice.
Much better than the house ale. the spice covers the ill flavors from pasteurization.  Good, but not world class.
Bottled(330ml). -malty, fruity and spicy, alcohol hints with nice spiced coriander flavor, moderately bitter finish, excellant brew

A very dark, but clear brown color with a small beige head. Nice lacing. Sweet spicy scent, almost a soy sauce scent.
Sweet without being syrupy, floral hoppiness and spice follow. Very tasty, Im happy to have found this one way over here!

Pours a dark brown with not much of a head. The aroma of this brew is wonderful sweet malts, spices and plenty more. Nicely balanced flavours of malt, raisins, spices and although it didnt give much of a head it still had a nice soft carbonation to it. What gives this beer a high rating from me is the blended balance of the flavours. Very well crafted and tasty.
Dark brown color, sweet light roasted fruity aroma, heavy sweet taste, full body, long sweet finish.

Dark brown in colour, with a beige foamy head that disappears rather quickly. Malty, fruity and spicy in the nose with hints of alcohol and old wood.  Quite sweet and a bit sour, full bodied and a nice hoppy finish.

Poured brownish amber with not much of a tan head...smelled of corriander and new leather boots and I too got notes of lime...taste is full of spice and fruits...small notes of nuts and licorice...finish is a little cloying though...this might be a tad over rated...

I have a hard time describing this beer but I know one thing for sure: This is an excellent brew! Very complex and pleasant nose. Extremely malty and spicy flavour with notes of dark berries (black currants, bilberries). The finish is not particularly bitter but the beer is still nicely balanced. Excellent stuff!
Brown color with a beige head. The taste is a very nice sweet body with spices and slight nutty notes. The flavour is very complex and nice.
Bottle. Sweet perfumy aroma with some hop notes. Dark brown colour, sparse head. Powerfully spicy and tea-like flavour. Quite bitter aftertaste.
Woah.  Lime in the nose?  Lime?!?  Soy?  Whats going on?  Cotton candy?  Flavor is caramel, salt, peat, berries smoke.  This grows on me.. but odd.

Poured dark brown with reddish hues with a small head that dissipated quickly.  Aroma is quite unique, with a distinct maltiness and a hard-to-place spice character.  Flavor is sweet malt, with the spices flocking to the roof of the mouth.  A slightly smoky roastedness predominates the finish.  Tastes very close to a scotch ale with the addition of unique spices.  There is a slight alcoholic twinge in the flavor as well.  Very unique and refreshing.

(bottle) Quite an interesting beer.  Very complex, with flavors I dont think Ive ever encountered before.  The stuff was good, though perhaps just a little too fruity for me to say I really liked it.  I will have it again sometime though.

Had big expectations for this, and it didnt disappoint me. It was quite expensive, so I wasnt sure if buying this was a good idea, but now Im pretty sure it was. Smells like... chocolate, and some other things. The taste is of chocolate, oranges, and a hint of lemon. Basically, this tasted like liquid jaffa cakes. Which is great in my opinion. Ill try this again, but the price is very high, so it wont be in a while.

Malt, brown sugar, peach and licorice in the aroma. Full bodied, thick and oily. Very sweet and low on carbon. Loads of licorice in the flavor, with some malt. Very tasty, but I miss finess in this beer. Licorice rules, and not very much else.

Very dark brown to black with light shallows. Head is minimal. Frangrance of boysenberry syrup with a blueberry chaser. Flavor is sweet coriander (not too sweet). A nice rich vegetable quality with sublime palate. The alcohol is very warming, but barely detectable. The carbonation is right on. Highly recommended. Zesty and a little rough on the palate with time. A little bottle is plenty.

nice golden breown opaque body, not much of a head.  nose is saturated with esters and phenols, coriander and dried banannas.  burboney, oaky, rich ripe fruits, plums, prunes, a hint of chocolate and tobacco, roastiness builds as the beer goes.  like an oak aged Barleywine.

Smokeless Joes.  I was quite scared to try this brew, but warmed up to it almost instantaneously.  Ruby in colour with tastes of sweet molasses, malt, coriander, banana, grass, and a touch of fruit.  This is a spice drink and a good one at that.

Interesting ale - a scotch flavored ale that resembles a barleywine.  Molasses flavor with hints of butterscotch and banana.   Fruit flavors more apparent as ale warmed.  Would definitely like to try again.

This ruby-colored ale pours with a short tan head and elicits a fruity (cherry?) aroma. The initial smooth, malty flavor is followed by a somewhat spicy aftertaste, dominated by coriander. Overall, a very tasty and interesting beverage. Bottle purchased at Whole Foods.

Bottle, Smokeless Joes. Dark brown pour with red tints.  Tanned brown head, small.  Some spice in aroma, slight coriander and cinnamon.  Mouthfeel was very silky - a perfect platform to explore the many flavours in the taste - coriander, and cinnamon, but not one dominating spice - instead, a beautiful blend of spices with a woody tint. As it warmed, I got a slightly fruity aspect to the beer as well. This struck me as being entirely original and a very good beer.  One of those complex beers you dont just enjoy for noveltys sake - youll go back to this one.
330ml bottle. Dark ruby, low carbonation, little head. Complex malt/treacle/chocolate/port/wood/toffee/licorice on nose. Full bodied, creamy mouthfeel and deliciously spicy and complex flavour.

UPDATED: SEP 8, 2004 Pours a deep red/brown color with an light brown white head. Head diminishes quickly and leaves a sticky lace. A good amount of carbonation is present as well. Aroma of spices (coriander),caramel, hops and malt. Flavor is malty with a peppery and spicy finish. Spicey finish mellows as it warms. Mouthfeel is medium bodied with relatively low effervescence.

Bottle into ale glass, Guthries (Chicago).  Its aight.  Personally, I thought it was a bit flat and oily.  Taste was not the issue, just the texture.  Deep plum flavors, sugar cane, of course coriander over everything.  Dark diluted mud color, no head, no carbonation to speak of.  Smell was faint, but I picked up some of the dark fruit smells.  In my opinion, not as good as its rating suggests.

What a brew! Great! Aroma is very strong and complex. Herbs, spices, malt (coffee, roasted), syrup and fruits (apple and peach). Fantastic. Well, just a little minus. Balance is not optimal but good. heheh. dark-brown coloured with a thin lasting brown head. Taste is very decent. Sweet roasted Coffee malt with spices and some fresh fruity notes who make it very pleasant to drink. Dry finish. Ill get some more of this one, thats for sure.

Dark brown with very little head. Aroma
of coriander dominates with a malt background. The flavor of coriander isnt as strong as expected. It is much more subdued than certain Wit beers.
You can also taste dark fruit and sweet
malt. I really like this beer!

Oh my lord..... This brew is heavenly.  Pours a deep brown with aromas of herbs and spices.  Flavors of roasted malt, smoke, almost seaweedy and chocolate.  Great mouthfeel that gently worms it way down your throat.  Very good.

Great brew with a intens dark color and a small head. This unique beer has a complex pallet of rich aromas of ripe bananas,plumpudding,sweet spices,cinnamon,coriander, and roasted malts. It has a dens mouthfeeling with a full rich taste. The taste leaves impressions of ripe fruits, exotic spices and good hops. Great beer with a original taste.

Pours dark brown with NO head. It smells like iced tea and prune juice. Tastes very herbal like something my mom would whip up when I had a cold. Definately a strong prune/raisin taste as well as hints of fresh coffee grounds. Dry with some spice and some iced tea flavor. Malty and creamy. As I continued to drink I noticed a slight chocolate taste. I would like to drink back to back bottles of this and get another for aging. The smell and appearance dont do justice to the taste.

lager glass: dark brown with ruby highlight. light brown and tight head diminishes into a ring around the glass. little lace is left. the aroma is great and so is the flavor and palate. i really enjoyed this brew. it smells like a syrupy candy; malty, peanut butter. the flavor carries a sweet and slightly spicy complexity. the palate is slightly syrupy yet it would never be cloying. its great. "a coriander spiced scotch ale." yeaup, i *guess i* can understand. it's a spicy scotch ale ;o) fresh, sweet, thick, and it's surprisingly refreshing.

Slightly hazy brown beer with a small light head.  Very fine bubbles keep rising and slowly swirl at the top of the glass.  Aromas of molasses, prunes, raisins,  and sweet spices with an alcohol bite.  Very malty and rich flavor with a spice and alcohol bite and a creamy chocolate flavor mixed with a little sour fruit. Very interesting. I like this more than their House ale.  Impossible to drink quickly. No want or need to, however. A beer to sit back and sip once in a while, contemplating how diverse beers can be. Unique and well made

Aroma of over ripe fruit. My bottle poured black into the glass. Tasted like grape juice that sat in the sun for too long. Not very beer like. Dry finish. I needed to wash this nasty stuff out of my mouth. Not able to finish this one. Maybe a bad bottle? Will revisit.

This beer poured a deep brown color with hints of red and a small white head.  The aroma was a little medicinal, with dried fruits and coriander coming through.  The taste was malty with hints of dried fruit again, and the finish was extremely dry.  This is a very different beer and one to try.

Deep black brown, with fine smallish head. Georgous sweet molasses/ tar cherry, malt chocolate, herbs and cream on the nose. It continues to delvelop new flavors as I drink it, anise, rosemary...Flavors of coriander, moslasses, bitter chocolate, with woody and charcoal notes throughout. Very RIch and  Delicious

thin off-white head that goes quickly.  black in color, but dark to light brown & cloudy when directly in front of a light bulb.  smoky and molasses sweet nose.  fine carbonation start.  bitter, peaty, salty taste and bitter finish, but not too strong a finish.  cant put my finger on the coriander flavor, even tried snooting some of the real ground spice to get a hint, but just not me bag.  sorries!

Bottled.  A lovely aroma of spices (cinnamon and the whole Christmas cake thing) and sherry like alcohol.  Almost black beer with very little head.  Beautiful taste, again loads of spices as well as alcohol,  Thick oily and delicious.
Dark Brown Coloring.  Syrapy. No Head.  Spice...Coffee. Roast.  THICK... Didnt really care for it...given the RB ratings...will try again on faith.

Dark brown body with some nice reddish glints. It is topped with a thin and diminishing beige head. Strong fruity (mainly raspberry) nose with some notes of flowers, herbs and roasted coffee. Mouthfeel is sweet, soft, liquorous, lightly carbonated. Taste is malty with nutty and fruity hints. Alcohol is pretty well hidden and the finish is mild but warming. This is a real treasure! Thanks again, PrimeMinister!

Nice dough and coriander aroma that kinda smells like black licorice. Taste had a somewhat sour cherry thing going on along with mellow pepper. Also noted some dark chocolate. A bit sweet but very tasty.

Brown color with red hues. Small head.  Very nice aroma of spices, caramel, cherry and maybe chocolate. Awesome flavors of cherry, caramel, spices, maybe chocolate, maybe smoke and a bit of roastyness. A truly amazing and very complex beer. I think that each time you taste another bottle you discover something new about it.

UPDATED: MAR 4, 2006 Nice bottle! Deep dark chocolate garnet with red hints under the light. FInely laced light brown head, very foamy, diminishing. Unreal dessert aroma. Coriander boosted caramel pudding on the top of a decadent chocolate flavored cake. Out of this world complexity with nutmeg, ginger and vanilla complications. A dark fruitiness is involved, very mild in the back of all that terrific malt, its plummy, raisiny. First sip hits me with an unexpected round mouthfeel, gentle carbonation, fully sensuous. Big molasses and licorice flavors, chocolatey, fruity, spicy, so complex you know youre missing half the flavors. Mild alcohol suggestion reminds you to slow down the sipping effortless effort. Wow this was great, maybe even better than expected, a wonderful dessert sipper with a nose that is nothing short of sinful and creates a dependance. Stunning artwork and unrivaled mastered spice usage. One of the few beers every human being has to try in their life, whether they like beer or not.

Bottle Volo. Pours mahogony with a white soapy head. Malty fruit nose.  Slightly sweet. Lots of roasted malt. Chocolate and vanilla. Coffee. Brown sugar and molases. The hops in the nose really come out when it warms up.
Light spices in the finish. Delicious.

UPDATED: JUN 24, 2005 Dark amber, with a small brown head. Aroma is spicy and malty. It brings chocolate and licorice and also have hints of fruit. Flavor is malty and from chocolate. The alcohol gives it a strong taste and it is quite spicy. Bitter and spicy finish, very complex.

UPDATED: FEB 1, 2005 Not sure what to say about this one.  Different.  dark color, minimal head.  Slight coffee flavor, along with what I believe to be coriander.  Ive never had a coriander in front of me though, so Im not sure.  Theres definately a fruit/herbal taste.  Not bad, not great.

(on bottle)Oh my; here comes the scotts. This is allmost a belgian strong ale- kind of beer. So dark/hazy brown, small/no head, with loads of dry, fuits, smoke and alcohol to the nose. Quite a mouthfull for an ale-lover, allmost too sweet and heavy, but the seasalty- and heetflavours comes trough and saves this excelent beer. A real treat for the dark nights of the fall.

Dark ruby-bronze body with a perfect silky beige head consisting of tight uniform bubbles. Rich Scottish malts, toffee, hints of dark fruits such as prunes, and a spicy edge. Even some oranges seem to be present here. Light smoke. Very smooth body. I really dig this. Thanks to MRomero548 for staring the evil Delta Force in the teeth again and delivering this Scottish soldier safely to my home base.
UPDATED: MAY 21, 2004 Muddy brown with light brown head.  The aroma was wonderful and full of malts and spices.  Flavor was the same.  I very much enjoyed this one.

Bottle at DBF 2004. Hazy dark brown body, tan head. Aroma is very malty, spicy, alcohol, tobacco. The flavor is just as good, spicy, malty, tobacco, some chocolate. Very nice brew. Very smooth and balanced!

my 1/2 way mark beer poured brown tan small head. aroma sweet malt spicey, raisins, hints of chocolate, alcohol.didnt want to stop smelling this.mouth fell was smooth and watery flavor was a very nice blend of spices raisin malts,some port wine flavor slight bitterness the alcohol just right> this is a very good beer will buy more

Very small amount of head. Surprisingly sharp and bitter scent. Has a characteristic whiskey color. A slight herbal taste but the coriander flavoring doesnt come out. On the malty side. Has a taste reiminscent of some citrus household cleaner. Not really a bad flavor but I think the coriander would work better in a lighter, wheat beer. Finishes well.

After doing official beer tastings for 10+ years, I have finally tried this beer and I like it so much, it could be a top 10 beer for me; Superb dark flavor is sweet, very malty, roasty, mildly bitter and strongly alcoholic, and is reminiscent of McEwans Scotch Ale; Nice smokiness accentuates the finish; The coriander is an interesting twist that gives this beer its uniqueness and complexity, but since I dont usually care for coriander in beer, its a minor distraction at first that takes a few sips to get used to, but in the end, has a positive contribution; The mouthfeel is thick and full bodied and coats every nook and cranny of the mouth; The complex aroma is just amazing, and is strongly scented of tea, and of raisins to a lesser degree; Muddy, ruddy brown color; Light tan head is a little small, but holds up very well, settling to a thin layer on top of the beer that remains until most of the beer is safely in my stomach; Some lacing, but not much

Sweet, flowery, coriander, chamomile, spicy, tea-like complex aroma. Could smell this for days. Very relaxing. Id score an eleven for aroma if I could. Dark brown with reddish tones - almost opaque. Thin tan head recedes to thick ring. Large bubbles.

Wow.

Flowery, herbal spices, chocolate, raisins, tea-like, caramel, port, sherry, a touch of alcohol in the finish. Lasting sensation of chocolate. Medium-full mouthfeel. Carbonation recedes but flavour lasts. Be prepared, its fairly still, but the mouthfeel is like a fine part. This is a great after dinner drink. Bottle.

Aroma of spices, port-like, alochol. Pours a very opaque ruby brown, thin head. Flavour is smooth, dry finish. Chocolate notes. Becomes rounder as it warms up. Sweetish aftertaste. An interesting beer, but the 99th percentile is pushing it.

Almost no head. Dark brown, or dark amber depending on the glass. Earthy aroma reminds of Belhaven, (imagined) Scotch soil and Christmas pudding. Aroma starts thin but builds and is well contained in the bowl of a snifter. Very good for the style shown but does adding spice to a strong Scotch Ale put it in this category? A very nice spice Scotch Ale. Warm malt flavours, chewy hops and a plesant spice quality all the same, well made for winters eve.

Caught me by surprise with the first sip of this headless dark brown beer. Interesting fruit and spice aromas that I would not have identified as coriander, sits atop a sweet malty background. This is a very nice beer but I can’t say I love it.

Opaque dark brown body with a medium beige head. Roasted malt and corriander aroma. Sweet malt, dark friut, spicy corriander and pepper flavors. Slightly bitter pepperey hops finish. Very interesting.

Very dark and opaque brown body. Beige head, one finger tall, medium lasting. Delicious, intense aroma with coffee, roasted grains, hops and spices, beautifully blending together. The beer is thicker than the House Ale but just as smooth, delivering flavours of burnt sugar, caramel and port. But despite the sweetness, the finish is bitter and sligthly smokey - even a bit tarty. The aftertaste is long and clean. Extremely drinkable. I was just saying "Wow!" at every sip.

(330ml bottle) Purchased at Glenville Beverage. Prices were good. Pours a large, creamy, beige head and a deep redu body. Nose is mesmerizing. Spicey, caramel and port. Raisin resin finish. Very delicious.

Appearance: dark, eggplant brown color, ruby red round the edges, with a head thick and creamy, tan and voluminous.
Aroma: unheard of! exquisite! Alert, lively, swimming in spiciness! To drink it in is divine! Deep and complex, and so rewarding in so many ways! Though containing precious little "subtlety", its like being smacked upside the head with a spice rack!
Tasty! Bitter hops at first, then dark, turbulent malt, and a very complex flavor: what is going on here? Its like drinking spices!
A certain fruitiness arrives around the middle, but I perceive its only suggested by the spices. In light of full reasoning, its all about the spices, in Jacobite. Wow! Me likey,me likey1
My very first encounter with Jacobite, but Ill be going back for more! A remarkable ale!

Mahogany with a tan head that didn't last long.  Nose was spicy with traces of fruit, perhaps prunes.  A bit of anise.  The body was full and rich.  The taste was distinct and yet evasive.  For some reason I thought of wine.  Perhaps a port.  Anyway, it was a complex and rewarding drink.
Coloring of a rich stout when poured.Dark with a creamy tan head.Hints of nuts, wood and spices.
This rich malty beer is reminiscent of a Jr. Barleywine. Deep garnet brown with just the slightest head. The aroma is malty with a fruity spicyness to it. Complex. Nice beer.

Thin head but creamy and keeps regenerating.  Great aroma of blueberries, blackberries, spices and a touch of hops.  Color is a dark red mahagony.  Flavor is a bit on the spicey and flowery side.  Almost a bitter flavor and not necessarily a good bitter flavor.  Kind of lumps in the throat.  A little licorice in there also.  Finish is dry and bitter.  Alcohol seems stronger than 8% also.  A good beer that starts off great but does not finish as strong.

Very little head. Thick and black with a little amber in a bright light. There is visible carbonation. The aroma has bread and black licorice. The flavor has black licorice, bread, a little tangerine and slight roast beef. The flavors are strong. This is definitely not my style.

UPDATED: FEB 26, 2005 So, my first round with this beer was less than stellar.  I believe my palate had not developed much at the time.  So now, I try it again.  Dark ruby color with a thin head.  Cloves, corriander, and maybe some nutmeg in the aroma.  Different... Chocolate, spice, and malts dominate the flavor.  A bit of earth and dirt too.  It tastes and feels a little chalky.  A bit of smoke?  Okay, much better this time around.

Murky brown appearance with a light mocha colored head. Aroma is luxuriant with elements of licorice, pipe tobacco and prunes. Mouthfeel is thick and creamy and sits well. The spiciness sits well on this one and makes an interesting brew - goes down smooth - would be good for sipping on a cold winter's night.

Wow.  I was seriously fearing some kind of soy-sauce thing, but this is a tribute to craft brewing.  Aroma is loaded with berries and vanilla.  Good spice bittering, this is a fruity dark wit with high abv.  Very good.  Thickish, maybe a bit undercarbonated.
UPDATED: MAR 17, 2004 Poured brown with a medium tan head. Aroma of malt and nuts. Big malt taste and more nuts with some chocolate. Pretty good but maybe a little overrated? Hell, maybe not.

33 cL bottle, snifter.  Caramel, chocolate, tea malt (H); no hop aroma; corriander isn't as heavy as I was expecting.  Smells mostly like sweet tea.  Deep brown body with a quickly diminishing tan head.  Moderately sweet, lightly acidic flavor becomes a moderately sweet, lightly bitter, lightly astringent finish.  Medium-heavy body, oily texture, soft carbonation.  The bottom line is: an odd little concoction, reminds me a little too much of tea.

"Best before June 2009." Pours nondescript brown with garnet highlights. Wispy foam, almost no carbonation, yet leaves a small amount of lacing. Molasses and brown sugar (dark rum?) in the nose are followed by dates or prunes, fermenting apple cider, vanilla, grapefruit zest, old leather, and faint espresso notes. Almost port-like. Surprisingly fruity flavor- blackberry, plum, grapeskin, sour cherry- backed by citrusy coriander and chocolate covered coffee beans. Perfectly balanced. A little less than medium body. Long and mild bittersweet finish.

Dark brown with no head but good amounts of bubbles on the sides of the glass. The nose is rich and dark with heavy malts. The taste has a distinct malt flavor with a little bit of plumb skin as well. The body is medium and overall is quite good.

Dark brown with no head. Nose is big malty and complex with a great spicyness.
Flavour is rich and malty with a spicy bite from the coriander. Medium bodied, finish is spicy with a bit of alcohol.

UPDATED: NOV 5, 2004 330 ml bottle best before May 2011.
Dark brown-black beer with a slight ruby tint.  Had a thin creamy head and some lacing.  Rich, sweet, malty backbone with a fair amount of fruit, especially dates, prunes and plums.  Coriander is very prominant but wonderfully complex.  Lemony aroma.  Tastes is very similar to the smell with a long spicy finish.  Creamy and chewy mouthfeel.  Absolutely delicious.
Rich malty complex spicy flavour. The spice is just right, it's not overdone. One of the best spiced beers I've had.

Poured rich, dark reddish brown with a large off-white head that settled fairly quickly and then disappeared entirely.  Aroma is really interesting, sweet and fruity like prune juice, with spicey coriander and pepper notes.  Flavor is also sweet, fruity and spicy with a lingering dry and tingly hop finish.  Medium body and moderate carbonation.  Very nice brew and certainly my favorite of the herb/spice style so far.

Dark mahogany with a silky tan head. I'm slowly enveloped with layers of aroma-candy sugar, sundried dates, nutmeg, dark chocolate, coriander and the faint sting of alcohol. Caressing carbonation, rich dried tree fruit (prune, fig, date), chocolate and pecans followed by a floral finish. Silky mouthfeel with a nicely balanced acidity and plenty of earthiness. Extremely enjoyable.

Wow, this is definately a very interesting beer. The aroma and taste are reminiscent of black licorice, not too bad! Much too high level of carbonation to be a beer to come back to again.  Although it grows on you, like a giant worm that you ingested while eating raw steak.  Kind of a symbiosis I guess.  Sucking all the life out of you. Wait, the beer...yes, it was good.  Nice experience.

Pours a dark brown with a reddish hue and a thin biege head. Aroma is spicey and mildy sweet. Coriander and different spices on the tongue, along with dark fruits. The beer also had a nice full and chewy mouthfeel. This was definately a great beer.

Had this one courtesy of my man Shag...What a treat...It's funny how many times i have passed on buying this beer cause I didn't realize how good it is.  Flavor was excellently spicy with corriander.  This beer is wholly complex... Sweet upfront that is closely followed the spice very nice beer

UPDATED: DEC 3, 2004 Deep dark ruby, bordering on black, body. A creamy tan head is formed on top that leaves behind very nice lacing. The aroma is very nice, sweet malt, spicy coriander, as well as many other aromas. An astoundingly complex and pleasing aroma is presented that becomes better and better as the beer warms. The flavor complements the aroma. Sweet up front followed by lots of spiciness. The body is full and creamy. The finish is sweet and lingering. Truly this is a world class brew.
Pleasing spicy aroma, dark blackish brown color, flavor was dominated by the coriander, very good but not as complex as i had hoped for, and i still prefer the house ale to this.

UPDATED: MAY 30, 2007 ([email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */) Very dark reddish brown with a tanned, lemonadey and mostly fading head. Strong and pleasant vanilla aroma - sweetish and port-wineous, with dark fruit and spices, plus loads of salty licorice. Sweetish, very licoricey and dried-fruity, roasted-malty flavor with relatively low bitterness, but a dryish finish. Medium to full-bodied, slicky-sticky and slightly thin, very low-carbonated palate. An interesting ale - something like Rochefort 8 with some added malt and without the yeast and carbonation. I would imagine this gets even better with aging (BBE 2017 also suggests that :).
(Bottled, at TOT 04, was 9-4-8-5-17=4.3) Almost black color, small and diminishing head. Very (roasted) malty, port-wineous, rye pudding aroma with herbs, earth tones and cask wood - maybe also blood. Very malty, dryish and bitter, acidic and salty flavor. Salty and acidic finish. Quite full-bodied with very low-carbonated, dryish palate. An excellent-tasting, full-bodied and interesting ale.

Brown, murky body with circles of bubbles sporing to the surface. Smell is worse, something like bark on a decaying tree during a humid, sweltering day. Needless to say the taste was suprising when I detected lucious notes of berries, dark pit fruits, spices, and sweeter hops that mimick more of a cocoa than grapefruit or pine. Bubbles wash the tongue nicely, leaving behind a double thick coating of malt. Tasty, but the look and smell of this beer were abhorent. Overall, a nice suprise.

Colour is a rich ruby-brown. Big, appetizing aroma of dark fruit (cherry, plum), spices (corriander, cinnamon), caramel malt, and a hint of chocolate. Complex flavour with notes of wild berries, corriander, cloves and bitter cocoa. A unique and immensely enjoyable brew.

This beer was the first beer of this style that I tried, and I couldn't have picked a better one to start with. This beer is my favorite beer, hands down. Nothing else tastes quite like it. Color is nice but not spectacular, aroma is pleasant but not overwhelming...but where this beer really shines is in the taste. I can't describe it, but this beer is just a pleasure to drink. The spice sounds like a bad idea, but it's delicious...the beer slides down my throat in dangerous quantities. I love this stuff.
Dark brown/black with scant tan head. Citrus aroma. Grapefruit hops. Dark malt flavors. But I discovered I don't care for the coriander, and I don't like licorice, which was also noticable.

Dark pour with brown edges. An off white head of small and large bubbles with some nice lacing. Coriander is easily detectable in the aroma and it also has a bit of grapefruit in it. Comparitive to the aroma, the flavors are a lot more mellow. Coriander is still there, some malts, and a bit of licorice. Creamy palate accompanied by a full body and a nice spicy finish make this a great beer.

Dark opaque brown w/ tan head.  Big spice/citrus aroma.  Big spice flavour w/ prunish malts.   Improves in flavour as it warms.  A lot better than the spiced winter ales I've been having lately, too bad its so expensive.
(Bottle)  Pours a dark brown color with a small white head.  Has a very nice coriander and licorish flavor and a bountiful aroma.

A scotch ale with coriander?  It actually works.  Aroma is malty - chocolate truffle, licorice, and a hint of smoke, and then, of course, that citrusy corriander scent.  Pours dark brown, decent head.  Flavor is the same as the aroma, actually slightly bitter for a scotch ale.  Full bodied, medium carbonation.  An interesting combination that works well.

UPDATED: NOV 26, 2004 very expensive in the us.  interesting spiced dark ale that avoids tasting like typical holiday beers.  so good smelling, everyone should taste this at least once.  definitely best room temp.  my girlfriends favorite beer. she is nice. i love her

Basically this is a perfect beer. It has rich flavors, compliments a fine and leaves no bitter aftertaste. This beer has a real sweetness but not sickeningly so. It also has a dark and spicey undertone. It smells wonderfull and smells fantastic. If you could judge purly on appearence and smell this would be number one. However the flavor is also impresive and not only is it the best UK beer by a longshot, it also is perhaps one of the best berrs ever.

Bottle. Thin, persistent, tan head.  Nice lustrous deep brown colour.  Initially fresh tasting, before the flavour of roasted cocoa kicks in, which in turn gives way to a sharp, potent alcohol hit, and finally lingering chocalate notes.  This is a bit too strong for me, but I accept it is a quality product.

Heavenly aroma of coriander, dark malt, plum and some orange creamsicle. Chesnut color, amber highlights. Flavor is quite malty with coriander, raisins and some chocolate towards the end. Fuller body, long lasting dark fruit aftertaste. Awesome.

UPDATED: JUN 19, 2006 Picked this up at Johns Grocery in Iowa City.  This one is deep brown and red, damn close to black, with an aroma that is part alcohol, part peaches and apricots, part oak, and part scotch.  The rush of flavors are amazing... initially its of wood and alcohol, then some sour cherries and smoked fruit... then some burned wood and finally it warms the throat and mouth with a biting hint at a good scotch.  Im really liking this one.

OMG,i'm really starting to get tweaked up nicely now.Nice dark brown to almost black color,decent small tan head that lasted for a short time,but left a small amount of lace behind.Malty dried fruit and spicy aroma with a few other aroma's that i just can't describe.The flavor was even better then expected.Malty and spicey with a nice very mild fruit(citrus) and hops semi-sweet to taste and just all around well done.The after taste is malty and spicey with the flavor's really coming together to make a fine brew,that is worthy of it's status here on RB.I just wish the price tag wasn't so steep at $5/bot it's more then welcome in my house but alas will be an infrequent brew due to the price tag and how much you get for that price tag.

UPDATED: MAY 10, 2006 Dark brown, has some ruby tinges and some darker maple browns.  Transparent and filtered.  Small light yellow head.  Smells great, full sweet coriander, some herbalesque hops, and a touch of light scottish malt.  And the taste delivers for a beer of this high rating. . .Yes, I love it.  Oh wow do I like when super-hyped beers deliver.  The best part is the body, I keep waiting for it to peter out and it just stays and the flavor keeps coming.  Lots of coriander but it is balanced supremely with hops and a good spicy malt.  Complexity entails a nice subtle smoked peat, some lighter sweet cherries.  Finish is delightful, flavor climaxes into spice, fruity malt and a wonderful even hops.  Full bodied, no carbonation problems.  no alcohol apparent. Worthy of its spot and more. Maybe just a touch too much coriander on the finish, slight astringency problems. nothing major.  Still wish they wouldnt filter these beers. If this beer would continue to ferment in the bottle it would be the best beer produced.  big statement but I belive it.

Very dark in color. I had looked at this beer in the store before, but it never really interested me. I am so glad I bought it last night. Very flavorful. Some coriander in the flavor. Not too sweet. Very malty. Got some raisin flavors in the taste. Very good.

Wow. To think I was passing this up in favor of other beers because I had no idea what this was about till I read all the ratings and decided to give it a try! Dark beer with perfect lasting 1cm head. Big fruity nose. Wonderful malty beer with just a touch of corriander in the background. Not too sweet, and no strong alcohol notes. Very well made and recommended.
user_location: Good Beer Bar Deprived, New Jersey, USA

text: Small brown/tan head. Hazy dark brown color. Coriander nose with some caramel notes.Med/full body, creamy mouthfeel. Citrusy, coriander flavor backed up with some chocolate, fruits and hints of cherries.Finish is nearly dry. Coriander is a bit too big and lasting though.

UPDATED: JAN 25, 2004 Bottled.
Dark brown with a frothy head.
A complex aroma with citrus, spicies and herbs.
Rather dry and somewhat vinous.
A fine flavour from citrus, herbs and chocolate.

Red-tinged chocolate colour with a short-lived head. Big, sweet malt aroma. Quite thick and packs apunch with flavour. It is malty and yeasty. I like the fact that the corriander is in the background, unlike a lot of Belgian Tripels where the spices are in your face. Thanks Clark VV
UPDATED: FEB 7, 2004 very dark reddish amber color.  smells like tobacco/raisins.  smooth. creamy.  tastes like, well, a nice mixture of good stuff. dry finish.  super tasty.

UPDATED: MAR 22, 2005 Aromas of molasses, oranges, and wheat.  Black, medium sized moderately rocky head.  Tremendous flavor.  Milk, oranges, and coriander. Exceptionally thick and heavy.  Very well balanced.  The abv is not noticeable.  I could sip this all night.
UPDATED: NOV 10, 2003 Thick and muddy like an overdue oil-change, but what a suprisingy taste!  Smooth, flavorful (mostly coriander), creamy, sweet, malty and a long-lasting and effervescent finish!

UPDATED: DEC 7, 2003 Pours black with minimal head.  Smells like a spiced rum and coke.  The malt, hops and coriander come together to taste like sweetened and spiced soy sauce.  The soy sauce comes from the heaviness of the malt and an odd salt flavor.  The aftertaste is dry with a slight mouth-puckering effect.  This beer is pretty complex and different, but it's just not that great.  I don't think coriander (at least not this much) goes that well with maltier and heavier beers.

Poured out of bottle, bought at Hi-Times Wine Cellars in Costa Mesa, CA 10/21/03.  Color is a dark plum brown, very little head on a vigorous pour, lingers on the fringes.  Tame nose is of wine, bitter chocolate, and some alcohol.  Very surprising, robust medium-to-full mouthfeel, intricate combination of flavors starts immediately on sipping.  Hint of sourness, creamy malts, and some dark, drying spices (is it the coriander??).  Overall, very mellow but complex, extremely pleasant and delicate.  Hard to describe all that's going on, but it's very subtle.  Unlike anything else I've had, and this is VERY good stuff.

The aroma is sweet and malty with notes of smoke. The color is very dark brown and it has a small dense light brown head. The flavor is very sweet chocolate with underlying notes of malt, bread, and roasted malt. Great flavor - and great palate.

Dark mahogany. Excellent khaki,well-formed,head. Yep,there is coriander in the aroma. Also dark fruit,brown sugar,liqourice, and the slightest alcohol. Perfect carbonation,the creamiest malt character/mouthfeel. Excellent malt(chocolate,nutty,dark bread) character but a little to over spiced for me. Would proabably be better around the exp(2009). Finish is malty,with just a touch of spice lingering. To say the least interesting but hard for to explain what I'm tasting. Fruity mouth,spicy finish.

ruby-brown colour, the initial foam quickly disappears, deep and very complex nose of prune, licorice, alcohol and spices (ginger, ?), full-bodied, robust bitterness and a long alcohol, malty and fruity finish - thanks to fiulijn for this beautiful brew !

UPDATED: OCT 12, 2003 I poured this into a goblet and held it up to light. A deep ruby red color with a thin tan head which is diminishing rapidly. Aroma is complex, I smell plums, figs and a big blast of coriander. Has a super creamy mouthfeel that is nice. Flavor is most interesting.  Good sweet malt base with a bit of spicyness thrown in. This is one interesting brew but not one I really see myself drinking often. It's just a bit too weird for me.
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text: Dark brown, almost black. Nice creamy head. Coffee, coriander, citrus-peels and alcohol in aroma. Very smooth and complex in flavour. Coffee, chocolate, dried plums, raisin and coriander. Chocolate and spicy alcohol in finish. A great brew.

Very good.  Each sip gets better.  Aroma is excellent.  Reminds me VERY much of Maudite and Trois Pistoles.  My wife was telling me it smells like raisons and watery soy sauce.  At first I was like, "What the /$%&!! are you talking about!"  But she's kind of right if you really take a big sniff.  The raison is definately there, but the soy sauce is a bit of a stretch.  She also said it tastes like soy sauce.  I don't get that at all.  The baby is sticking his fingers up her nose, so maybe that's it.  There's no head on this.  To reiterate, this is a lot like Maudite and Trois Pistoles.  Perhaps tgis is a little less sweat and drier in the finish.  For the price, I would rather have the cheaper Unibroue.  This is very good, but I think I expected a bit more

Very unique, interesting, and good ale.  Nose is malt, ginger, little plum.  Beer pours dark ruby red with off white head that mostly diminishes, quickly.  There is no lacing.  Flavor is quirky, malt front with spices, then the alcohol kick in.  Tasty.

UPDATED: JAN 3, 2004 Had this last night.  I did not really know what corriander tasted like, but identified a unique flavor to this ale that fits well.  The price is high, but so is the quality.  I will buy this again.

Very dark brown colour with a slight ruby tint when held real close to a light. Medium sized tan head of small bubbles tops the beer. Strong aroma of coriander (of course), malt, yeast, curacao (orange peel) and a bit of chocolate. Medium-bodied; Strong malty flavour with very noticeable hints of the spices, chocolate and a slight sweetness. Aftertaste bittered from the malt and the chocolate but not too much dealing with the spices at all. Overall, a great beer and one that should be had by everyone! Bottle says: best before June 2009. I got this 33 cL bottle in a trade with great guy: Matt A. (Mabdoney)...Thanks again Matt-A great beer to start out my final year at college!

A very nice deep ruby color and thin tan head start this highly anticipated brew.  The nose is VERY unique... beautifully spiced and very delicious.  The flavor can't QUITE live up to the excellence of the nose, but is still very nice and leaves hints of the spice in the mouth for quite some time.  Really an excellent spiced beer!

Tasted in Toronto (Purchased from Cairo in Washington DC).  Deep black colour, opaque.  Rich and creamy tan coloured head.  Aroma is licorice and spice, hint of chocolate-orange.  Incredibly smooth and rich ale.   Sweet taste, hint of bitter licorice and big malt finish.  Very very impressive.
A profound ale. A perfect after dinner ale. Rich, complex and splendidly tasty. Elements of a good quality port. High marks for this.

Wonderful dark brown color with a thin head. Aroma of dates & molasses. This one definitely has a complex flavor. First it hits you with a nice fruit flavor then the spice kicks in ever so slightly, then it leaves you with a sweet aftertaste on the palate. One of the best beers I have found TRY IT, TRY IT, TRY IT!

A dark burgundy brown with a little bit of lively head. Aroma is apricots, dates and dried fruits in general. Some coriander, but probably only detected it through the power of suggestion. Flavor is tart apricots, whole grain bread, and spicy bitterness. Sugary but there is enough acidic bite to offset it and the end result is totally unique and very nice. Couldn't drink more than a few at once, though.

Dark brown almost zero head. The aroma is of molasses, raisins, roasted grain and maybe citrus. Thick bodied, a mouth filing brew, sweet malt, burnt sugar, dried fruit, coffee. Its ends on the dry side and a bit warming. Yeah

Spicey, molasses, treacle aroma, deep ruby colour, with a large toffee head, much lace. Pine needles, a strong spiciness, hard to pin down, buckwheat flavour too. Bitterlicious, full bodied, very dry finish. Terrific!

Beautifully black with a thin off-white head.  Fruity, but not very citrusy aroma, with a good hint of spice.  sweet, yet very nicely spiced flavor, not much of an alcohol taste for 8%.  More beers should be this good.
Fruity smell, but a strong spicy side to it.  Color is nice and dark. But man, is this flavor complex.  A little too much for me right now.  Hell of a good brew though.

I've never tasted anything quite like this!  In both nose and flavor, it's really fresh and flowery; yet has very heavy malt and burnt sugar (caramel and molasses).  Strangely, wonderfully sweet, but not cloying.  Excellent and special.

UPDATED: NOV 19, 2003 Much better than expected. Dark brown/black appearance. Aroma is of chocolate, coffee, and raisins. Flavor has a slight alcohol burn with raisins, plums, chocolate, sour apples. Slight spicy. Quite complex. This is an excellent beer. And worthy of its previous top 50 beer standing.

Dark dark brown, rich carbonation, sparkling tranquility qualities in the lacing, stunningly beautiful. Aroma of corriander, slightly fruity, chocolate, coffee, alcohol. Flavor is almost cloying with just enough chocolate malt to balance all the flavors together. Spicey and zesty! Coffeeish bitter finish, slightly astringant. This beer has some wonderful complexities and delicious spicey notes.

Dark amber color, fruity plumb/prune aroma, with small head that disappears quickly.  Had a very nice plumb raison flavor balanced nicely with corriander. Begins with sweetness and ends in a spicy bitterness. Delightfully warming and complex.
Dark amber with a medium off-white/tan creamy head.  Coffee, chocolate, hops aroma.  Silky smooth, spicy, oily.  Nice.
A rich fruity smell clings to your senses from the first aroma.  Beautifully dark and complex, definite hints of corriander, clove, and raisin.  Very warming and relaxing to drink on a cool night.
Dark brown, purple body with a nice lasting head. Smells of licorice,plum,and raisin. Oily and spicy(coriander). Good balance, alcohol is hidden well, but still has a warming feel
Dark red body. Incredible aroma with malt and spice. Taste is spicy (not too much!) and malty (notes of smoked malt). Very nice.
Beautiful beer from a beautiful brewery! I stayed there back in 2001. Nothing like having the beer 50 yards from where it's brewed!
UPDATED: AUG 28, 2004 Very dark brown/ruby with a big tan head. Aroma of Malt, spices, fruit and candy. Flavor of malt, chocolate, toffee, charms blowpop  and spices.

Clear but very dark black color, short head. Aroma is roasted malts, coffee, milk, bit spicy. Flavor of roasted malts, oatmeal. Quite bitter coffee finish. I'm quite disappointed with the UK top brews...

Dark appearance. Coffee, liquorice and roasted malts in aroma. Fairly complex taste, but somehow this is just not my kind of style. Nice for a try, but way too expensive (3 euro's a bottle) to drink more often.

Dark, coffee-like, or exotic polished wood. Thin but dense yellowish head, fine pearling. Thick, soupy, celery aroma, even celery-salt like. There's definitely celery-taste in this, and not just a bit (DMS?). It's even annoying, and the coriander, the other aroma, seems to strenghten it. Warming up, the coriander seems to take over more and more. Thick, rich and chewy mouthfeel. Some alcohol and quite some esters retronasal. Sticky feeling afterwards. As if you've eaten something. I ought to find this great, but I'm searching for the fatty-rings on my soup, sorry, beer.

UPDATED: AUG 28, 2005 Rerate: The spices seem more subdued but the blend still does not work for my palate. I will increase the flavor score and overall by one point a piece, still my most against the grain brew. I tried, I really wanted this to be better...

The appearance is beautiful, reddish brown with just a little light shining through, little head but still got some lacing out if it, medium-bodied. Wow, very spicy and vinous on the nose, a bit of raisin sweetness detected once I adjusted to the overpowering spices. Holy batman, the spices attacked my taste buds right from the get-go, okay, something else will follow, this is complex right...wrong! I just can get past the heavy corriander taste, I like the taste in a witbier, but this is just too much! Some sweetness to the rescue but too late. This beer ruined my palate for the rest of the evening, Im soooooo disappointed, really like complex scotch ales. Did I have a bad bottle? I hope so because everybody else cant be this wrong about this beer. I will re-rate when I find another bottle from a different vendor. Drain pour last 1/2 of glass.

Very dark, reddish brown with barely a head at all.  Smells to me somewaht like FruitLoops cereal, and tastes like it too.  A co-mingling of various fruits.  Spicy and herbal.  Crisp and refreshing.  Perfectly balanced, a nice roastiness.  A good beer.

I didn't think that an ale with coriander would do it for me, but this is quite good.  This has a beautiful dark red color, and an aroma of oats, spices and maltiness.  The flavor is very much like a barleywine, with a complex mix of tastes from grain, to mildly sweet fruit, earthiness and, of course, coriander.  This is some great stuff.
Brandy, brown sugar, banana, and spice. A bit too strong on the volatiles (banana esters and alcohol) for my liking.

This brew poured a very, very small head with fine bubbles that quickly dissolved. There was no lacing on the sides of my glass. It had a licorice aroma to it. There was a lot of carbonation observed with this brew. It left a fizzy feeling on my tongue and an aftertaste that lingered. I could not acquire a good taste for this brew as it most certainly had a unique taste.

This brew pours a very small dark brown head of fine bubbles that quickly disappear.  It has a dark semi-opaque brown carbonated body.  It has an average strength aroma of spices and malt.  The flavor of this brew is different than most other brews, not bad, not great, but it took a little while to get used to.  It contains notes of spice, raisin, dark chocolate, and licorice.  After a few tastes, the gas started to make me burp.  The alcohol started to show itself after half a mug.

Pours a deep red black with a tan head that evaporates rather quickly.  Even sitting on the table, I get a wiff of the sweetness of the aroma.  Scents of burned sugar, fruit, spices and wood just dance around my nose.  The flavor is of charred spiced wood, delicate at first and hardening into a more agressive flavor by the end.  This is damn good.

UPDATED: NOV 1, 2003 Garnet black with a snow white head. Fruity nose with a spicy, vinous kick. Notes of bitter coffee, band-aids (which I taste in nearly every Scottish beer I try), chocolate, and alcohol. Try as I might, I can't get into this. The earthy bitterness just doesn't sit right on my palate.
Had my first taste at the traquair house in Scotland.  Love the toasty spice,fruit. overtones.

Muddy dark brown, rapidly diminishing offwhite head. Almost brandylike aroma, although the alcohol is well-hidden otherwise. Voluptuously full-bodied. Flavor of dried fruit, oak, smoke, with a definite presence of coriander that merges into the other flavors rather than elbowing to the front. There's more bitterness from the roast and the coriander than from the hops. Scotland is our friend.

UPDATED: MAY 20, 2003 Huge malt and spiced up nose.  Deep dark ruby/ruddy hue.  Beige-ish head.  Starts sweet, caramel, chocolate, velvety smooth, leather, black over-ripe cherries, medium bodied, light smokiness.  Finishes all spice, very smooth.  This brew is incredible.  The alcohol is hidden in an oh so seductive manner... This is a world class beer!  And its readily available...

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2004 Dark amber. Off-white head. Well, this is a strong bastard, and according to my humble opinion beer should be consumed in large numbers(?)...oh well. This one is fully aromatic, I sence a mix of prune and "English Candy"(correct me if you have a more aproppriate word for those sweets) in the aroma. The taste is kind of scurfy(correction again maybe?) and there might be some bitter almond in the flavor too.

murky floodwater brown with an ebb of ruddy embers deep within, an unregaling brown like a wet woodchuck has snuggled into your glass. head is able but not athletic, the lace sagged toward oblivion in tired little wisps, like fragile summer clouds toasting away above a drought stricken landscape. aroma is a sweet amalgamation of raisins and orange peel, and many other things dark and delicious crowding the aromatic spectrum: brown sugar and cedar and port and buttery breads and oven fresh ginger snaps. coriander is not a spice i could previously tell from fenugreek or wapiti dander, but i've been handed a sample by a friend, and learn that the leaves of this plant we call cilantro, and the perfumy ground seeds also comprises a major constituent of curries: it's that spicy orange aspect. here, that orange flavor dominates with sweet pecan pie malts and a bit of peat amid a creamy wash of carbonation until finally an assiduous pekoe tea bitterness can creep up the malty stanchions and decorate the finish with filigrees of late  hoppiness. gorgeous, full --and solid as the locked gates at traquair castle.

Deep dark brown color with a thin ring of foam.  Strange blue raspberry aroma with some caramel malt.  Tastes like a cross between an English mild and a barleywine.  Full raisiny body and silky palate end with sweet chocolate date notes.  This hides its alcohol very well.  This is a very unique and interesting brew with good complexity.

Dark red brown color. Head is large and rolling. Aroma is complex, mixture of malts, spices and fruits, with a mixture of old musty basement added. (This is a good thing). WOW. What a complex tasting beer. The rich malts and spiciness interact to make this a very complex and tasty beer. The malt sweetness is balanced by the spiciness. Body is more like a porter or a stout. It has a definite vinous quality as well. Flavors are varied; malts, plums, apples, smoke, chocolate, coriander, vanilla and whole lot more. Smooth.  A very unique beer, one of the must tries. Hides the alcohol well. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is smooth. Aftertaste is slightly bitter.

Very interesting brew. Pours a deep red/brown color, with a very small brown head that swirls beautifully around the surface. Aroma is very rich, with a dark fruity base, laced with sweetness and a nice maltiness, with a spiceyness that I guess is primarily coriander (based on the bottle discription). Flavor is much like a red wine, with red grapes prominant, rather sweet, and the same spiceyness as the aroma, but less prominant. Flavor is totally smooth throughout. Palate is just a little thinner than I would like. Overall quite a nice and interesting brew, with a substantial kick by the end of the bottle (as I'm learning now!).

UPDATED: FEB 10, 2004 What a great beer. Rich brown color, smooth, vibrant on the palate.  Complex with a duel between the strong coriander and spice, and sweeter flavors. One of my favorite aromas in beer.  Top notch.  The more I've had it, the more I appreciate it.

Oh my beautiful beautiful beer.....how i would rivet your every orofice with my being if you were human...wow!!!! It poured a mahogany brown color with virtually no head. The aroma was entrancing...coriander, caramel malt, fruits, and an aged quality danced around my nose. The taste hinted at so much...with wood, sugar, plums, apples, caramel malt, coriander, alcohol, and a chocolatey sweetness. Wonderful mouthfeel as the carbonation creates a velvety sheet of satin across my tongue. Dry, spicey sweet finish. Just unbelievable in every respect.

Advertised as a scotch ale, and I tend to agree... probably because I've only had one other scotch ale which possessed the same unrelenting malty sweetness that is quite delectable. Nice, delicate aroma of corriander with a dark, deep purple appearance and minimal head. Taste had the malty sweetness and corriander which was expected, as well as a caramelized fruit, slightly roasted flavor that was perfect. Burst of flavor, with a palate that complemented everything very well. For some reason its hard to find exceptional ales with distinct, predominant malty sweetness that obtain an unrelenting flavor without being too cloying. This beer does it. Great, great brew.
