UPDATED: FEB 21, 2003 Very unique beer. Had more of a herb/vegetable prescence than most "herb/vegetable" beers that I've had, but definitely in a good way.  After paying over $6 for this beer I had high expectations, but the beer came through.  Nice sweet malty aroma.  Pours the color of a flat Coke with practically no head whatsoever.  Very complex flavors, sweet malt flavors with slight licorice, cola, and other distinct flavors that I assume was the coriander.  Important to point out that the flavor had no similiariy at all to other beers spiced with coriander (Belgian Wit). Medium body. Long sweet finish. Soft carbonation. Very unique beer. Very drinkable.
Not real sure what to make of this one.  Definently a sipping beer.  Tastes good in its own little way.  vegetableness seemed there if that makes any sense.

Stunning ale. I feel lucky to be drinking it.  Almost an odd flavor that might be off-putting to some but give it a try and don't be too quick to judge.  Coriander??? In a beer???
It works for me.
Deep brown in colour.  Aroma of molasses, ginger, spices.  Flavour sweet, bitter, spicy.  Very complex and one that everybody should try.

I really expected to love this more- deep cloudy brown red; minimal head; Aroma was sweet, pruney and had some caramel. Very deep and dark atsting- medium body. Not a mindblower like I wanted it to be.
Dark amber beer with a small creamy head. Spicy, flowery aroma. Koriander taste. Slightly sweet with a strong bitterness. Maybe too much of the koriander.

Dark brown, with a tan head that dissipates quickly.  Very sweet and malty, with subtle fruit flavors.  The corriander has a much different effect than when it is in a Belgian Wit.  It may be the source of a slight licorice taste.    Extremely good.
Deep brown colour with a thin, disappearing head. The taste is really spicy and fruity (apple and plum), quite similar to wine. The aftertaste is malty. Not my kind of beer, but, anyway, interesting.

UPDATED: SEP 1, 2016 2015-12-17, bb 2010-05-31, probably 10 years old, 6-3-6-3-11=29Black color, with almost no head. Oxidized, dry, thin, with a strong liquorice component.Could hardly please anybody at this stage.2010-12-30, bb 2010-05-20, probably 5 years old, 7-4-7-3-15=36The color is dark brown, almost black; the head is medium-sized, creamy, reducing to a thin layer. The aroma shows some toasted nuts; caramel. The body is quite slim, the texture is a bit oily; the caramel and roasted malts flavor is still quite good; it has some small signs of oxidisation; the bitterness in the end, mostly supported by the roastiness, is quite evident. Solid.2009-12-31, 9-4-7-3-15=38The color is almost black; fizzy, initially there is a medium sized creamy head, but it disappears quickly. The aroma is intense, of caramel, mature but not old. It still has a respectable body structure, with dark caramel flavor, but the age is more evident here. Balanced final, with an evident share of dark malts and dark caramel. Surely not at its peak, but interesting anyway.2003-02-01, 10-5-8-4-16=43Dark color, creamy head.Wonderful complex aroma: malty, fruity, Porto wine, sweet liquorice.Full malty mouth, round taste, some sweetness, sharp presence of liquorice, caramel, roasted malt; almost fruity; still a bit young.Good final, a lot of malt, liquorice, caramel; well balanced by a pretty strong bitterness.
Pretty dark in color, little head.  Aroma of coffe and brandy.  Taste is pretty average.  Not very impressed, not very spicy of any one direction.
Not a bad little brew. Very ddep ruby color, with huge spice nose. The alcohol didnt seem to hide much at all, especially as it sat. Very tasty, it keeps the tongue busy from start to finish

UPDATED: JAN 17, 2003 Pours a deep ruby/garnet color, with a thick, slowly diminishing tan head.  Aroma is HUGE, full of spices, fruits (especially apple), and vinous qualities.  Flavor is strong on the spices and apple, with other fruits playing around in the background, and hints of alcohol.  As it gets warmer (was initially served about 60°F), the alcohol becomes a bit more prevelent on the tongue, and warms the gullet nicely.

UPDATED: JAN 12, 2004 Pours a rich, dark brown. Small head. Obvious spice aroma. Possibly cinnamon or nutmeg in there too. Slight fruitiness is evident as well. The taste is definitely unique. The coriander is evident as is anise/licorice and possibly coffee or maybe even dark chocolate. Finishes very bitter but it soon recedes. Worth trying but nothing overwhelming.

Deep brown with luminous ruby hints, almost no head.  Blackcurrant, rasberries, caramel, spices and alcohol aroma (my wife says she smelled figs too).  This beers got a nice sweet and sour fruitiness ending on a comforting alcohol bitterness.
Strong spice aroma. The flavor was sweet, spicy, and slightly bitter. Smooth, creamy feel.

Pretty good.  Im not sure what the coriander is supposed to taste like, it did not seem to be highly spiced.  It just seemed like a very nice ale.  I like the regular Traquair House Ale better, its more well rounded.

deeeeeeep brown color.  with a rough pur i got a head that was white and lasted about 1.5 seconds.  teh aroma is rather incredible, lots of spices, corriander stronger than i have ever smelled it before.  it is a wonderfully sweet aroma.  the flavor is also very sweet due to all of the corriander.  there may be a little bit of dark fruit in it as well and a touch of the alcohol flavoring.  medium body that clears out of the mouth fast.  very impressive beer.

deep brown color with no head whatsoever. aroma is malty, chocolatey and some coriander with maybe just a hint of prune juice. coriander is stronger in the flavor with a finish that is slightly coffee and chocolate-like. the strong presence of coriander is why i like this beer and sunshine wheat so much!
Spice and malt nose.Maybe I got a bad one, but the flavor reminds me of the smell of Absorbine Junior

Veh tasty.  The herb note is not as strong as I thought it would be.  Has the classic Belgian taste and mouthfeel.  Well done, although the pretentious bar where I drank this served it in a pint glass.
Malty aroma.  Transluminate, dark brown in color.  A little bubbly on the mouthfeel.  Great malty taste.  Ill be having more of these in the future.
Crisp and full with plum and coriander flavors.  Very unique.

UPDATED: JAN 3, 2004 Aroma is pure excitement.  Very nice deep reddish mahogany color, head is not much of a factor here.  Flavor is become analogous to my concept of ambrosia, nectar of the gods.  It's really just a decently strong, sweet, malty Scottish Ale with a whole lot of coriander in it, but somehow this makes it one of the more delectable beverages I've ever consumed.  Unique flavor profile in the extreme.  I guess I really like coriander a lot, because sometimes when I'm standing by the spice rack in the kitchen I'll take a whiff of the coriander so that it reminds me of Jacobite.  One of my all-time favorite beers.

pours hazy reddish brown with a tight beige head.  great aroma.  big toffee-ish malt with complex hints of fruit(orange?) cocoa and coriander.  light carbo, but very thick and full mouthfeel.  nice flavours of caramel, raisins, coriander, anise and chocolate.  bitter sweet finish lingers.  excellent.

Muddy brown.  Little carbonation.  Super sweet spicy nose.  Its like a liquid Terrys chocolate orange.  Groovy! So interesting.  The taste is even more like a chocolate orange, in that the notes are very subtle, but still super.  Kind of thin I thought.  Aftertaste repeats all the sweet malt flavours.  Thanks Indra!
Molasses, spicey nose. Dark brown body with a little layer of a head. Spicey and roasted bitter taste. Thick. Good balanced.

Extremely tasty and well balanced. The nose like a spiced molasses, and kinda port wine-like. The dark ruby color makes this attractive as well. Some many flavors: toffee, chocolate, spices, and roasted malt. The end is crisp and dry. Thick, syrupy body. Beautiful!
Sweet orange peel,coriander aroma.Mellow sweet oak hoppy spicy flavor that hides the alcohol well.Similar to a fine Belgian specialty.Mild hoppy herbal aftertaste.

Im not really a fan of strong, syrupy UK ales, barleywines and old ales. They seem to be pursuing a madeira, cream sherry or port sweetness and heaviness and its just not my thing. This one poured coffee brown, with a distinct coriander fruitiness - almost like a spicy fruit candy -  and a heavy maltiness. No head at all; very low carbonation. Flavor is lush, sweet -  coriander with a touch of molasses and vanilla...and some oakiness. Heavy with nutty malty, syrupy flavor. I did not notice any hops in this. It is mellower than the House Ale, which finishes with an inappropriate bitterness. It makes for an OK dessert style sipping drink. If thats what I want, though, Id rather have a sherry...

Voluptous spicy berry aroma. . .have you ever had a berry pop-tart?  Lightly spiced mouth feel. . .I dont know how to describe the complexities. . . possibly sweet rasberriesm maybe some raisins, perhaps fruit - plums?  One of the more interesting beers I have had.

Very dark reddish colour with a fantastic big and creamy head. It smells like spicy chocolate milk. The malty flavour is truly complex with notes of coffee and herbal liquor (Fernet Branca). Full bodied. The mouthfeel is almost like a good strong Baltic Porter. A very good brew to fortify oneself with.

Dark ruby colour with a huge chocolatish head. Very tempting. The aroma is full of scents. Chocolate, spices (almost reminds me of the better dobbelbocks). Flavour is complex. Loads of coffee, chocolate, malt and spices. Has a good lasting aftertaste with a hint of coffeebitterness. This is truely great stuff. Happy ive found it.

UPDATED: MAY 25, 2003 This beer rocks.
Wow! What an aroma.
Notes of coriander, toffee, molasses, milk chocolate, caramel, prunes, apple butter and honey.
This slightly hazy, ruby colored ale has a large, creamy, khaki head. Fully lasting with decent lacing.
Up front, the palate is pounded by tons of malt. Slightly sweet with bursts of coriander (ok, I'm guessing coriander is what that heavily spicy aroma is... I wouldn't know coriander if it fell out of the sky, landed on my face and wiggled. Time to hit the spice rack here in the house to familiarize myself with the stuff), molasses and coffee. Balanced out quite nicely with a good, subtle hop presence on the backside. For a Scotch Ale, this kind of balance is rare and very welcomed.
Full-bodied. Soft carbonation. Syrupy mouthfeel. Short, moderately alcoholic, fairly dry and slightly pungent finish. It seems that great care and thought was put into the crafting of this ale. Get your hands on a bottle and enjoy.

darkness like an old sugary port wine with blindingly dark burgundy light waves bouncing off my inner brain..laced out head like a sky of fresh clouds contrasting against the crisp blue sky...aroma was pounding with tartness Ricocheting off of dark chocolate raspberry sweetness...sweetless raspberry cocoa morphing to extreme spiciness and back again to cocoa raspberry but ending sweeter than the start...spinachy/coca cola like aftertaste

Dark ruby red color.  Creamy medium head.  Bright flowery nose, probably the coriander.  Amazingly interesting beer.  At once it is dark with malt, caramel, and chocolate tones, but the coriander gives it a bright sweetness.  The alcohol emerges in the middle but doesnt really effect the palate.  A bold experiment but done with perfection of balance.
I enjoy the coriander, and have never had a beer quite like this one.  Alcohol very subtle, but good balance.  Maltiness is appropriate, and the finish is sweet and fruity from the spices.  Very odd.

This is a very interesting beer indeed.  Notes of plum and raisin on the nose.  I thought the coriander would be more pronounced.  Alcohol is evident in both the aroma and flavor. The maltiness lasts a long time on the palate.  Reddish/Amber hue, definitely one of the most peculiar beers I have ever had.

This looks exciting, and it had better be considering its $6 for an 11.2 oz bottle...not saying that money buys happiness but it certainly buys beer that makes me squeal with glee. Smells immediately of the coriander, burnt orange peel, clove, and musky grape. Tastes like...my imaginary thick-accented Scandanavian grondmother just baked this in her oven. Wow, the alchohol comes out a lot more but blends so nicely with the muskiness that I feel like I should say something like yes Frederick this is definitely an excellent year. However, I am not wearing a silk bathrobe or a monocle, so Ill sum this up by saying...Ive said enough already.

Pours a very dark brown with a small off white head. Has a strong aroma of coriander and malts. Medium bodied with just the right amount of carbonation. Starts of malt sweet with that typical scotch ale taste, but finishes nice and spicy with just a hint of bitterness. The malts and spices are in perfect balance, a wonderful brew and probably the best spiced beer I have had.
Pretty nice.  The coriander fits in perfectly, adding some hoppy bitterness and a bit of intrigue.  The underlying ale isnt all that remarkable, in my opinion--Id probably prefer McEwans.

UPDATED: OCT 5, 2004 Pours a dark reddish brown with a small fast fading head. Medium bodied at first, loaded with roasted caramel and tangy,
                lightly smoked malts. Complex flavors, licorice among them, with a  nice dry finish. Alcohol not that noticable on the palate, but it warms the face. Kinda pricy, but fantastic.

Massive amounts of cookie dough in the nose and even taste. Oodles of style traits characteristic to a belgian: spice, malts, dark coloring etc. Not exactly THAT impressive, but it was good...i dont see why its classified as an herb/veggie. I was half expecting to be drinking liquid broccoli. At 7 dollars for 11oz. i dont think im going to be indulging my senses to often with this. Also...it was VERY well balanced.
UPDATED: MAR 24, 2003 Though a spicy drink, lacks body but makes up for that in flavor.
user_location: Middle of no where, Ohio, USA

text: what a great idea - coriander with shitloads of dark smoky malt. fruity and fatty sweetness, raisins and custard, then really dry spiciness, a bit of hops, and subtle peatiness that i could only detect when i breathed in after gulping it. reminds me a lot of Hercule, which is a Good Thing.
Not bad.  Very complex ale spicy and malty. Nice corriander flavor
Dark reddish brown. Spicy nose. Huge, malty and sweet body. Complex, and very tasty, but a bit too spicy for my liking, and still I prefer their regular House Ale.
berry aroma, light brown, no head, damn fucking parmesan pretzels but still can taste winy coriander

Sometimes complexity in a beer is wasted on me, like when the  combinations are too wild as they are with this one.  I definitely get some coffee and a hint of raisins, coriander and licorice.  But there is also some vegetable quality about this (I noticed the same characteristic with La Chouffe) that just doesnt work for me.  Im sorry about giving a low rating, but I just didnt enjoy this brew.

Very stouty. Nice bitter with a twist of spice. Very heavy and smoked. Nice dark brown appearance if you are in a tea/coffe-mood-night, this i a good alternative if you would like to consume some alcohol simultaneously.
Dark,amber,and fruity raisins,alcohol,and, hops.Spicy flavours of coriander and fruit abound, this glass blossoms as it warms, not really my style, though it is one quality beverage.

dark amber/red.  Very vinous mouthfeel. I got thick sweet malts, raisins, licorice.  Some, but not much, hop presence.  I think I missed some of the coriander, but it was so tasty, that I didnt miss it, either.  The alcohol was well hidden behind everything else.  This was an  excellent "sipper".

yum yum and more yum.

all of the things i love most in a beer: maltiness, lightly spiced and somewhat raisiny/chewy...YUM. a new favorite!

UPDATED: JAN 29, 2008 Strong malts in the nose with a fair amount of alcohol.  Ruddy garnet color and a thin beige hat.  Substantial malt character with a slightly chewy mouthfeel.  Strong molasses flavor with a  a decent dried fruit/ floral sweetness.  Definite hints of coriander and 8% abv. becomes more prevelant as the beer warms.

This poured with a beautiful deep garnet color, thin head that left lace down most of the glass, and a complicated sweet nose.  There is such a complex malt flavor of sweet fruits well balanced with strong bitterness.  There is a subtle spiceyness that I can only attribute to the corriander.  The alcohol comes up as the beer warms.  Excellent sipping beer.

Almost opaque deep dark brown with a smallish medium lasting tand head. Faint spicey aroma when cold. More fruity caramel malty coffee and liquorice when warm. Medium creamy smooth light imperial stoutish type palate. The middle is exceptionally complex and mellow with subtle roasted malt bitter and hint of turkish delight perfume. Alcohol is well covered until it warms up and even then is still quite subtle. Simply a wonderful beer and truly delicious.
My wife called it a chocolate truffle in a glass. Not a bad assessment. Rich chocolate malt flavors with just a hint of fruity (orange?) spiciness in the finish.

wonderfull flavor coriander nicely balanced with heavy malt profile
a very unique scottish ALE
Nice dark amber color.  Big coriander aroma.  Coriander comes through in the body, but is not overpowering as you might expect.  Definitely a brew you have to be in the mood for.

Anticipation was killing me to try this beer.  I have been eye-fondling it in my local liquor store for many weeks.  Poors thick into the glass.  A tight tan head.  Aroma was disappointing ... smelled musty.  Rich malty chocolate tones with powerful anise base.  Coriander flavor is barely perceptible.  Nice overall spiciness from hops.  This is a great overall brew, but one of the rare times that I have been in disagreement with ratebeerians.

Dark reddish brown color, good head formation. Strong deep malty aroma, caramel and dark fruits. Thickish palate, dark malt, prune and plum fruitiness. Light hop bitterness, nice drying spicy touch (although I wouldnt have guessed coriander if it wasnt written on the bottle. Great complexity and hearty warming feel.
Dark ruby color, very pleasing licorice aroma.  A powerful malty Scotch ale that is surprisingly sweet.  Not everyone will like it, but those who do will love it.

Incredible roasted malt, alcohol, and subtle corriander aroma. Dark mahogany color with a large head after a rough pour. Strong roasted flavor. Corriander in the background, barely perceptible to me except for the sweetness it adds. Very malty. Some alcohol flavor. Extremely full bodied. A very good and quite interesting Scotch Ale. The only negative is that its quite sweet, possibly too much for some people.

This is a well-made ale, but its licorice-like sweetness (something to do with the coriander, I suppose, and the malt) is almost too much. Despite which, Im surprised at how much I like it. Recommended for lovers of sweet Scottish ales, and worth trying whether you like such things or not.

As deep as Ruby Red gets before it becomes Brown, the head is nice and creamy, beige in color, the lace clings in sheets to the glass. Nose is malt, caramel or molasses, not quite sure, also a bit Brandyish, and quite Sniffable. Thats a Guslerism. Front is sweet, the top light, the finish is nicely hopped, somewhat dry, moderately carbonated, and a real Hoot. ranks a respectable #209 0n my current 1000 master beer list. Well worth the try I might add, thanks to my good friend herbjones,
Spicy malty nose, sweet fruity malty flavor, strange corriander taste.
Im with aceofhearts on this one.  To me this tasted like a whiskey stout, with a few hints of fruits and caramel.  This beer was pretty dark, almost a blood red color.  Excellent Brew.
Smelled of fruits and caramel...had a weak head, but was a pretty dark red color.  Taste is best described as a crisp doppelbock with notes of whiskey.

Mahogany, maple syrup in the aroma, very rich and sweet.  A bit of well-balanced whiskey that compliments the aroma quite well, but its still a bit weak compared with Happy Jacks.  (You might hear about this beer sometime...)
A decent beer.  Strong malt flavor with accents of corriander.  not to overwhelmingly spicy.

Why this is in the herbal beer category, I have no idea. All I know is that this was amazing. Taste excites taste buds I never knew I had. Dark, sweet, full, with a satisfying finish. Complex and wonderful.
Amazing. Every aspect of this beer is unbelievable. It has a wonderful aroma, and the flavor is top notch. The alcohol is hardly noticable.
Odd little drink, me likey.
This is a lovely beer.  Deep brownish red and strong head. Nose and palate enjoy the strong malt character of the scotch ale touched by the coriander citrus. More refreshing that you typical SA.
Dark ruby color.The coriander is definately present in the nose along with a nice maltiness. Easy drinking but with the complexity of the flavor you feel inclined to sip and enjoy.

Extremely smooth malt flavor with hints of raisins and other dark fruits.  The coriander must be very restrained as I cant distinguish it.  A very nice scottish ale, one of the nicest Ive had, but one of the top 15 beers in the world?  Not on my short list.
Very unique having a non-Belgian ale with corriander, but it worked well.  Not sure if it was worth what I paid though
Black appearance similar to a stout.  Mildly spiced beer which has a definate unique and different taste.  Once this is adjusted to the beer becomes one of the greats within the UK.

This beer is as good as it gets. It has such depth of flavour and aromas that lasts and lasts. With such aging potential it is a must for the cellar I cant wait to let it age and try it in 2010. Thanks duff for this all mighty beer experiance.
UPDATED: DEC 18, 2013 Elderflower-laced molassesCoriander-coated crème brûléeLicorice-licked vanilla... A bit heavy on the spices for my tastes, but always a compelling sipper...

This beer poured out a very black color that appeared dark ruby when held up. Was no head on this one, maybe due again to temperature served. I had the coriander aroma plus some malt. The flavor was of coriander, toffee and anise. The body was not bad, the finish a little bitter. A good dark beer, but a bit pricey. Maybe on certain occasions.

Bottle (1995 edition).  Few things smell as nice as this beer.  It springs to life with each sip and rises in itensity and complexity leaving an aftertaste as fine as the aroma.  This beer seems to work on three levels.  First, it has the rich malty, mollasses, smoke, and deep flavors.  Second, the deep fruit flavor takes over with plums, apples, and wine-like grapes.  Then the spices take it home with licorice, coriander, and ginger among others.    Unlike some of the great Beligan beers which may have more complexity but would be hard to drink all day or in large quantities, the Jacobite has such a solid foundation and is so well balanced that it would be hard to imagine it ever overwhelming and dulling the senses.
A wonderfully roasted and fruity aroma. Palate of toffee garnished with berry flavors. A great beer.

Here is another one of these beers that I feel obligated to give a high rating b/c it is interesting and complex...but I have to stress that I could not drink a whole glass of this.  The flavor is wonderful - but in small doses.

Immediately after opening the bottle I smelled what I would swear was Froot Loops or Trix (I assume that is the corriander). 1995 edition (through June 2009). Poured a lovely burnt sienna (I have the Crayola to prove it) color with a lively short lived head and lacing. Berries, licorice, and slight alcohol flavor pervade. Almost $5 a bottle here in Ohio but this was worth experiencing and I will get it again for sure.

Spectacular.  Gorgeous appearance.  The aroma changed nicely as it warmed; the spiciness came through most when cold, then supplanted by chocolate richness--like my wifes fresh-baked bitter chocolate brownies.  Filled my mouth with double cream-like richness and stickiness.  Nice flavors, only a lighter presence of alcohol.  Not for drinking in quantity, as much as because of the sweetness as the alcohol.  I love sweet drinks (like port) so no problem here!

This beer poured with an easy and fluffy light-tan head. The body looked black until it is held up to a light where it becomes a dark ruby. The aroma and flavor make this a very interesting beer. The coriander mixed with the very rich, dark malt backbone of this beer made for a very interesting aroma. It reminded me of chocolate covered cherries (the cream kind, not the clear liquid centers) despite the fact that the beer has no cherries in its ingredients. The flavor lacks the cherry notes (although I burped and tasted the chocolate covered cherries). Instead you get a rich toffee and chocolate maltiness with some mild notes of the coriander giving it an interesting taste of something like a bastard child of scotch ale and Belgian abbey ale. There is some bitterness, especially in the finish as the beer warms, but it seems to come from the dark malts as much as from any hops (which were buried under the onslaught of the aromas and flavors of the other ingredients.) The mouth feel if full with a slight cheesiness but not too syrupy. The heaviness of this beer makes it difficult to drink in large quantities or fast, but youll be satisfied after one and will want to savor it anyway.

Dark brown in color with almost no head.  The aroma is quite amazing, though still be a bit too complex for me to describe.  I can taste the chocolate and spice.  Its a bit sweet in the mouth, then spicy.  Nice finish.
Its roughly the color of cola with a very small head. The flavors are chocolate and spice. Very different. Wasnt bad, but not as good as Id hoped for

UPDATED: SEP 30, 2004 Bottle(re-rate). I just love this stuff, i could sniff in all night, coriander, butterscotch, christmas cake. Very soft mouthfeel, smooth, spicy. Main flavours are coriander, raisin(and christmas cake/pudding), butterscotch and mollasses, so smooth and seductive. Very full mouthfeel, and very soft, wonderful to drink.

Very complex beer. Nose is of licorice, plums, pumpkin pie spices. Flavor leans toward molasses, but theres plenty of spiciness and a good dose of finishing bitterness to counter the sweetness. A study in balance.

UPDATED: DEC 10, 2003 One of my all-time favorites!  Nothing quite like this brew - tastes a bit of licorice.  Body like a porter.  Truly unique - like Quelque Chose or Florisgaarden Chocolatbier.  Highly recommended.

UPDATED: NOV 21, 2009 Bottle, BB June 2017.  Head is initially small, frothy, light brown, mostly diminishing.
Body is dark reddish-brown. Aroma is moderately malty (caramel, milk chocolate), with a strong note of coriander and lesser notes of
licorice, cherry, blackberry. Flavor is
moderately sweet, moderately acidic, lightly to moderately bitter. Finish is
lightly sweet, moderately acidic, moderately to heavily bitter. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation, lightly alcoholic.  In the nose, imagine a caramelly, less bright form of Tripel Karmeliet...lots of coriander.  Kind of stark in the mouth; not a lot of malt sweetness or texture to balance the acidity and spice bitterness.  Not bad, but not very impressive either.

Lots of black licorice aroma from a dark brown and almost headless ale. The alcohol was the first thing I noticed. The taste then shifted to sweet tooffee-ish  then to black licorice (or whatever flavor  GoodnPlentys are) and finishes where it started...strong alcohol on the tongue. Very interesting, maybe best as a dessert beer, but the little bottle is a bit steep in price. I think Ill get another to stow away for a later date.

An interesting, deep, spicy, alcohol-y aroma that struck me as being somewhere near patchouli, but not as overwhelming.  Silky smooth mouthfeel.  Balanced, sweet flavor with a mild, yeasty bite (sourdough-ish, but in the background).  All blend together in a very nice experience very like a light liqueur.

Deep brown red beer with minimal head.  Strong coriander aroma.  And what a strong taste -- coriander, currants, malt, and alcohol all fight for dominance. The alcohol leaves a pleasant burn in the aftertaste.  This is clearly a sipping beer.  I like it, but I clearly dont enjoy it as much as some others do.

When it’s written right on the bottle, “best before June 2009,” and it’s not even June 2002, I have got to believe I shouldn’t be opening this beer for years.  Coriander is a medicinal tonic for the stomach, so this is the brew that cures all ails? Like the House Ale, a rich, reddish-brown color, little to no head, I felt this was softer, much more mellow than the House Ale, a milder malt flavor that initially kept disappearing on the palate, but becomes much more drinkable as it opens up and in much larger quantities, a stiff drink any way you look at it, but a true tavern drink, unlike the House Ale which is strictly for sipping, this is a wonderful complement to almost any kind of food.

Suprising complex aroma. The malt and spice really dominate. Deep reddish brown in color. Reminds me of a good barley wine, great balance of malt, spice and bitter with a good although noticeable alcohol content. Definately belongs in the top 20!
I didnt like this beer at all.  it was my first Spice herb vegetable beer.  it has a taste of flowers which i didnt like.  it was bitter to me
Very malty, and the spice came through somewhat as it warmed.

I feel like a party pooper with my relatively low score for this beer. This is a spicy dark beer with a slight floral finish that is OKish but I didnt enjoy this anywhere near as much as the Traquair House Ale.

A dark but relatively headless beer. Extremely strong notes of licorice in the malt, hints of smoky malt flavor reminiscent of a Scottish Ale. Not as much spice as I expected, but an innovative spice beer...fairly smooth on the palate, covers the 8% abv very well. Extremely complex brew.

dark red brown color. thin head. tremendous aroma with berries , plums,chocolate, caramel and . Lots of malt present but the spices work well to balance the sweetness  leaving this both a malty and sharp beer.the coriander spicing is apparent but subtle enough 
to complement the beer without overpowering it. nice smooth mouthfeel and leaves a lingering taste on the tongue much in the way of a well ages scotch whisky. 
perfection if not for the price

THE BEST aroma of any beer I have ever nosed.  Hands down the aroma king.  Beautiful dark amber color and pleasant fizzy head.  Being that I have a head cold at the moment, not all of the flavors are appearant to me.  I do taste mounds of molasses, port and licorice.  Will have to sample again when I am at 100%.

Absolutely different and fascinating.  Looks like cola when poured, deep brown with a rich, thick head.  Amazing scent--rich and sweet, with loads of toffee, butterscotch and chocolate.  Flavor is port, pepper, and a bit medicine-ish.  Also tastes a bit like a milkshake.  Finish is sharp, pungent, and hoppy.  If nothing else, one of the singly most unique brews Ive run into, even if the flavors seemed a mite over the top at times.
Dark ruby to black appearance with a thin toffee head.  Good malt sweetness with spicy/rooty (especially licorice)flavors.  For some reason this one didnt hit me as world class, but very good.

Deep ruby red,thin,dissipating head. Unbelievable nose of orange chocolate,malt,cookie dough,corriander,and others. Creamy mouthfeel,rich body,nice creamy,chewy malt, milk chocolate,very seducing up front. Gives way to spicy blast with hints of licorice and a slightly bitter finish. This guy is certainly one of a kind. A little overpriced but damn tasty and glad I got to try it.
one of the best

A most interesting brew that is reminiscent of a dubbel spiced in the manner you would expect in a wit.  The corriander is immediately apparent in the nose along with cookie dough, bread, milk chocolate and bitter chocolate.  The flavor is very similar to a dubbel with dark chocolate, and cookie dough predominate in the beginning and eventually giving way to the spices.  The beer finishes spicy and slighty bitter.  This is not a hop bitterness, but rather a bitterness imparted by the spices.  Deep brown, nearly opaque color with a medium sized off-white head.  A unique and masterful creation that improves as it warms.

Yes, it absolutely gets thicker, more oily as it warms, in an interesting way. Whatever this brewery does with its malts is amazing; the sweet bits, the earthy bits are perfect. In the House Ale you get it full blast, but now here its mixed with these flavors which at first were overwhelming. I got used to the coriander, licorice smokiness (and whoever said lemons in there has got an amazing palate!) and Im glad I did.
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: UPDATED: DEC 17, 2003 Excellent aromas of corriander licorice and aniseed which carries through to the body. Alcohol is not overpowering and the palate is smooth. Possibly one of the best british beers and better than many Belgian strong ales.
Deep red, almost brownish colour.  The aroma is spicy and fruity, reminiscient of cherry cough syrup.  The flavour is malt balanced, fruity, and slightly spicy with hints of brown sugar and cinnamon.
One of the worlds top beer.
harsh, malty aroma.  hints of spice, dark stout colored.  earthy an d spicy taste balances the malt.  excellent.
1995 Bottle(?) Best before June 2009 drank on 1/13/02. The most interesting spiced beer that Ive had. Super complex, greatly balanced.  A beer to be slowly sipped while pondering its many facets.
The incredible flavor and aroma given to this beer by the coriander makes this a unique beer in the world! Personally the best scottish beer

Some earthy spice in the pour, dough and a slight associated feel next. The malt is dark, powerful and rich, some light alcohol flavors, fruit and molasses as well as some milk chocolate. The head falls into an oily surface of arabesques. The coriander spice as well as the bitter component are on the playbill but in cameo roles - the nose and flavor hold a bit of coriander and the finish is a mild bitter.  Although I dont believe there is any added anise, the flavor is a definite component of the finish and may divide drinkers among the love/hate line of licorice. This is a unique and delicious beer related to barley wines as much as Belgian strongs.
This ia a wonderful beer.  Its delightfully complex.  This beer is by far one of the most professionally done brews around.

This is a one of a kind, top notch ale. First, the aroma is mouthwatering. I was a bit afraid the coriander was going to be overblown, but no. It is perfectly balanced incredibly complex. Initially the spice is dramatic, but then it moves to a heart of perfect Scotch Ale. Very clean finish for a beer of its gravity. Wonderful, if just a bit headless.
Wow.  This is quite a beer.  It is extremely dark with an incredibly unique, but wonderful combination of spices!

Great aroma of malt and spices. Nice dark body with a decent head. Smooth mouthfeel that gently coats your mouth. The taste was of restrained maltiness with a slight touch of spice, however I expected the spice to be a little more assertive. Still a fine beer though.
UPDATED: OCT 12, 2003  I give these geniuses a good rating for being daring.  Enticing herbal, licorice blend that is divine.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text:
a unique mix of classic ale and spice. light opening and a light aftertaste with a lot going on in both. a nice mix of flavors without any one shouting down the rest. dark as night, and slightly aromatic. kind of beer you can drink and drink and drink.

drawback: $5/bottle in my area!
worth it tho, entirely worth it.

Gorgeouse tawny port coloration, beautiful head, nice but strange aroma (some things in there Im not so sure about...).  Flavor:  what I like most is the mouthfeel, so creamy and supple.  The coriander seems to give it a bit of nice bite, but theres also some alcoholic sharpness that Im not so crazy about.  All in all, though, an exceptional beer if not a great one to sip during 90-degree heat.

Truly outstanding and the best spiced ale Ive ever had.  The aroma is surely exceptional: spice, lightly fruity malt, def molasses.  Flavor is def on the sweet side.  Not cloying but coats the mouth.  Superb balance - everything can be detected, nothing dominates.  Masterful creation.  Nice reddish brown color, good head.  I love the foam that clings all the way down the glass.
The spices are judiciously chosen and used. They dont cover the malt; rather, they complement it very nicely.

Does the combination of orange and licorice sound good to you? Then youll love this beer. I, however, found it to be, well...gross. Cloying, sticky, and too rich. I think my bottle may have been old, but still...

Sketmen is full of it....if every one else here has given the beer almost perfect ratings and one guy trashes it.....then I totally do not listen to the guy who trashes it....this beer is very special

Before I comment; this is simply the best beer Ive tried to date, bar none.  This may serve to knock other high ratings down, in fact.  Color is *dark* ruby red with a big frothy head; the aroma is that of a extra malty, sweet Belgian Wit.  Initial flavor is rich and sweet, but not sticky.  Proceeding that, things get complex, but in the most wonderful sense.  The aftertaste begs you to take another sip, but not before savoring the previous one fully.  An absolute must try if you can find it.  Yes, its $5 per bottle, but hey, a pint of Guinness costs about that with tip in most any bar, so you CAN rationalize the price.

All I can say is WOW, the taste is absolutely amazing! After my 1st experience with this, the search was on to purchase more (thank goodness Merchant DuVin is so accomodating in calling back!) I am waiting patiently for my next bottle.  The flavor that arises from this quality ale are amazing, nothing like it Ive had before, definitely one to keep in my top ten.

UPDATED: JUL 24, 2005 Very dark brown colour.  Opaque.  Thin, light brown head.  Ive said it before and Ill say it again, one of the best aromas in beer - flowers, coriander, the finest milk chocolate, toffee, cinnamon, bread crust...a true 10.  Mouthfeel is smooth and silky.  Flavour is sweet, with coriander, brown sugar, light molasses, chocolate, and beautiful malts.  Luscious and complex, one of the worlds most gorgeous brews.

This is one of my all time favorite beers.
The nose is to die for...very complex.  I pick up notes of
vanilla, corriander (of course), malt, oak, molasses (?).  Anyway...
a superb, complex ale.  One of the worlds finest in my humble opinion.
